column10: Slay the spire gets all the love, but this is the apex CCG!
Great rouge-like deck building game
The most fun I've had with a game since Hearthstone back in 2013. Easily recommended if you are even remotely interested in strategic card games.

Slay the Spire inspired, and that's a good thing. STS is a great game. This one has really sucked me in, lots of replay value and mechanics to explore. Art and animation are solid and I have yet to discover any bugs after 37 hours of play. Solid, workhorse game that I'm getting my moneys worth out of and then some, highly recommend.
Its great but not as good as slay the spire 9/10

In Monster Train, you join the war on Hell on the side of Hell. You must protect the train carrying the last remnant of hellfire by deploying a variety of (mostly cute) demon characters and spells to fight off waves of angels attempting to storm the train. Runs clock in at a svelte half hour ‚Äî a good lunch-break length.

While choice to stack the levels vertically instead of, as one might expect for a train, horizontally is a bit odd, the theming gives the game a distinctive look-and-feel that sets it apart within the crowded field of turn-based fantasy deckbuilders. You choose from a variety of factions with distinct powers, such as the Umbra, which devour smaller units to grow stronger, and the Melted Remnant, whose units despawn after a few turns. There are just enough hints of lore to make the world feel robust. Think Snowpiercer if it were populated entirely by Dark-type Pokemon. The soundtrack is also a total banger.

Monster Train is strong in most areas of roguelike design, but geometry it blows out of the water. The train has three levels, not counting the pyre room; within a level, units on both sides are organized in a row, which has limited space. Enemy units enter on the bottom floor, exchange attacks with the allied units targeting whichever unit is currently in front, and then move up to the next level.

The geometry, therefore, functionally has three dimensions: Horizontal, vertical, and time. To hit an enemy, an allied unit usually needs to intersect it in all three dimensions. A lot of the strategy revolves around placing units so that they intercept enemies enough times to take them out before they reach the pyre room; a common failure state is having an army that deals enough damage mathematically but not in the right place and time.

The key to the brilliance here is that the three axes all function differently. In a game with a grid map, ‚Äúone square up‚Äù and ‚Äúone square to the left‚Äù are functionally the same, but here, ‚Äúplace the unit one level up‚Äù versus ‚Äúplace the unit adjacent‚Äù can have wildly varying outcomes. A choice like ‚Äúmove all the units from level 3 to level 2‚Äù can be a game-winning move. This kind of strategic thinking is why I lean so hard on geometry as a design pillar.

And that‚Äôs Monster Train! Overall, this is a solid, well-thought-out game with tight mechanics. While the gameplay can get somewhat repetitive after a lot of replays, especially the seemingly-endless Covenant ranks, the fact that it‚Äôs gotten to ‚Äúa lot of replays‚Äù status in my library is in itself a ringing endorsement.

Read my full analysis on Medium: https://medium.com/@gwenckatz/going-rogue-monster-train-de73fde50fea

Honestly, I've never played a turn-based card game before and even getting to try it on my very close friend's PC, I never really could get into it... UNTIL I PLAYED IT MYSELF. It's definitely a wild experience and the variety between gameplay runs is quite intuitive. Easily my favorite part is how you can get a deck that you can run with and then get a head scratcher of an enemy set you are pitted up against to overcome. THAT, is what I like. It has nice challenge without adding too much fluff to make it feel bogged down or overbearing and it is quite fun in all aspects I'd say. Another strong point for me is the awesome soundtrack. That in of itself adds to the game as well as the other artwork of enemies, NPC characters, and champions and other characters alike. I hear a lot of how it's like Slay the Spire, but personally I do but also don't see the comparisons, but hey! That's all up for player interpretation! Would definitely recommend! üíú

I loved Slay the Spire, but I enjoyed this more. There's a lot more depth and variety, and feels less tedious.
Great card battler. Mechanically interesting. Each faction is very unique.  Difficulty scales well. A lot to love about this one.

Monster Train is a roguelike deckbuilder with an immaculate sense of pace. Combat is strategic and engaging, with the various factions adding an interesting layer of complication. The procedural elements walk that razor thin line between being too random and too predictable, so every run feels fresh and fair. Really the only reason I stopped playing is because the flow state doesn't really click with me. Eventually I started "seeing the Matrix" and battles felt like abstract explosions of numbers. It's still one of the best roguelikes I've ever played, especially for fans of collectible card games.

Never thought I'd be so hooked on a card battler until I tried this game.

That being said, you do lose track of time, game is pretty fun. Buy alone at full price, but would recommend buying the game + dlc at discount.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Having beat Covenant 25 (Monster Train), and Ascension 20 (Slay the Spire), I feel Monster Train was the more satisfying game of the two to repeatedly level up in. The two are hard to compare, but I wholeheartedly recommend this game to fans of Slay the Spire, and card games in general.

This game has the rating it has for good reason, it is along with slay the spire one of the founding fathers of the roguelike genre I keep coming back to this game and it's always fun to go through a couple of runs.

If you haven't yet got this game and slay the spire in your library I would recommend buying both and playing them, keep in mind this game is far easier than slay the spire due to what I believe is lower RNG and is a perfect introduction to the roguelike genre.

I tested Monster Train on the Steam Deck, and it works great. It works with the controller input and the touch screen.

Monster Train is a Roguelike Deckbuilder like Slay the Spire but with its own twist to the game. You have three levels to fight on, with a fourth floor that is the heart of the train, and if that goes to zero, you lose the run. 

The enemy attacks your allies, and then that repeats. In the multiplayer mode, you are challenged to compete against other people to beat the same seed better and faster. I like this approach to multiplayer.

They just added Workshop support to the game. Each time you beat the game, you can choose to make the game harder. You choose two allies to start your run. As you play, you will unlock more allies and cards. I am updating this review to say that I think this game is near perfect.

Monster Train is a game I first picked up year ago, but the more I played it, the deeper I got into it. The deeper I got into it, the more I learned to appreciate it. 

Monster Train is a roguelike deck building game with similar mechanics and features as other such games, but with a unique twist: the presence of a board state, similar to TCGs like Magic. Your mission is to protect your hellish train's engine from angelic invaders. There are three levels to the train (not including the engine itself), which makes for a lot of different gameplay situations. At times, you will have to fend off attackers on each level of the train. Turns can therefore take a lot of time to think about, as there are a near-endless amount of options to take each turn.

This complexity can be overwhelming at first, which is probably the reason why I did not immediately dive too deep into this game. The learning curve is steep for sure. Once you get over it, you will see that the game has a lot to offer. The complexity opens up as you stick with the game, as you discover the wealth of valid strategies and broken card combinations. More than 60 hours in, and I still discover new synergies that break the game. The open-ended nature of the game is alluring and addictive; there is always more to discover and experiment with.

Monster Train is an unique deck builder game that I have really enjoyed. I have played many deckbuilding games and Monster Train is the game that extended my perspective on this genre. The main mechanism of the game is what creates the "Train" part of the game. Your chosen units, with potenital upgrade attachments, is placed one of the three floors, and fight with "Monsters". Floor switch mechanics, floor related upgrades, minion buffers and debuffers, the choice of cards in the overall game is perfectly fit into the mechanism of the game. I strongly recommend this game, especially if you enjoy deckbuilding games! If not, there is no shame to try it :) Might change your mind!

I learned about Monster Train after searching for "Best Roguelike Deckbuilders" following a love affair with others (read StS). What I found was a game that not only introduced new concepts but also grabbed me right away with that wonder of "ohhhh, there's another idea to try on my next run!" I'm 75 hours in so far with no end on the horizon yet.

There are just so many different ideas to try, and so many that feel utterly broken right up to the point you find what counters it. I've lost count of how many times I've said "hehe, I've got this game figured out now" only to be humbled a few turns later with yet another new discovery of something I either hadn't realized or hadn't yet fully understood.

The artwork and sound design are superb. So many little details that are just so satisfying. If you like deck builders and have any interest in seemingly endless broken combinations (until you realize why in fact they are well balanced) then do yourself a favor and check this game out. It's sucked me in time and again, only to be put down for a week and then picked up again and played for hours more. Great stuff!
Great card combos, that feel unique. High rolling a run of Monster Train is the best feeling. Recommend to anyone who likes deck builders.

A week ago I was diagnosed with a terminal illness and the doctors have given me a year at best. I'm so glad I was able to play this masterpiece before I go. I don't know how many people will see this; but I recommend to you to buy this game if you do see it. Gameplay, atmosphere, graphics. everything is masterfully crafted. If you read it, thank you and good bye.

If you like deckbuilder roguelikes like Slay the Spire you'll PROBABLY like this game. 

The positives - the game has a lot of personality, the different clans that serve as the base of your decks are unique with their own fun mechanics, there's a good amount of depth, there's lots of ways to "break" the game, and each run doesn't demand too much time so this game works really well if you only have a short time to play. 

The negatives - the game can be really chaotic and it's often easy to totally lose track of what's even going on, the game falls into the common pitfall of "some cards are must picks and many cards just straight up suck", and other than a couple bosses most enemies feel pretty samey. 

Though to be honest those negatives aren't huge. The game is a lot of fun. 

I think the most important thing to call out here is that this game is NOT Slay the Spire. They're very different games with their own take on the deck builder genre. A lot of strategies that Slay the Spire rewards will backfire on you here. This isn't a bad thing. The reason I'm mentioning this is because I immediately got a lot better at this game and had way more fun once I stopped trying to play it like StS. For example, StS encourages you to ramp up energy per turn and your strength scales largely through passive powers. In Monster Train you're encouraged to double down on strengthening a couple cards and playing them as frequently as you can. Card Draw as a result is waaay more important in Monster Train than in StS. 

Slay the Spire is the better game between the two, but Monster Train deserves a spot in your library if you like deckbuilding roguelikes. Pick it up, it's a lot of fun.

The game is good, card and hero variety is there, lots of content for completionists.

However, unlike most rogulike deckbuilders, the game lacks closure. You just finish a run and that's it. In the standard version of the game, there's no true final boss, no secret boss, nothing. Once you unlocked the main heroes, there isn't much to look forward to, rather than just being a completionist.

I'd be fine with that. However, I noticed they've added a true boss that could bring closure in a paid DLC. I can not in good faith believe that this is priorizing game quality over greed - and that to me, is what's been ruining the gaming industry lately. 

It feels like they left it out of the main game on purpose, so that more people would buy the DLC - and to me, letting core content out of the standard version is worthy of a negative review. 

DLCs are fine when it adds extra heroes, cards, artifacts, etc on top of an already working product - so they are mere complements to the core experience. But something that is as crucial to the experience (to me) such as having proper closure and a proper final boss is a huge letdown. Beating it in standard version feels like you never actually beat it.
 
Good game, bad developer practice. Hence the negative review.

If you love deck building games, this is a devilish little treat. With new mechanics beyond just deck building, you place your units along your train to strategically take down the enemy. With lots of challenges that can move you beyond just the introduction, this makes one of those come back to game to kill a little time with its reasonably paced runs. 

Each faction you can play has enough variances where you will have different strategies while approaching the enemy. Lots of upgrades to both your units and magic cards to make for more powerful combinations. Decent sound work, though the being hit noises in multihit attacks can get a bit annoying.. Fitting music and just a fun vibe all around.

The biggest downside is that its not on Steam Deck. WHAT a perfect gem this would be on it! I would also caution against getting the DLC right away until you've played the base game more as it will make it significantly harder.

GRADE: A for me. I have played many deck-building games and most of them fall into the same general format, Often they end up being shoddy knock offs of the original mechanics, card design, and game play loop that Slay the Spire nailed so perfectly. This is not that! It brings tower defense and rouge-like deck-building together in a fun unique hybrid that i really enjoyed playing hundreds of hours. And on top of that it has a fun multiplayer survival gauntlet mode that's worth playing.   

Monster Train isn't your average Slay the Spire clone. Sure, while it definitely scratches that deck-building itch, but it throws in a three-lane vertical tower defense twist that changes the game experience and strategy depth. Instead of static encounters, these monsters advance toward yours bases core as they climb floors, forcing you to juggle defense across multiple fronts Similar to Plants Vs Zombies.

Monster Train really embraces the power of card combos, letting you stack buffs and exploit mechanics to create ridiculous Damage or Debuff machines, It's not just about winning; it's about witnessing the glorious Frankenstein's monster you've built tear through the opposition.

While the learning curve is steeper than a Hell-bound express train, the payoff is immense. Every victory feels like a hard-earned conquest, a testament to your deck-building prowess. and once you feel like you've got the mechanics and progression mastered you can go online and play some multiplayer survival matches, where you try to out last or out score you opponents on a parallel run. This is a pretty neat feature that densest get the amount of credit it deserves for getting competitive multiplayer Deck-building to feel fun and functional.
If you like either the Tower defense or the Deck-building Genre then i think this is worth both your time and money to try out.

[i]Monster Train[/i] is a brilliant deck building game.

The game has several clans, of which you pick two, one primary and one secondary. Primary clan provides champion unit, which is the reason why it matters, which clan you pick first.

Each clan has it's own pool of cards and they tend to certain play style. Which means that with every run you will be combining (mostly) two decks to synergise and support themselves. This interaction is the main factor that makes the game extra fresh experience for the first 600-800 hours; the game's initial content is not added, but multiplied together. If the developers decided to create one new deck and add it to the game, they would functionally add another 40% of already existing content via clan combinations and possibilities. Yes, [i]40%[/i] increase by creating one clan (there are 6 clans at the moment of this review, DLC included). The more I play, the more I adore this detail.

Of course, such game design comes with a caveat; since each deck potentially interacts with another, it means that balancing the game is extremely hard. One nerf might make some cards unpickable, another buff might make some card combo completely broken. The game doesn't try to be perfectly balanced, as often the fun you achieve in the near-end stage of your run is over-stacking and insanely boosting your strategy beyond being broken.

Overall, I had a lot of fun. I think I'll continue to have more. If you like deck builders, getting insanely strong and broken combos and a fresh variety while playing the same game for hundred of hours, I'd recommend you to try [i]Monster Train[/i].

I don't like Roguelikes. I really don't. I still don't. But I like this game.
To begin with I have always enjoyed building decks but roguelikes tend to take an approach where you are supposed to master extremely barebones repetitive games with some sprinkles on top and the occasional bone the game throws you.
Which means a lot of your enjoyment hinges on the perceived quality of the basic game mechanics and their balancing, as you need to consider your ability to clear a game with extremely limited resources and options.
I get bored easily and quickly because a lot of them lack variety from the get go and increase their difficulty without a sense of progression within the game. Getting better at a game doesn't mean much to me, it's something that happens incidentally as I spend time with something I enjoy. 

What makes Monster Train such a treat is that it offers 6 different clans to play with a combination of two of them on every run. Each clan has 2 leaders each, each of which level up thrice throughout a run into 3 different specs that can be combined. Leading to a lot of variety and ways to experiment off the bat and throughout. Generally, this game gives you the most consistency among the roguelikes I have played, which makes it immensely fun and more realistic to experiment with certain builds as opposed to other games where you need pure luck and 200 runs to try out some build you thought of. The game has a collectible card aspect where you unlock new cards with cleared runs and bonus frames for clearing the extended difficulty runs. So you are encouraged to clear the game with even weird builds for a sense of progression. It is superficial but all this extra work on the presentation makes the game a joy to play. The presentation is generally fantastic even though the animations are extremely underwhelming. Monster Train is somewhat easy to start with but can grow quite challenging later on. Not to mention the DLC adds new extremely cool and surprising mechanics to the game that utterly change how you perceive units. I am far off of beating the game but I see myself coming back to it occasionally. 

Looking at the negatives, I think for extremely dedicated people it may not be hard enough, and Slay the Spire has tighter balancing, with much more weighty decisions moment to moment. The increase in consistency also means that after 100 to 200 hours, a lot of your runs might feels samey. This is great in my book as that is about as long as I am willing to play a single game anyway but it might be bad in yours. Also, the DLC is fabulous but the extensions and difficulty it offers have left a few champions behind to an extent where getting a win can be hard on higher ranks. I wish the developers had balanced the game around high covenant playthroughs because unfortunately my favourite hero is probably among the worst in the game. Among the dozen or so roguelikes I have tried, this is possibly the one I have enjoyed the most.

One of my favourite roguelikes for sure.

Pros:

+Countless Card-Synergies, every playstyle is legit
+Lots of differently factions and combinations between them
+Polished graphics and sound
+Tons of content to unlock, goals to achieve, etc (The steam achievements on the other hand are easy)
+Deckbuilding and Tower Defense Genres are perfectly mixed here
+Optimal length of a single run (~45 minutes and you are done)
+You can read tons of lore in the encyclopedia if you want, or even show it ingame.

Cons (nothing really, I feel that you should always point out negatives as well, but they really are minor issues (except for the DLC, you will see later here)):

-The Endboss variations differ a lot in difficulty, which was quite annoying during my "early" runs. This is offset by the fact that you can see the endboss-variation right from the beginning on and build your deck accordingly.
-This is more or less a general roguelike problem but I point it out: Sometimes the rng just lets you loose and you can do nothing about it. Or sometimes a slight miscalculation from your side will result in a devastating loss.
-THE DLC!: I have grinded through the base game and only THEN the DLC is worth it, when you absolutley thirst for more content. Otherwise it is more likely to ruin your experience.
To break the DLC down: it ramps up the difficulty very high but lets you build "broken" decks. Sadly it results in mostly unfair games, a high likeliness of trail and error and makes a lot of factions and synergies useless. So basically you are fine without it (it does not create new steam achievements as well), you give it a lot of patience so that your experience is not ruined or you finished the base game and want more content.

This is an extremely satisfying and thoughtfully made deck-builder game. I highly recommend it to those who enjoy the genre! As a former Hearthstone addict, Monster Train scratches the right itches without hooking you on a monetization treadmill. It's at least on par with Slay the Spire, and an improvement in many regards:

- Fast-forward toggle option lets you skip through long combat chain sequences. I REALLY appreciate this game for being considerate of the player's time. There are no tedious filler animations to wait through.
- The art is quite polished and the character designs are charming. The style is a bit tongue-in-cheek while still being cool. Very comparable to Hearthstone's aesthetic.
- The final boss is indicated at the beginning of the run, so you can draft your deck accordingly.
- Cards you win playthroughs with receive special borders, incentivizing draft variation between runs.
- Your in-game logbook records your win status with different clan combinations, so there's tons of replay value.
- RNG is thoughtfully incorporated without hinging massive swings. It serves to break up monotony more than it ever feels like a slot machine. You are guaranteed to draw a playable unit every turn, which really smooths the gameplay. 
- The "floors" of the train create an interesting strategy dimension for unit placement.
- You can save-scum by exiting to the main menu in combat. This restarts the battle from the beginning, forgiving your errors. 
- While there is no PvP mode, daily challenges let you compete with other players for high scores. 

A typical run for me takes 30-45 min average. This game really hits the sweet spot of being elegantly in-depth while pleasantly casual. The developers seem to truly understand how to create a fun deck-building experience. I actually have nothing negative to say about this game. It's definitely worth the purchase!

Summary: Barely recommend. Decent game, but I'd recommend it more if it had a different theme and less random bullshit. 

Monster Train plays great, the mechanics are solid and fun, and the art and animations are bright and colourful. It isn't difficult to see why so many people gave it a thumbs up. If you like PvE card games or rogue games, you'll most likely enjoy this.

It is a good game, and it's always nice to have another decent single player card game, but unfortunately I'm sick of rogue games.

There's nothing like having a great hour long run going, not even coming close to losing... and then having the rug pulled out from under you because you ran into an enemy that cannot possibly be beaten. It's like, "Well... I was having fun and did want to keep playing, but...", the game decides nope, that's it for you. Back to the start. It's great fun while I'm actually playing it, but then I'm left with a sour feeling at the end of each run, only wishing I could have kept going and having zero desire to start from the beginning again with an entirely new random setup.

This game is great for anyone who just wants to play for short segments at a time. Otherwise, if you want to play for long stretches, be prepared to start from the beginning over. And over. And over again. There really isn't that much variation between runs to justify all of this meaningless repetition. Just let me play the damn game. But they won't, and you can't because randomisation in games has become the new padding to make up for lack of content and to give the illusion of a full game experience.

I mean, I get the idea. I've played enough of them. Get as far as you can, level up, go again. It's been done to death and I'm sick of it.

Plus, I'm not fully on board with the whole being on the side of hell versus heaven thing. I never did appreciate games like this. Especially where they try to make hell look good. The fuck is that? Some people take the concept of evil quite seriously, while others think it's a theme. Hades, Bayonetta, Monster Train... they all want to make you think being evil is cool for some reason. Can't even blame the music because nobody listens to decent rock anymore, so we'll just have to blame Bieber and leave it at that.

Monster Train knows what it is and strives to be the optimal version of that. It isn't hampered by odd design decisions or misunderstandings about what the player would want from this type of game. It feels polished and well intentioned. Still, for all of the pros, there are a few cons that seem to be baked innately into this sort of game.

Pros:
1. The game is built around handing the player a massive number of possible upgrades and modifications for their cards and units. This allows for an unreal number of possible synergies, some pleasingly game-breaking, and gives the game a very wide-open feel. 
2. Monster Train's varied factions each have several potential archetypes and synergies that play with the other factions in fascinating ways. Some of the concepts, such as units feeding on other friendly units to gain strength, or units that burnout like candles after a set number of turns, are really unique.
3. The Covenant levels and unlocks give the initial hours of the game an extra dopamine kick that may hook players initially as they come to grips with the game's mechanics. There is a lot here for completionists.

Cons:
1. Frequent non-gameplay. This is a byproduct of the game's design, with its multiple floors and waves of enemies coming over time, so its hard to call this a design flaw. However, often a winning strategy involves buffing a tank-y unit over and over again each turn. Spending five or ten turns playing the same few cards over and over isn't particularly engaging. 
2. Gameplay density. To that end, moments of meaningful decisions often come primarily at the start of a run and decrease as you progress. Decision making is the core component of any good roguelike, and towards the end of a run, especially a busted one, things can get a bit dull. The game encourages player's to make a deck that does one thing, and to optimize that one thing into the ground. 
3. Lack of visual immediacy. The presentation of Monster Train is about as good as it can conceivably get, so again its hard to call this a flaw. Still, its hard to know if your floor will be able to take out the next wave or the boss in advance, short of some guesswork or a calculator. Combat previews help the player understand what will happen next, but for future waves and the like it's hard to know for certain at a glance. 
4. The game doesn't feel like a card game. When cards can be changed so fundamentally, or when the deck is thinned to the point of doing the same thing every turn, and given the RNG-mitigating effects of things like priority units being drawn each turn, it doesn't feel like you're playing a card game. I generally don't get the feeling that I'm playing the cards I'm dealt, or considering probabilities regarding what I may draw on my next turn. 

Each of these drawbacks can hardly be called a design flaw, and though they hamper my enjoyment of the game, they don't make it a bad game by any means. This game has the potential to draw some players in for countless hours, and I think that over time I will return to Monster Train from time to time. This game is solid, and definitely worth purchasing on any sort of discount.

If you have ever played Xenoshyft (an irl deckbuilder lol) this is pretty much a digital version of that.  I really enjoy that game so all the possibilities that come from being digital make this a no-brainer for me.  I love Slay The Spire, but this takes from that, adds Xenoshyft, and runs.

Another thing I love about this is the difficulty.  Instead of starting off impossible and slowly getting more possible (like 99.9% of roguelikes/lites), this one started easy and seems to get more difficult as you go on a win streak.  Three runs in and I haven't lost yet, but I can sense it coming.  A lot of people would count this as a strike against the game, but I really don't understand why more games aren't diverting from the norm and taking this route.  I do love roguelite elements (Hades, For the King, etc.), but it is refreshing to be able to start off easier and progressively ramp up the difficulty until you lose and break your win-streak.  I hope more games take this route.

One extremely minor gripe (not even so much against this game specifically) is that I am sick of this look/style.  I know there are limited budgets regarding how these games look, but it'd be cool to see it done "better".  I don't know how else to say it.  At the end of the day though I completely play these games for the mechanics, as does nearly everyone else, I'm sure.  So again - just a very minor downside IMO.  Nothing that would turn me away from the game.  

I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes deckbuilders.  You do not need to be a fan of roguelite mechanics to enjoy this game!

The best in rogue-lite deck building combat ever designed, with brief sessions (8-9 battles), nuanced difficulty considerations that keep the challenge at your level and escalating, and diverse variations of card builds, which make every run fresh.  

You beat it or die in 30 minutes - 1 hour, but as the difficulty scales with your level of play, every decision feels particularly weighted.  The game also feels more fair than other deck builders.  In Slay The Spire you could have a great deck, with a balanced defensive card representation, but still not draw a single defensive card when you need it most.  The tiered train, allows the developers to scale these things best out of three turns, so defeat feels less like a single, unfair hand.   

The expansion is also amazing, as it rewards you with new enhancements, even allowing players to combine units to make over powered hybrids, but as you take on these great buffs you also increase the difficulty.  Accrue 100 difficulty currency (pact shards) from these new upgrades and get an especially difficult boss for a more absolute victory.

[b]‚ÄùI summon blue eyes dragon in attack position‚Äù[/b]

[hr][/hr]

[b]Monster Train[/b], a gimmicky card game that doesn‚Äôt feel overcomplicated and fills the void of roguelike card games by not copying the most famous example, instead creating and maintaining its own identity throughout.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Pick a main faction and a supporting one and you‚Äôll get a base deck that includes a mix of the two.

Besides the usual upgrades such as decreasing costs of a card or increasing its damage or giving it various proprieties as well as many ways to restock resources, duplicate cards and find new ones the game spots a very particular encounter style.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
You are on a 4 floors tall train, enemies will enter in the lowest and each turn move up by a floor to reach your 4th in order to damage your lifebar that you‚Äôll have to keep for the whole run, so it‚Äôs paramount that you deploy units on each floor seeing what units to put in front to take the burnt of the damage while trying to figure out or plan out what spells and abilities to use to weed out damage dealers in the enemie‚Äôs backlines.

Each encounter has a boss, some major some minor, but all will lock themselves on the lowest floor on the last wave and battle on until either they or your units are dead.

It‚Äôs sounds like a lot but despite that every mechanic, ability and run is very easily memoizable.

An extra layer comes from the different playstyles the various factions, and by extension the various combinations of them have, maybe you‚Äôll choose to stack arboreal tanky units in front while the much harder hitting demons stay in the back, or maybe you‚Äôll try a run with the oceanic spellcasters that get more powerful with every spell you cast combined to the emberblighted that further specialize in buffing to have units exponentially scale in power .

[h1]Story[/h1]
A very simple one, the angels have finally defeated the forces of hell and extinguished its flames, only for a small faction to survive, trying to bring the last spark that could ignite the underworld again to the pit.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
My only gripe is a few generic tracks and VERY bland design of the game‚Äôs units and enemies. 
[hr][/hr]

Recommended, it‚Äôs not too different from what you could‚Äôve already played before discovering this title but it‚Äôs different enough that while playing you won‚Äôt see any similarities once you‚Äôve entered its mindset.

Impeccably balanced and challenging gameplay. Absolutely must try this game you like roguelike card/strategy games. Plays like a tower defense mixed with Slay the Spire. Each run has quite a bit of variation, allowing you to try out the many interesting combinations of powerful spells/units to develop effective strategies.

Amazing game with a lot of depth and very satisfying risk/reward ratio. DLC added an entire new layer of deck/card manipulation. Has plenty of QOL features such as game speed and showing you the end result of a round, which is a godsend in a game where sequencing attacks and triggers is paramount.
While its visual style isnt to my taste, it didnt prevent me from enjoying this gem of a roguelike with a unique take on the deckbuilding genre. Loved every moment, even the losses.

(Let's see how many train puns I can fit in a review) When I first saw this on Steam, I thought "oh no, just another Slay the Spire clone" so I wasn't fully onboard about it. But being an STS clone isn't a bad thing. In fact, Monster Train improves on several mechanics that make even more fun to play than STS. 

First things first, the train tracks. Like STS, you get to choose your path en route to the next boss. BUT what is good about MT is you can see which track offers the "best benefit" based on your situation, so it wise to switch things up and drop your one-track mind of just picking strong units. The benefits can be seen in train sight: one track shows you health recovery and an artifact, the other gives you a new spells, a unit and gold. 

Another cool feature of MH are the monsters. You get a primary class of monsters, supported by a secondary class. Each class has their own unique spells, units, and play style. You can choochoochoose which classes to get that best complement each other. 

The game IS quite short though, so it's perfect for those quick breaks during a busy day of work (one run will take 15 mins at most since you can automate it -- to an extent). The final stop (after you've defeated the boss) is a bit disappointing, unlike in STS which had a "true ending" mode. 

Overall I would recommend buying this game. If ever they release an MT2, I'm all aboard on that one.

Second best single player deckbuilder on the market, closely behind Slay the Spire.

The visual style can be a little off-putting at first (looks a bit "mobile game-y to me for some reason) but once you get used to it, it becomes one of its strengths. Really adds a lot of character to the monsters, and helps with visual clarity.

Each clan has its own strengths and weaknesses, but the real strength of the game is that you can pair any 2 clans to fuse their playstyle. For example, if your bruiser clan is taking too much damage to survive to the end, you can pair them with the tank/healer clan to give them the survivability needed to maximise their damage.

Monster Train is a Rogue-like deck builder.

You are the conductor of the hell train on your path to the abyss or something. On your way there you will be attacked by enemy encounters that want to destroy your pyre to stop the train from moving. Once the battle starts and the first wave of enemy units enter your train on the lowest level, you can play cards that summon monsters or play spells. Then the enemy units attack your placed units, your units attack theirs and then they move up to the next level on your train. Then you draw cards again and can place your units and cast your spells. Once they reach the fourth level, they will attack your pyre. Once the pyre is destroyed, you lose the run.

After some rounds the final boss of each encounter will spawn and instead of going up after one round will duke it out until the boss or your units on that level are dead.

After your successful encounter you have a moment of brief respite and get the chance to add cards to your deck, improve your cards or pick up relics that grant you some sort of benefit.

This makes Monster Train a deck-builder with some tower defence mechanics.

There are 5 (6 with dlc) clans that give you unique cards and champions. You have to pick a combination of two of these, with each clan having two champions to choose from. This creates up to 80 (120 with dlc) unique starting decks.

At the start of the run, you can see the main boss encounters which vary in their respective strengths and weaknesses, so you should build your deck accordingly.

You can create heavy tank builds which damage your enemies with thorns or frostbite, stack multistrike on your damage dealers and buff their attack value, summon endless hords, revive your units, debuff your enemies or simply let them fall back to the bottom floor.

With the right synergies you can create exponentially growing feedback loops that can kill bosses even before they enter your train.

Monster Train has a rich micro cosmos to explore, to learn and to apply with daily challenges adding a fun long term element of replayablity.

10/10

[h1]What I liked[/h1]
- [b]Upgrading Cards:[/b] Finding the right upgrades for your cards and stacking them is very satisfying. Having two upgrade slots and sometimes even three or more makes for some fun opportunities to increase the power of your best cards. 

- [b]Duplicating:[/b] Fully upgrading a card and then duplicating it is some of the most satisfying things I have done in games for a while. Especially with the merging of minions that the DLC includes. What is better than one overpowered minion? 

- [b]Synergies:[/b] You will be keeping your eye out for finding cards and abilities that fit well together. Because there are many to find. You have a great ability that happens on strike? Put some multistrike on that minion!

- [b]Lots of Content:[/b] There are more than enough cards, artefacts and upgrades to play around with. I was more than happy to play with the first 3 factions and the many combinations they provide. Each with 2 different heroes you always have at your disposal at the start. The 5 factions in the base game make for so many combinations that I have barely touched the DLC faction. As you are playing these factions you will slowly unlock new cards for them as well. And even when you have unlocked everything there is still the daily challenge, modifiers, achievements and of course the accession levels to unlock.

- [b]Leaderboards:[/b] A lot gets tracked in the game, your history to the detail of the individual choices you made. All to be compared with friends or other players.

- [b]Seed saving:[/b] A neat little feature is that you can save the seed of a run you just did and share it with friends to see how they would do. You can even turn them into challenges that can be shared with the community.

- [b]Satisfying Sound and VFX design:[/b] All the impact, rewards and just general feedback on every action you take is well done. It never gets annoying.

[h1]What I didn‚Äôt like[/h1]
- [b]Can‚Äôt observe battle when choosing:[/b] Some cards let you make a choice in the middle of battle. Like returning a specific card when it was consumed. But there is no way of glancing at the battle once you are on this screen. 

- [b]Boss stats:[/b] At the start of your run you can see what the three bosses will have for abilities, but there is no way of seeing it again once you start the run. So it either becomes a memory game or you make a screenshot/photo with your phone. This is quite bothersome. Thankfully there is a mod for it.

- [b]Hero upgrade possibilities:[/b] Every hero has three different upgrade possibilities and at the start it takes a while to know what they are. Since this is something you can always synergise with it would have been nice to see the three possible upgrades in the clan select window. Instead I now had to open the logbook everytime I forgot.

- [b]Easy Early Runs:[/b] The first two runs I did were not very challenging. The end was reached without trying too hard. It would have been nice to set a starting difficulty scale that would adjust. There is an XP system that rewards you more the better you play, but this only means you unlock all the clans and cards faster. The ascension levels take over this role later.

- [b]Losing units:[/b] At first when starting the game I was surprised to see my units not going to the discard but losing them for the entire battle. There are ways to heal them or increase their maximum health in battle but it still felt bad. Losing one unit could make things spiral out of control. Only after a couple of games did I understand that this is the core of the game. Later you also unlock a faction that turns this upside down with cards that return previously defeated units. This is a small gripe I have with the game. Maybe the tutorial should be clearer on this.

- [b]Intro video:[/b] The cutscene video when you start the game is nice but it would have been great to have an option to turn it off. Thankfully there is a mod for it.

- [b]Hellrush matchmaking:[/b] There is still enough players doing the daily challenge for a filled leaderboard but the hellrush‚Äù mode is dead. I waited for an hour on a Friday evening and didn‚Äôt get any matches. 

[h1]Why others should try it[/h1]
It took me a while to write this review. Everytime I wanted to submit it I wanted to refresh my memory and got stuck playing the game. If that is not recommendation enough I don‚Äôt know what is. The DLC is great too.

Along with a tremendous amount of quality and polish, Monster Train has two rare features:

1. It allows players to see ahead all the way to the final boss, and plan accordingly.
2. It has an auto-projection system that displays the outcome of combat decisions before the player acts, allowing the player to focus more on high-level strategy instead of number crunching.
Fun game.

I've had a lot of fun with this game. The obvious comparison is with Slay the Spire, and I think I like this one slightly more. It's really fun how you get you choose two "clans", compared to Slay the Spire's one character at a time. It produces some super interesting and unpredictable synergies - unlike in Slay the Spire where the synergies are obvious right away. I also love how you can upgrade any card in a lot of different ways, which can sometimes lead them to be useful in ways which they weren't before. I often find that most of the drama/hardship in Slay the Spire comes from whether or not specific cards show up (randomly) in your options, whereas this game feels more dynamic than that. I think this is because there are a ton of ways to mutate your deck, some from random events, but from some the multiple different shopkeepers. It makes it feel like your choices have a meaningful impact on whether you win or lose and it's not just left to chance.

Maybe the only downside is that this game has very few mods available, and when you do use them, they disable progress through the game, whereas Slay the Spire has tons of working mods out there which have significantly prolonged my interest in it. 

Honestly, if you're into this genre, you should play both games :)

I've only just played 4 hours of this game but I felt compelled to create a review based on my experience. Coming from Slay The Spire (spending around 120 hours in that game), I couldn't find a roguelike and deckbuilder which was similar enough, but also different and varied enough to StS to scratch the same itch. Chrono Ark, despite being an amazing title, didn't cover the same feeling of enjoyment that StS did.

That's when I saw Monster Train on the steam store. Whilst initially I believed it to be some cheap mobile game port going by the font, art and screenshots, I looked closely and saw many elements resembling that of Slay the Spire, and was immediately interested in picking up the game. This was no mistake. The game, fundamentally, follows the slay the spire / roguelike deckbuilder gameplay, with spells, items, relics and story events etc to find on your journey. However, as aforementioned, the game switches it up and adds some very interesting caveats which instantly hooked me further. 

There will be more to come on this review once I hit the higher levels and unlock the rest of the covenants (I've been victorious in one run so far, and the variation I currently have, as well as all the variation and rewards ahead of me suggest that I could easily spend another 60 hours or so in this game. In any case, I intend to write a much more detailed review at that time but wished to create a review early to say the following:

If you are looking for a game like slay the spire, but believe you have more or less exhausted StS vanilla content, then try this game. It's fantastic.

Surprisingly fun deck builder. While superficially similar, it's very different from 'Slay the Spire' in that you manage a roster of heroes and spells, levelling them up and deploying them on three levels to fight the increasingly difficult waves. Although you start out with only two factions, there are five factions in the game which you unlock by summoning heroes. from these, you choose your main faction which gives you a champion unit witrh special abilities and a support faction which gives you spells and unique heroes.

The very early stages are a cake walk which can lure you into a false sense of security because the difficulty ramps up after three of four encounters. Then you see the need for devising a consistent upgrade strategy. Levels are quite short and can be played through quite quickly and then you get to choose your upgrade path, allowing you to upgrade your spells on one path and your heroes on another. And you can discard some of your cards or heal your pyre.

There are a tremendous number of synergies to explore here. How you upgrade your champion, which heroes to pair it with, there are so many possibilties here.  I've yet to unlock the last two factions but I'm already spoiled for choice as to what to do each run. There are even a selction of really powerful spells which can only be cast on the floor below your pyre so there's a lot of fun to be had here.

I recommend the game Monster Train for newcomers to the card battler genre. Monster Train offers a simple and easy-to-understand gameplay, but with your own creativity, you can come up with hundreds of ways to combine cards and strategies to create your unique playstyle. This game features clever design, unique game mechanics, and visually stunning graphics.

I know many of you are curious about the differences between this game and Slay the Spire (STS), so I will provide a detailed comparison of these two games below, so that maybe someone reading can decide on which card game roguelite they'd wanna pick up first.

Both of these games are roguelite deckbuilders; every run you start with a basic set of cards and then progress by slowly drafting more cards level by level to make a more cohesive, synergistic deck. The key difference being, you mainly use damage and block spells in Slay, while you use units in a tower defense-like layout in Train. STS was the first notable game of its kind, and Monster Train is quite derivative but unique enough that in some ways it might even be the better game.

Both feature lots of build variety, run variance, interesting pathing, some really creative cards, and of course some juicy, juicy synergies. I wanna make a fair argument for each, and give 3 examples per game of a strong point it has that might make you consider it over the other.

STS - Strategy: There are many, many ways to make a viable deck in Slay The Spire. You don't have to rely on getting all the right cards for a build, in fact the best players don't even think in terms of "builds" but just draft cards to tackle the individual problems that lie ahead. On the other hand with Monster Train you might find yourself going for the same few optimal combos again and again. In particular there's a unit upgrade called Multistrike which effectively doubles or triples the impact of any damage scaling plan you have. While it's not required to win, it's kinda silly how it makes almost everything you do better.

MT - Synergy: You can totally break both of these games with absurd combos, if you know what to look for and get a little lucky. I would say it's more fun to do in Monster Train tho, you will get these broken runs more often and imo it feels better to see a row of super-buff units hold the line against hordes of enemies, than to nuke the enemy in 1-2 turns in Slay (though of course that is fun too). MT also makes card duplication and removal much more accessible, so once you come up with a winning strategy it's much easier to have it materialize and be consistent. More often than not, your final deck won't have any fluff. Each clan also has unique starting cards which means certain synergies can get rolling faster, as opposed to Slay's basic Strikes and Defends that you get with every character. On top of all that, the DLC's unit infusion mechanic takes everything to the next level, basically letting you smash 2 units into 1.

STS - Balance: There are 4 characters in STS and 3 of them are so different yet so well-balanced with each other it's a marvel. The 4th character Watcher is admittedly more consistent than them once you understand her, but the way she scales is so unique that it's fun to play her as well. You have characters that do all sorts of different things, from proccing effects by exhausting all your cards, to poisoning enemies and then turtling up, and yet all these characters and even the strategies within them are not much better/worse than the others. Genius design. In Monster Train though, some clans and champions (basically your primary unit) are definitely better than others. Sometimes you might even throw the champion away. Even within the clans there are certain units and strategies that are straight-up better, especially after the new enemies added in The Last Divinity DLC. At low Covenant levels, it won't be too much of a problem though.

MT - Content: Slay's art style is unique for sure, but to be honest Monster Train's is just a lot better. Aesthetically the things you're doing, the units you're controlling, the enemies you're fighting and how you're attacking each other, looks awesome. The soundtrack slaps, the card art is animated, everything has interesting flavor text and a lot more lore than Slay The Spire. I have to admit when I first played STS I was a bit put off by the designs, and I didn't really experience that with MT. There's also a Logbook that keeps track of your achievements and progress in a more in-depth way than Slay does, and is more convenient overall.

STS - Difficulty: Some people want a challenge, a game with a very high skill ceiling, that will take months and months to master. Slay The Spire is for those types of people. Ascension 20 is brutal, especially with the bonus boss that I won't spoil. On the other hand, Covenant 25 in Train is still a relatively stress-free experience, and the secret boss of MT does hard-counter certain strategies but it's not too much of a difficulty jump, just more specific in the problems it wants you to answer. I try to keep up with both communities and have noticed MT winstreaks go into the several dozens, whereas in STS even a streak of 10 is very impressive. It's very satisfying to make all the right plays, reach the boss all cut up and bruised, and eek out the win with your rag-tag collection of cards that you were smart enough to make work together.

MT - Difficulty: Wait, again? Yeah I decided this was a strong point for both of them depending on your perspective. Monster Train is still plenty challenging in its own right and it does not hold your hand, but it is more approachable and gives you more tools to make the perfect deck. As previously mentioned, duplication and removal are more accessible, in STS you'll be lucky to even duplicate one card. But also, you can put exactly the upgrades you want in units and spells, whereas Slay's cards have preset upgrades. Making any spell you want -1 cost, or be held over for every single turn, would be absurdly broken in Slay The Spire, but in Monster Train it's a regular occurrence. It's also easier to avoid permanent damage, while STS has you constantly taking chip damage. You get more rewards between each combat, while STS might have you fighting several enemies before your first shop. I could go on. A lot of what you'll get used to in Monster Train could make Slay The Spire look brutal and frustrating by comparison, while still being difficult enough to be rewarding.

I honestly can't say which one of theses games I prefer. I want to say Monster Train but that might just be recency bias, and the fact that I'm new to card games so I lean towards the more accessible one. But hopefully these key points helps you decide which one is more your style. I can honestly say both of them are some of the most addicting games I've played. I have yet to play other deckbuilders like Roguebook or Griftlands, but the bar is set very, very high.

Monster train is a decent deckbuilder.
Unfortunately, if you compare it to STS, the extra steps and the suboptimal status indicators make every turn take longer without any reason. It simply lacks the straight forward plain gameplay that STS has. Now, it comes with a few extra things, like having basically two tribes that form your deck, and you can alter the cards' stats. But if we compare it to a more fleshed out and complex Deckbuilder, like Griftlands, it simply does not stand up.

The positioning mechanics are interesting at first, but sadly very bland after an hour and not worth the complexity. The multiple floors are interesting at first, but not having the whole battle visible at once gets tiring quickly. I got it on a 60% sale, and probably won't play it much further. STS and Griftlands are just superior options, each in their own way.

The soundtrack is stellar tho.

I haven't played long enough to have a strong opinion about the game, but I'm enjoying it so far and very much want to be able to recommend it. Unfortunately, it kind of seems technically broken. Many people report crippling startup hangs that haven't been addressed after years. The game provides no feedback as to what's going on during the hang, and no log messages either (even if you dig in the save directory to find the logs). There's a laundry list of random things in the discussion forums to fix this, and it's a total crapshoot whether they'll work for you.

The game looks fun and I'm enjoying it so far, but the devs absolutely MUST fix their broken startup bugs for this to be recommendable.

I would say that Monster Train is to Slay the Spire what Battlefield is to Counter Strike.

The game-play loop is far too short for its own rogue-lite mechanics, the synergies too simple, and the map progression is over before it really gets a chance to shine.

It does look good, and the synergies themselves are somewhat unique. There's less RNJesus involved in what cards you may or may not get, and it's a lot easier to restart a run/battle than STS, too. That's about it.

EDIT: Two words: Little. Fade.

I can not confirm it being the "best deckbuilder" or generally being a very versatile experience. I like the tower defense part, but for the price tag it gets repetetive very fast. Every deck a very smoll number of monsters & spells and you end up aiming / shooting for the same thing over and over. Other synergies just do not keep up in tempting you to try them. Especially when they take super long to set up / build, but then the run is over after what is it? 5 battles? It feels sad at first to be kicked out of a smooth run, and in later difficulty feels like you were meant to have more time to build something before facing the boss. Decks at that point are half finished at best, killing the aspect that's meant to be satisfying and the actual fun of "succeeding".

If there was more different cards / options / modes(1) outside of the DLC I would probably upvote it. But I am not getting enough playtime out of this. The first 12 or so hours were enjoyable, the last couple sittings I forced myself to keep trying as I did not want to waste my money.
(1:) I know there is custom, but it does not count towards any progress so what's the point in a game that's not a sandbox but defined by 'beat this' mentality?)

I'm sure if I've spent a lot of playing time it would all eventually feel natural and I could just enjoy all the details and make the most of all the mechanics the game has to offer, but everytime I feel like playing a quick game, I just go to an alternative.

Still recommend it, since there is a lot of effort and gameplay to enjoy, and it seems there are regular updates. But if you are a fan of Slay the Spire and wanted another fix, there may be better games for you, like Dicey Dungeons or Griftlands, both extremely well-designed and, in my opinion, have a way better user experience than Monster Train.

Monster Train is a very fun roguelite cardbuilding game! This game is similar to other games in the genre (e.g. Slay the Spire) in many ways like designing combat around defense/shields, damage, DoTs, and other common abilities/mechanics. Monster Train is also unique in ways that make it interesting and distinct from other games. Instead of a single hero you deploy several monsters over multiple floors, so who and where you deploy is important. Choosing a primary and secondary for each run from the four factions with unique abilities keeps the game engaging. You choose between two simplified paths between each battle with a few rewards. Overall a great game that's definitely worth the price.

Monster Train is an incredible deck-building game that offers a fresh take on the genre. With its unique blend of tower defense and roguelike elements, it's a game that's easy to pick up but hard to put down.

The game's card mechanics are deep and strategic, allowing players to build their decks to fit their playstyle. The five different factions each have their own unique strengths and weaknesses, creating endless opportunities for experimentation. The game's difficulty is also adjustable, ensuring players of all skill levels can enjoy the game.

The presentation of Monster Train is exceptional, with gorgeous visuals, a fantastic soundtrack, and a dark and twisted art style that perfectly matches the game's tone. The game's story is also surprisingly engaging, with a variety of interesting characters and a well-crafted world that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

Overall, Monster Train is an absolute gem of a game that deserves to be played by anyone who loves deck-building or tower-defense games. It's a game that's easy to get into but hard to put down, with endless replayability and an exceptional presentation. If you're looking for a game that will keep you hooked for hours on end, Monster Train is the perfect choice.

I love this game so much. It's like a TCG, a deckbuilder, a turn based strategy game, and RPG all rolled into one. A friend recommended this game to me because I liked Slay the Spire, and while I do love that game as well, this one blows it out of the water for me. The reason is because of the multi-level combat system and how innovative that is for me. Yes your deck is important, but HOW you play your deck changes from level to level depending on the makeup of the various waves of enemies. I also love getting to level up characters and improve their stats and give them added abilities. I just love love love this game, and if you like Slay the Spire this is the biggest no-brainer for you...ever.

Very diverse roguelike: a lot of different in-game mechanics lead to many random-overlapping choices, with may result in some insanely crazy combinations. With that much random the game feels somewhat unbalanced (in player's favor), but also very fun. You can win with very, very different approaches, which is very satisfying.
 
Once you realize that you can restart any battle from its beginning - it becomes rather difficult to lose in this roguelike. But, often you are playing with such haphazard crazy decks, that 'restart maneuver' transforms the game into an interesting puzzle, where you have to find a path to victory.

Also: the music is amazing. One of the best orchestral soundtrack I've heard in games. Practically every single track is great, the boss ones are just masterpieces (my favorite being Fel and Archus themes). Though the most beautiful track (called The Descent) is in the credits, accessible right from the main menu. According to corresponding achievement - only 15% of game players heard this one. A shame.

Get ready for a ride in Monster Train while it last. I think Monster Train deserve more love, it was way underrated and shun away piece of gems. I think this could be erected by presenting Multiplayer Monster Train with maps/story/adventure/choose-me-plot of journey where coop player able to make a choices at the same time coop to defend the train on each of their own floor to the destined station.

So! 200 hours in, I have to come back to leave a review. 

This game is fantastic, and contrary to a lot of the brush-off comments I've seen, it's not actually a Slay the Spire clone. In some ways, it's better than StS, changing up the battle mechanics in new and interesting ways. The depth here is unbelievable - it feels like every run I'm discovering new synergies between different cards and different factions. Side note, the lore is great too, I love reading the snippets about every card and character in the log book - it adds so much personality to the world! StS can feel very disconnected from any real sense of time or place in contrast. 

Morale of the story: Monster Train is a fantastic game, if you love rogue-like deckbuilders you will love this, even if you are a hardcore StS addict you should give it a chance - you'll probably enjoy the Hell out of it.

I have spent 3 years with this game and a little over 150 hours later, I am now in tears...This is my first ever game that I have 100% the achievements for! It is also a super rare case, that I stick with a game past 100 hours and find it the same amount of fun and only Monster Train has been able to achieve this. This game us dumb in the best way possible: just when you think you are taking the game seriously and nothing is working, you have fun, with a build that is just for the lols and looks kinda stupid...only for it to get you to the next covenant level!!! So many loud laughs I have had with this game! There is so much to learn and it is a journey that will teach you so much, not only game wise but will teach you a lot about yourself too...or maybe I am just being quite dramatic haha, well, either way, a quick checklist for ya:

1)You like roguelikes/roguelites with fun, satisfying and replayable gameplay loop ? 

2)Do you love an easy to learn and very hard to master complex system that will reward you with constant excitement for learning new stuff just when you thought you had it figured out ?

3)Do you like games with impeccable identity, charm, artstyle and creative character concepts ?

4)Do you want a game that you can both tryhard if you feel like but also just return to once in a while for one game or two ? 

5)Do you wanna keep coming back for more because the last boss was JUST 500 health away from victory and you KNOW you could do better if you just pick a bit more AoE, invest in some front line tanks, position your backliners a bit better and THEN FOR SURE IT WILL WORK ?!"

If all or really any of these is a yes: GO PLAY THIS FUCKING GAME, PLEASE, I BEG YOU ITS SO GOOD, GOD FUCK I WILL MISS THIS GAME SO MUCH IT'S SO FUN !!!

Thank you Monster Train, I will forever treasure these 3 years

It's a more accessible, funner version of slay the spire. I consider this to be a nearly perfect deck building game so I thought I'd check out the negative reviews and see what common complaints were.

It's too easy: The first ten covenant levels can be a tad easy, sure, but those levels are largely where you are being exposed to what works and what doesn't in the game. Does a unit and spell combo "sort of" work at covenant 10? Then you will be absolutely clobbered 20+. In the "easier" parts of the game, pay attention, even if it feels unnecessary. Learning which unit infusions work and which ones don't can be the difference between winning and losing later on.

There isn't enough content (not enough enemy units, not enough effective strategies): The later portion of this complaint tells me the player didn't learn the game. There are so many cards that appear low-value at first but are game-changing when upgraded in a certain way or paired with another card. The complaint about there being a lack of enemy units is fair enough.

The game is "shallow": A similar complaint to there not being enough effective strategies, which is completely ridiculous. Underpowered units can find their place in a covenant 25 run and not even the most unfortunate run generation is beyond conquering.

To sum up once more, this is a more accessible slay the spire. Unlike the aforementioned game, you won't have to sit in a single combat for an hour+, trying to figure out just a handful of turns with a calculator. This game has plenty of depth in deck-building and combat strategy while avoiding the strenuous and, at times, overly random nature of slay the spire.
Great. Simpler that slay the spire, but those perfect runs can feel even more satisfying.

Game is great if you're into deckbuilding games, but if you have an iPad or iPhone, buy that version instead since they play pretty much the exact same way (actually the iOS version is a little bit more fluid in terms of moving around the train and navigating the interface/selecting cards, compared to the PC version. The base price is actually about $20 cheaper in the Apple Store as well, and you can play that on the go (I have no idea if this game works well on a Steam Deck).

I'm writing this after I finished the game in Covenant 25 and its way too easy comparing to Slay the Spire. That is because of some scripted artifact and card drops, almost removing the RNG factor of roguelike card games. But they designed the game not around card drops, but around clan interactions. While the scripted artifact and card drops may make the game easier in some ways, they don't detract from the fun of playing the game. In fact, the real enjoyment comes from the clan interactions, which provide a lot of variety in terms of playstyle and strategy. 

What's even better for people like me is you can actually start and finish a run in one sit. The game doesn't overstay its welcome. Unlike Slay the Spire, which can sometimes feel like a slog, Monster Train's runs are relatively short and sweet. This makes it easy to jump in for a quick game, and keeps you coming back for more.

If you're looking to explore the roguelike card game genre, Monster Train is definitely a game you should consider trying out first.

Welcome to my essay on why Monster Train can have my babbies:
Let's set the stage: I got 3 free months of XBox Game Pass from Discord more than a year ago.
Not wanting to waste those 3 months, I held onto the code right before it expired, then activated it and started to explore all the possibilities. I didn't wanna waste time trying to download Halo or something, so I just downloaded a bunch of games that were small in file size. However, even after downloading these games, I struggled to play them... The thing is, I like to consider myself a Gamer, but I find myself lacking in what the kids call "Gamer Energy," and because of this, more often than not, I stick to a small handful of games I enjoy, barely straying from said games.
Modded Minecraft, Terraria, Stardew Valley, Sudoku, Picross, A whole lotta Nintendo Gams!
I enjoyed playing games that had a story, gave a bunch of tasks to do, or just let you solve some shite.
RPG, Action, Adventure, Survival, Platformer, Puzzle, Strategy, Rhythm, Shooter, Beat-em up, Fighting!
I liked many genres, and my indecisiveness helped me not stick with a single genre for long.
Though, with all these great genres, there was one genre that I really despised... [u] Roguelikes! [/u] [b] DUN DUN DUUUUN! [/b]

No, but seriously... I didn't like Roguelike games for the longest time.
Since I lacked that "Gamer Energy," playing a game where starting over again was the main idea had me looking at these games as if they were just throwing your hard work away to start a fresh game... [b] BOY WAS I WRONG! [/b]
Since I was having a tough time playing the games I downloaded from Game Pass, I felt that I needed to force myself to play ANYTHING before I lost my membership.
[i] "Oh look, a Roguelike. I can play this, and then when I lose within 2 minutes, I can just quit and get on with my life." [/i] - Said the naive Roguelike Virgin.

I played a round and lost. [i] "But, I feel like that was going somewhere..." [/i]
I played another round and won. [i] "Wow, that was a neat build, but I feel it could've been better..." [/i]
I played ANOTHER round, and then I realised that the round I was playing was actually my 10th, and it was almost 5 in the morning.
After that night, I felt like I needed to show this new wonder I found to someone.
So I got my lil sister to sit down and build a deck with me; after that round, she asked me if we could do another one. Then, the next day, she asked if we could play it again.
[b] WE SPENT THOSE 3 MONTHS PLAYING THIS GAME! [/b]

This game surprised me... I played Slay the Spire before this game, and yet, for some reason, Slay the Spire didn't click with me. Though, after playing this game, I went back to play Slay the Spire and found that I was able to enjoy it a bit more the second time... I also started to try out other Roguelikes, and now I have many new Roguelikes occupying my wishlist. Monster Train changed me.
When the 3 months were up, I went straight to Steam and bought this game without a second thought. I haven't done something so impulsive in years, and usually now-a-days when I buy something that isn't groceries, I get a bit of buyer's remorse... Yet, this triggered no such thing.
I did it for the core game, and the moment they released DLC, I did it for that. LATER, when it was released on the Switch, I bought that motherducker without ANY restraint!
They're still working on the Google Play version of the game as I write this, and I'll tell you this now: I'm buying it. [b] ZERO SELF-CONTROL!! [/b]

I love this game and only hope that it can grow in popularity.
Ever since they released the workshop, I've checked on the mods all the time to see whats new, and for some time now, there hasn't been anything...
It has its fans (*points at self*), but there just isn't a lot of noise going on for it compared to other Roguelike games doing similar things. Though I still cross my fingers every night when I drift off to Sleepytime Junction for this game to blow up and get all the attention.

Sorry for this long-winded review... I just really love this game, dude!
Please, for the love of all that's lovely in this world, [b] SUPPORT THIS GAME! [/b]

This is a tower defense game wearing Slay the Spire's skin. The games get compared a fair amount, but beyond the main gameplay loop (adding, removing, upgrading cards from a deck) the similarities fall off quick. This is not just a StS clone; both are excellent games offering something unique.

MT:
-Faster runs with explosive power bumps
-Aggressive deck transformation
-More starting permutations

StS:
-Better balance, more nuanced design
-More of a traditional "deck builder"
-More archetype cross-synergies

If Slay the Spire goes down, then this game can put you on the train to heaven.

As I stand guard on the Monster Train, I cannot help but marvel at the irony of it all. Hell has frozen over, and the inferno that once raged with unbridled fury has now been reduced to a mere flicker. But as the last line of defense for the final burning pyre, I must stay vigilant and protect it from the forces of heaven.

The stakes are high, but the journey is thrilling. With each battle, I collect new cards and artifacts, each one bringing me closer to restoring the inferno to its former glory. The strategy involved in building my deck and choosing which demons to summon is endlessly entertaining.

But the challenge is real. The enemies are fierce, and their tactics unpredictable. I must constantly adapt and evolve my strategies if I hope to survive. And the rewards for success are truly satisfying. The sense of accomplishment I feel after a hard-fought victory is unmatched.

In Monster Train, the fate of Hell is in my hands. It is up to me to lead the charge against the forces of heaven and restore the inferno. It's a daunting task, but one that I am more than ready to take on. Bring it on, angels. I am ready to defend the final burning pyre and ensure that the inferno burns bright once again.

Monster Train is a deckbuilder which prioritizes broken decks. Improvement comes from learning just what those broken combinations look like, and how to spot them early and commit to them. I personally think it is less careful/requires less thought compared to Slay the Spire, but it is also probably my second favorite deckbuilder because it meaningfully differs from the latter in a way other deckbuilders do not. When I want careful, precise decision making, I'll boot up STS. When I want enormous numbers and an absurd amount of effects on screen, I boot up Monster Train.

If you're in the market for a roguelike deckbuilder, this is one of the best options. 

-Reasonable skill floor, skill ceiling is in outer space
-Huge variety in playstyles through the champion/race archetypes
-Tightly balanced, the core gameplay loop will keep you entertained for a few hundred hours
-Satisfying visual/sound design

In my estimation, one of the very few games in the genre that appeals strongly to both casual players and dedicated fans. Unbelievable gameplay:price ratio as well. Strongly recommend.

[h1] Monster Train - Addictive Fun with Hellish Charm [/h1]
[b]What can I say?[/b] Monster Train is one hell of a game! Pun intended. From the moment I started playing, I was hooked. I purchased the game at 8pm last night, and before I knew it, the clock struck 6pm the next day, and I had already logged over 16 hours. That's right, more than Dead Space, which I've owned for over two weeks.

The game's premise is simple: defend your train from the forces of heaven with a team of monsters. But don't let the simplicity fool you. There's a lot of strategy involved in building and managing your deck, choosing the right monsters, and upgrading your spells and abilities.

The graphics are beautifully designed, and the music fits the game's hellish charm perfectly. The gameplay is challenging but not frustrating, and the replay value is excellent, with plenty of customization options to keep things fresh.

If you're a fan of card games or strategy games, Monster Train is a must-play. And if you're not, well, you might just find yourself addicted like me. All aboard the Monster Train!

[u]Pros[/u]

Addictive gameplay that will keep you coming back for more
Challenging but not frustrating difficulty
Beautiful graphics and fitting music
Excellent replay value with plenty of customization options
[i]Cons[/i]

Might not be for everyone, but give it a chance, and you might surprise yourself
