If you like Slay the Spire, you'll love this game. The combos you can pull off are tons of fun, the characters all have their own unique playstyle that adds tons of variety to each playthrough, the card selection is the right size where it's not too large so that you never feel like you can get familiar with anything, but it's not too small where it feels restrictive, and the gameplay cascades onto itself in a very satisfying way and you get the sense like there was a lot of effort poured into this project at every level.
I'm not usually a big fan of deck-building rogue-like games but this one is fantastic. The pace, progression and combat are all very well done.

[h1]Not for me[/h1] 
Monster Train is a well loved addition to the roguelite genre. However, it didn't fit with me. There is clearly a large structure in place to keep runs changing and evolving over time. However, in a singular run fights can feel very similar. Part of the issue is that Monster Train is close to an auto battler. You place down your units in a specific order, possibly use a spell or two, then you let the scenario play out. When I first started I though including a fast forward button was silly, now I realize that even on the fastest speed I see myself reaching for my phone as the blurs on screen play out as they will. I know people love games like auto chess, but that combined with each fight in a run feeling fairly similar with small adjustments I just don't feel like an active participant. 

There is clearly a lot of content in this game and I have a friend who loves it. However, it is not one I enjoy or recommend.

Starts off like a subpar version of Slay the spire, but quickly becoming its own thing and addictive at that. Not in a bad way though. Plenty of variety and fast paced, plenty of challenges too. I'd recommend this to anyone that likes deckbuilders. A solid choice.

I've always loved card games, and have even played some of them on a professional level. So when I see a nice colorful game like Monster Train on sale, I'm instantly inclined to buy it.
Monster Train is a roguelike card game - which means that it doesn't contain a campaign mode or anything of the sort. Instead, you'll be battling the same enemies and bosses, but using different cards. Subsequently, you'll unlock more cards that you can play with. There are several suits (or colors, if you like) of cards in the game. Each of these suits is represented by 2 heroes, which are powerful cards that are always in your opening hand. At the start of your run, you choose a hero and a support suite (which must be different from the one your hero is in). You get some random starting cards in both suites, and off you go to the first level. A standard run consists of 8 levels packed with artifacts and opportunities to improve your deck. There is a fight at the end of each level, and a boss in each of these fights.
There are only several different mechanics in Monster Train, mostly associated with a single suit. However, you can still make interesting decks that are bursting with synergy - and ultimately, that's what card games are all about. There really isn't that many cards in the game, and you'll soon know them all by heart. Alas, that also means it won't take long to see all the game has to offer. When you become completely familiar with the game, a run only takes about half an hour or so. Somewhere around that point, the game stops being amusing.
Monster Train is cleverly designed, simple and fun. I would recommend it to anyone who likes deck-building and the combinatorics of card games. It's a shame it doesn't feature more cards and enemies, the game would be a lot better.

Monster Train is a combination tower defense, card-battler, rouge-like. Over a series of 9 rounds you will engage in the same two step process of refining your deck then engaging in a series of battles. 

Your deck is comprised of one champion, a variety of units (which may be placed onto floors of the train to fight), and a variety of spells. Cards primarily come from a pool of three sources: your champion (who comes with his/her own set of basic default cards), your primary clan, and your secondary clan. With two diverse champions within each of the five factions, there are 40 (=2 * 2 *  (5 Choose 2)) truly unique combinations to experience.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Great diversity all around, from the feel and interaction of the factions, the champions, the events, and the enemies.
[*] The overarching implementation of leveling up your deck after each fight through the a choice of one of two tracks to take (each of which with different rewards) lent a sense of control and strategy to the deckbuilding.
[*] Each run was easy to get into and was of the perfect length.
[*] Imaginative unique creatures.
[*] Deck refinements (card upgrades, trashing cards) were well done.
[*] Extremely well-priced on sale.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] All single-player, turn-based games need an Undo button for deterministic moves. Mis-clicks happen.
[/list]

Summary: I finished Rank 25 with all 40 combinations. I found some of the combinations a bit too taxing (i.e. you need good luck overall with your offerings), but that may be expected with so many interactions. On the whole, I found that the Rank 25 difficulty was right where I wanted it to be (as compared to StS which I personally find much too hard) and all combinations had their own source of enjoyment to find. I got a great deal of time out of this title and for anyone who enjoys card-battlers, this is an easy recommend.

Overall: 9.5/10

Steam Reviews are the make-or-break for me when thinking about a purchase-- happy to report that pretty much all the praises being sung about Monster Train are true.

It has everything I want from a roguelike deck-building game. I love the versatile and distinct decks I can make, I love the varying win conditions you can reach, I love the excitement of the randomness anchored by the solid structure of the card pool. It's awesome how overpowered you can get after you've learned how to make the most out of your cards.

One thing that I thought was gonna be a problem: not being able to save mid-battle like in Slay the Spire...but that turned out to not be a big deal at all either; you get autosaved before battle, which is absolutely fine.

Excited to play more of this game.

It's a really great game if you like card/deckbuilding roguelikes and games like Slay the Spire. 

The different clans and the fact that you enter each run with two each time makes up for a great amount of replayability! and lots of fun synergies!

Feels like a very intentional alternate take on the Slay the Spire formula, where they've streamlined the acceleration process and generally no longer demand patience or caution. It's a deck builder where you're not overly stressed about your choices, since it's abundantly clear when some card or relic will launch your deck into the synergy stratosphere. Hp isn't so precious, and defense isn't always necessary or rewarded, so you spend more time leaning on the gas and less time making responsible decisions. 

STS worked because you felt extremely smart identifying synergies, and could only Break the Game every so often. Monster Train works because the line is so clear that you can just sit back and feed off the power start to finish. Remains to be seen how that nature affects its infinite-replayability score vs other roguelites, but I will at least stick around long enough to get through the in-game completionist incentives. Easy recommend for any fan of deck builders.

It wasn't a bad time but most of my playtime has been really mid with this game.

I'll start with the good things about the game. Game mechanics are fun and the game has strategic depth. It has creatively designed cards and overall the gameplay, while it derives a lot from Slay The Spire, has a lot of personality. The game is relatively easy for a veteran card gamer, but it gets challenging with the covenant levels and I feel like the difficulty curve is extremely fair. The game is also pretty intuitive to understand.

Alright so here are the issues. I feel like winning doesn't feel satisfying enough. I think the main reason behind that is because a run is pretty short (30 min) and also there aren't enough surprises along the journey. The way the encounters and bosses function is quite monotonous as well. Tho the biggest problem this game has is it's repetitive nature, lack of content and a lack of unique strategies / deck archetypes. The pool of cards for a given class is too small and while the game has a cool dual class system, it seems like most classes don't mix well together, so it seems like you only wanna build your deck around your primary class and only take some cards from the secondary. Also I feel like another thing that amplifies this issue is that most classes have extremely strong starting cards. This makes it so that as you increase the difficulty of the game, you end up having to build more and more around these starting cards, which suppresses experimentation. Also the game gives you a lot of agency over how many cards you're able to purge/add to your deck. On paper that sounds good, but what this ultimately means is that there's no need to improvise and there's no risk in fishing for the right cards and rejecting everything that doesn't match your vision. The only exception from this monotonous deck building is that sometimes you find cool artifacts that you can build your deck around, but unfortunately it's pretty rare, since most artifacts in this game are basic. So this game is really fun when you're still figuring out which cards are good and which ones not, but after that it's really mid, and that's the issue.

If you like Slay the Spire you'll love Monster Train.

I was put off at first by the weird name and cartoony, hearthstone-clone, F2P-look the game's store page has, and only bought it because it was heavily discounted. I needn't have worried - underneath the slightly strange branding there's an absolutely stellar game.

The mechanics are perfect - it's easy to understand but hard to master. Card games can be difficult to get right - it's often fairly straight forward to play 'optimally', and then you're basically at the mercy of the RNG and just along for the ride. That's certainly how I felt with Hearthstone. But Monster Train gets it right: there's still a lot of RNG - it's a rouge-like after all - but there's a lot of strategy as well in terms of what you play where; which battles you choose to fight and which you leave to a different floor. There's also a good amount of 'right, how can I make this deck work?' too; there's not [i]that[/i] many opportunities to draft units, so while you can have an ideal build in mind, you have to be willing to change direction.

I've spent many happy hours playing Slay the Spire, but this has replaced it as my 'I've got an hour to kill, what can I do?' game. It's easy to drop into and easy to save and come back to if you can't afford the full hour a run typically takes. There are still cursed runs, just like in any roguelike, but it's still enjoyable even when you're never drawing right. And when you get a bit of luck and a build that really synergizes: it's a blast.

My only critique is that I wish it were easier to 'come back'. Usually when a run starts going bad it's really difficult to recover. I think slightly more choice on some of the rewards would serve that purpose - it would let you tailor your build better and fill in that one card your build needs but the RNG isn't giving you. But that's fairly minor - and I find exactly the same thing in StS (in fact in StS it's worse - while your demise is still assured, it's much more drawn out).

Don't let the art-style fool you, it's deep and awesome.

For context, I bought the game at -80% without the DLC (the latter remains quite expensive even on sale).
With that price in mind, I would almost recommend the game. However, I think the game is clearly lacking in many aspects. 

After 15 hours on the game, the only thing that comes to my mind is: "Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle".
The first 10 hours of the game feel great, you unlock many cards and clans, you learn things, and all is good.
But after that, you soon realise that every run is just the same and that the more you unlock, the weaker you actually get (while enemies kind of stagnate despite their buffs). A lot of great cards are quickly unlocked, but higher levels cards feel more like obstacles than potential assets. They will just dilute the previously owned good ones, preventing you from playing the way you want. 

Difficulty levels are also way too numerous. They put the highest to 25, but you need to win as many times to unlock it. The problem is that there are not that many differences between each level of difficulty, leading to very repetitive runs. You don't feel any progress. "Why?", you ask. Because there is absolutely no variety in terms of enemies or bosses. 2-4 runs are enough to see all bosses and enemies. That's it. Nothing new later on. I get that it is to prevent too much randomness, but added to the fact that you only have a very limited amount of events, and that every (of the two) path you can choose from is quite the same, you end up repeating the same runs over and over just to get a slight penalty and worse cards. Add to this that most of the big bosses are HP sponges, and you get very few viable options for clans combinations and decks.

The game is far from being horrible, it would be a decent 3/5. But it gets stale pretty quickly.
For these reasons and because I know that there are better options on the market for the same range of price, I cannot truly recommend it.

Obviously you see "deck-building rogue-lite" and immediately jump to the Slay the Spire comparisons. 

These are two completely different experiences. 

The easiest place to start is the core gameplay experience. Both games have similar core gameplay loops where a player's combat capabilities are determined by a deck of cards. Within combat, this deck is shuffled so a player never knows exactly what combat capabilities they will have going into a turn. Cards have an associated cost to play and affect the gameplay in any number of ways. The player moves between combat scenarios and intermissions where they may affect the content of their deck of cards as well as observing special events/healing/etc. If player health hits 0, the run is over and if the player is able to kill the final boss, they win the run.

I think the most obvious difference between the two games lies in understanding how they want the player to learn and execute optimal pairings within combat. First of all, of the 4 StS classes, none of them have one ‚Äúbest‚Äù strategy. Each of them has numerous strengths and synergies that can bring the player to the final boss. In general, I would describe the cards/relics as ‚Äúdeliberate.‚Äù Interactions between cards/relics/potions are intricate and it‚Äôs difficult to explain without knowledge of the game. The important thing to understand is that cards/relics impact each other in surprising ways. This is exemplified by the fact that each card has one specific upgrade that can completely change the way the card can/should be used. So more often than not, the decision to take a card/relic depends heavily on the makeup of the current deck and if there are valuable synergies to be had. The problem (and where the real strategy comes in) is that there are enough cards/relics and few enough opportunities to add them to your collection that going into a run with a strategy in mind is just about a premature death sentence. When two players win separate runs with the same class, it‚Äôs all but guaranteed that they were forced to use different strategies. Even two players on a run with the same seed will likely end up with polar opposite decks. Then, of course, is not knowing what enemies one will encounter until they get into a fight and not knowing what boss they need to prepare for until they defeat the previous one. For players to be successful, StS requires that they be adaptable and understand how cards/relics work together while having the forethought to decide if a card is worth taking when there is no guarantee of getting the other card required to maximize the deck synergy. 

While the run-to-run variability within a single class is definitely present within MT, it's to a much lesser degree. Relics/cards don‚Äôt quite have the same ‚Äúdeliberate‚Äù nature to them. Each class has a narrower scope than the 4 StS classes, so a given run will have more obvious playstyles and cards are more easily adapted to a given run as cards have 2 upgrade slots and the player is able to pick from a list of modifiers as opposed to one unique one. Within battle, the major strategy comes from knowing when and where to summon your monsters as you have 3 combat floors all occurring at once. Each floor has a maximum amount of monsters it can hold, and each monster has its own effects/strength/health. Bosses are mostly the same and predictable. Overall, strategy lies more within liking the playstyle of a given class and understanding how the different classes interact with each other. It's still satisfying killing the final boss. I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs better or worse, just different. You‚Äôll get the itch for one and then the other. If you like StS, this is worth checking out.

Additional notes: the first time I installed Monster Train, I gave up after the tutorial and one level. Not interesting, a bit too generic, and yet very confusing on some levels, too many things... And yet, months later, the second time was the right one. I actually understood what they intended, I gave it more effort... and it was good! Admittedly, I am not one of the team that considers it better than Slay the Spire, I still believe StS is better (more elegant game design, richer, longer, etc). But Monster Train is still a very neat roguelike deck builder in its design, albeit a bit more casual and much shorter than StS. If you liked StS, give this a try! Very interesting ideas (mix of decks in Smash Up style, stairs in the train, etc) that give a fresh look to the genre, unfortunately very short (the idea is to make short runs, which is a fair take on it, for me it just gave less replayability sadly).

I liked Monster Train since the beginning, but after I understood the world and the character concepts I got totally hooked by the game. That's a really cool idea: different factions of Hell are trying to reignite it after Heaven took over and transformed it in a frozen wasteland. And the factions are diverse both in terms of themes and in terms of mechanics. It's a really intelligent game that is not necessarily difficult to play at higher levels, but demands a lot of attention and strategy, which is not annoying at all when you are dealing with such amusing designs and ideas.

If you like Slay the Spire, play this game!
I always enjoy finding combos and synergies, and this game has a lot of opportunities for those.

I loved Slay the Spire, but that was the 8-bit Nintendo, and this is the 16-bit Super-Nintendo. 

More "classes", more unlocks, more build variety, added late-game challenge, and a bigger pool of bosses make Monster Train a bigger bundle, but the on-screen instant math that helps you calculate if targets will perish, keeps the pace every bit as fast as Slay the Spire (which again, I love) while having three full lanes of action to balance with. 

The soundtrack is one of the best of the year. It has a real momentum and weight to the action tracks with the ambient tracks having nice mix of strings and older instruments that keep an engaging atmosphere. The music is reminiscent of Trevor Morris (Army of Two), Darren Korb (Hades), and Nobuo Uematsu (Final Fantasy), and great.

Though, can I be real with you? 
Get it for iPad if you have the option. That's the best experience.

I love how upgrading your cards at the merchants always gives them huge buffs and makes them feel OP (even if it turns out that they actual aren't). The only thing that kind of annoys me about this game is that certain leader combinations can give you two sets of cards that really don't play well together. I wish the game was designed so that all of the leader combinations worked out to provide synergy in some way. 
But if you like deckbuilding card games like Slay the Spire, I feel pretty confident saying you'll love Monster Train as well.

Some deck combos are obviously OP which are a lot of fun. Other deck combos appear weak but I've enjoyed discovering their OP combos that I overlooked.

If you love Slay the Spire, you'll probably enjoy this one too. The base game feels a little too easy, but you can do more difficult runs as you progress.

Yep, no choice but to compare this to Slay the Spire, and it's not holding up. For me, deck-building roguelites require a certain nuanced depth to keep you pulled in: the itch to start a new run and a need to progress. Spire, in each combat, can at times be blunt, but much of the play requires calculation. You can't just play the same every single combat, even with a particular deck. Monster Train however seems to trend in the other direction, where the deck is played the same in every combat, and either it works or it doesn't. The depth in play isn't there within a single run. Across runs, yes, but then runs take too long to get that return. So, when I'm feeling that urge to play a casual game like this for a run or two, it's simply much easier to just jump into Spire. The return is better.

Style, graphics, sound... all solid.

P.S. I dislike tower defense games... that might be part of the problem here.

My favorite deckbuilder so far! It differentiates itself by being about spells and unit placement, while also invoking a lil' bit of Tower Defense feels.

Why Tower Defense feels? You try and place your units as tactically as possible on 3 floors. Waves of enemies will enter the train and they will keep ascending, unless you vanquish them in time. When they reach the 4 th floor, that's a problem because that is where the heart of your train is (called Pyre)... it can defend itself, but also has limited health. If the Pyre reaches 0 health: It's game over, man! Game over!

The game stays interesting to play, because there's different Clans to unlock which offer different styles of play. By playing these Clans, you will unlock more cards, items and map events, which will expand your deck possibilities and ultimately survivability.

The real challenge in this game begins as you up the difficulty (called Covenant level). These Covenant levels are comparable to the increase in run difficulty in other Deckbuilders. There's a Leaderboard (with your Steam friends on it) and more unlocks to motivate you to keep playing, trying to incrementally beat the available Covenant levels.

There's also a DLC for Monster Train that will offer even more variation and flexibility, but I haven't had the urge to touch it yet, as I'm still learning the ropes in the base game. 

Definitely worth your money!

(Works great on the Steam Deck! One of those perfect types of games for it).

I got this game on sale for ¬£9.00.  Although it was worth the sale price there are 2 reason because of the bad review.

1. When you beat the game you unlock challenge mood which makes the game much harder as the enemies unit and bosses (particularly the bosses ) power up as you power up which makes the later round bosses too hard.

2. Seraph the chaste.  Is a boss that is just way too over powered as his buff abilities make the fight unfair and near impossible to win.  His first ability reduces the buffs on your units by half and the negative abilities on enemies units by half which makes it harder to power up your units to be strong enough to kill him and his second buff causes him for the first 15 hits that he does on your units to heal back the damage worth that he causes for these hits.  This means that you either need to kill him very fast before he starts attacking or do enough damage and have your unit be strong enough to over power the heal;th regain when he start to attack which is not easy because of his ability to half the buff values on your units.  I was unable to beat this boss and I suggest if the makes are planning on making another game then they try for themselves to beat each boss to get an idea if any of them are way to unfair like this one.

Addictive and satisfying, this game does a great job at making you want to keep unlocking cards and factions to play around with and add to your strategies, allowing for some wiggle room with snowballing and becoming god like in the later levels. The three floor system is unique, I found it tedious at times because I found the cards that incorporate them as a mechanic weren't as useful as a straight up spell or unit cards and wasn't worth the mana resource, but I loved setting up units in a kind if tower defence feeling way.

Compared to others in the genre it's not as difficult (Although it has challenges and modifiers to supplement this) and the runs feel quite short, I find this makes it more addictive and tempts you into testing out the modifiers and covenant levels. Losing isn't too frustrating because you'll still pick up exp and faction levels based on achievements during the run.

Pros:
 - Addictive and satisfying
 - Varied play styles and factions to mix with
 - Seemingly endless challenge and difficulty modes add to the play time

Cons
 - Can feel repetitive despite variation, due to run length, the same bosses, enemies and back drop
 - A lot of cards try to use utilize unique mechanics but I feel they're just not as useful

Monster Train is a nifty take on the card battler trend. You are essentially managing 3 battles with 1 hand of cards, and there's 9 stages overall with 2 mid-bosses and one big bad end boss.

The theme is pretty neat. I have a soft spot for the "devils are the good guys" plot. I ran a Pathfinder game that was more or less this, with a supremely powerful tyrannical oligarchy of angels as the bad guys. 

The game doesn't have a complex story, which might be a minus to some, but it's great when all you want to do is sit down and play some strategic battles with digital cards. It is what it is and I like that it doesn't try to be more. :) Each of the playable races has its own quirks and specialties, and being able to choose a secondary race makes for varied and interesting card synergies. I am a fan of the aquatic race that's very direct-damage oriented. :)

The difficulty is not so punishing it's un-fun. I've only won maybe 2-3 times at the time of this writing. I know people who have won much more. But I've made it a point to do the extra achievements every level so I can max my gold input, which does tend to get more dangerous the further your train goes through Hell's gates.

It's a solid game and I will keep it in my short list of non-narrative games I play to unwind!

amazing and satisfying deck builder

Like many similar games in this genre, it seems overly reliant on a snowball style of engine building.  So, a shade of bad luck early in any given fight can ruin a run with no hope to "catch up" to the synergy you need to be at by the time the trash waves end.  You'll know the fight is over because you didn't draw what you need to build the snowball in the first few turns, even though the fight won't actually be over for 10-15 more turns.

Overall, punishing for not drawing the specific parts of your deck you want in the first two draws of any particular encounter.

If you wanted to enjoy Slay the Spire, but couldn't because the games hates you and relic rng destroyed your perfectly good run, Monster Train is for you. It's a much easier/more chill version of STS (at least on the base difficulty) and adds it's own unique twist on the genre.

Don't know why it took me this long to write a positive review for Monster Train.

In short, it's really damn good. It's a similar vibe to Slay The Spire, and yet I enjoy every aspect of its gameplay more. It's a game that allows you to break itself if you find good enough card synergy and get a little lucky. I've found dozens of strategies that are so powerful I found myself giggling like an evil genius as I carried them out, secured a landslide victory, and tbagged the corpses of angels.

On top of that, there are 5 clans, which you can mix in 20 different ways. This gives every run a unique spin, since you're rarely playing the same angle.

[B]I watched a stream of this game and it looked pretty terrible[/b] [b][u]BUT[/b][/u] I bought it due to it being on sale and I am really glad I did.  The game itself plays like a tower defense card game where you are defending a crystal that is on the top floor of the train and place units on each floor that attack and get attacked each time you end turn -- surviving enemies move up a floor towards your crystal.  

[b]~If you are a fan of Roguelike games[/b] I suggest the game (especially if it is on sale -- 100% add it to the collection).
[b]~If you're a big fan of deck building games[/b] - chances are you will enjoy the game but I have often found myself skipping collecting new cards as a smaller deck just seems to work best (less than 30 cards).  There are 5 different tribes (6 with the dlc) that each has their own cards... and new cards unlock for each tribe as you level each of them up.  This adds enough variety into the game where each run feels different.  You build up your deck through the relics that you attach to each card themselves and not as much through the cards you pick.

I actually enjoy this better than Slay the Spire and such mainly because this has a lot more synergy involved.
You have to see this game as a hybrid of deckbuilder, turn based RPG, and tower defense.
The best thing about the game is that aside from a few specific starting cards, the card synergy is amazing. While trying to get more cards "Mastered" (finishing a game with them) I'm like "Well this one doesn't sound good..." and then by using it I learn when and what other card types it can synergize with.
I've found more hidden combos in this game than any other card game I've played. And on top of that I've had so many "This deck is NOT going to work out" and then it brings a victory. Or even a "This is a really stupid idea" that wins the game.
It's a Tower-Defense Deckbuilder game.

Almost 1 tapped him with just my juiced imp LOL.

I had some artifact that made spells free if they were below the cost of the played spell, so in combination with +draws, I was basically casting a full hand of buffs each turn to steroid the hell out of my imp.

Very cool combos/synergies so far, and the "four train floors" mechanic is actually pretty cool that adds another layer of strategy to how you wish to assign units.

The in-game tutorial was also both very quick and intuitive, and teaches you the basics while you play your first run. Awesome game!

This game saved my life.

I am 35.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This is a really fun deckbuilding roguelike at a nice price, I probably would recommend waiting until it is on sale.
If you enjoy Slay The Spire or Inscryption, this is in that same vein. It has a lot more variance than the aforementioned games but you can customize your deck a lot more.
You choose a primary clan and secondary clan, which function similar to a "class" system, and you can get cards from both classes during your run.
I really enjoy it, but the variance is a blessing and a curse. Each run feels very unique but sometimes it just doesn't go your way and the game hits you with a level you aren't prepared for.
There is a large emphasis on balancing big upgrades that also increase enemy difficulty, so you need to carefully decide if you need the power-level increase or keep the enemies weaker.

If you enjoy Roguelike deckbuilders, I highly recommend this one.

This is a mixture of a tower defense game and a card battling game with rogue-like elements, challenging combats, and creative mechanics that you have to exploit to their fullest extent so you manage to defeat otherwise insurmountable odds. If you don't find a broken combo to exploit, chances are that you're done.

Personally, I'm not much into tower defense games. This game had overwhelmingly positive reviews and it seemed like a card battler, so I bought it on sale. It was not until later that I realized it was not a kind of game that I liked, and that instead of using combos with your cards, you use your cards to lay towers to defend yourself with and support them, while your opponent plays a completely different game.

The game is good; that is undeniable. It has variability, it leans hard of trying to make itself fun to replay over and over, and you can tweak it from pretty easy to punishingly hard; it always tries to make you play it in a slightly harder mode, dangling unlocks and golden fonts for you so you'd want to.  I don't have a problem on how well it is made, how polished the mechanics are, how nice the graphics are, or nothing like that.

I simply didn't like it as a personal preference. I don't like tower defense as a concept in general, and I mistakenly bought one without realizing it. I even got the DLC before checking that it was something that I would most likely not enjoy, even after seeing a short video, not realizing what I was in for. Still a good game, can't stress that enough.

A deckbuilder which doesn't really allow you enough time or resource nodes to really "build" your deck.

(no it doesn't require it to win, but it makes the second hero purely luck based and kind of pointless if you don't get the purple rarity monster early)

Another game where you are just going to hit "restart" over and over until you get a good setup. BTW, each champion basically has one build route to go, there is almost zero player choice in the game, and even if there are maybe two or so build routes you can go, again, the game doesn't give you enough player freedom to actually manipulate your deck.

Update: after nearly 1800 hours of this game I just can't stop playing it. This is a fun, addictive game that always seems to surprise me.

Original review: I have only stuck to the standard, single player games, with the exception of the occasional multi-player speed runs. I have to say this game is very fun, addictive, and well done in every aspect. If you are a fan of these type of turn based, roguelike climbers, then you will love this one. It seemed like an odd concept at first, playing the minions of Hell fighting against the forces of good, but I quickly became enamored with my little minions and all their oddities. And the more I level each of the factions, the more interesting the game becomes by unlocking new abilities and minions. This is a must try for anyone who likes these types of games, and even for anyone who has never tried this type of game.

Doing a review way earlier than I usually do, but this game is super fun! I'd put myself in the more casual camp of Slay the Spire (StS) players, so I was really surprised that I beat the final boss on just my 2nd run. I don't think I had one of those "broken" builds, but maybe I accidentally stumbled into one without realizing it. Monster Train feels more "streamlined" compared to StS. I'm sure the game gets more difficult as you go, and there are optional ways to increase the difficulty, but if you found yourself getting frustrated with StS but want something like it, pick this one up. And while it's 75% through November 29, it's a no-brainer - get this game!

My primary gripe at this very early point: The enemy noises on attack/hit are a little harsh and don't have a lot of variety, so it's kind of an unpleasant cacophony if there's lots of enemies you're tearing through, or fighting a boss that you slowly whittle down. It's just *SKWAK*SKREE*SKWAK*SKREE*SKWAK*SKREE*SKWAK*SKREE* until the boss is dead.

Replayability is a key part of any roguelike/roguelite, and I don't anticipate that being an issue - it seems you're incentivized to try and beat a run with all the possible combos of clans. The music is rad, art is great, and I appreciate that you can speed up the animations once you end your turn. I'm looking forward to seeing more of the cards, too - I can tell there's going to be tons of fun combos to discover.

This is exactly what a good deck builder should be. It's fun, it's repeatable. And the gameplay is varied to the point of always being a surprise. You aren't going to get the same cards each game, and most of the gameplay styles are fun. I applaud this work, and bought it again today. 

I don't like the DLC, but I do want to give the makers more money.

I wanted to like it but there's just something missing.  Like most card battlers, synergies are key and the different factions are nice.  But there are only so many times I can run through without getting bored.  

It's a great game for casual players and I am relatively casual in my gaming.  It's pretty easy to get into the concept and what you start off with kind of sucks.  But that's the point of a roguelike.  As you go through you get more powerful and understand the synergies and strategies for different bosses become apparent.  It's quite short to make one run through... and maybe that's what bothers me.  

I don't really see a point in unlocking all the cards, all the covenants, all the things.  It's not new and fun anymore.  I mean, I get it, the covenants give you different "penalties" or things to potentially change your strategy, but you never really have to sweat it too much.  Maybe I just don't like going through the same 9 levels over and over again with no variety.  

I know I'm in the minority, but I just don't find the game fun anymore.  But I thought Slay the Spire was boring too so maybe I don't like card battlers.  Actually, maybe just roguelike card battlers.  I loved Epic of Gilgamech, and Griftlands but they're not really roguelikes (especially not Gilgamech).  Across the Obelisk is, though and I'm finding it way more fun and challenging than this or STS.  meh... whatever... I just didn't find the game fun after the first 15 or so hours

The game - and this is probably why it is rated this high - is fun in the beginning, when you have stuff to explore and learn the ropes. After a few quick runs (and they are very quick!) a certain same-y-ness starts to sneak in.
There is little progression, little diversion, the game plays mostly the same, deck build almost entirely dependent on who you chose as your champion aka from the start on, because that's how the game works. There's little depth in all of this. The game itself is very easy in itself and (of course) gets progressively harder the more you turn up the extra difficulty (covenants), something which I've always hated - but that is just me.

It's a fine 6/10 for me, but after a few hours the fun curve significantly drops, and this game has neither depth nor content to really even tempt me to grind. I'd rather just start another slay the spire run.

Slay the Spire spawned a lot of bad games in an exciting new genre, but Monster Train is not one of them. The format is incredibly unique within the "deck-builder roguelite" space and everything about the presentation is fantastic.

Maybe there are some balance issues -- the RNG element does allow you to have a run that's impossible to win -- but that comes late enough that I find myself wanting just one more run. For hours.

First impression is that it gets to the fun parts of broken combos faster than Spire. And takes about half the time. Those two things are a big upside over Spire, and I've got 500 hours on Spire. My biggest complaint is the same one I have for Spire, or even Hades for that matter. You unlock increased difficult so incredibly slow. Each tick up in difficulty is almost imperceptible from the last. It will be like, now win a run and the monsters will have 2 extra health. But when you beat that run, the monsters will have 2.5 extra health. Can you just give me like 3 to 5 difficulties? I hope Monster train at full difficulty is challenging, but it will take me a million years to get there with how often I'll probably play the game. 7.5/10.

One of the best roguelike deckbuilders on steam!
What this game does especially well is the postgame content. Clearing the highest difficulty level unlocks a ton of additional challenges that in turn can unlock special card frames. Collecting all divinity stamps, card frames and crowns in the logbook offers a lot of replayability for completionists.
The DLC is very polished and adds fun new mechanics to the game (infusions, hoards) that further increase the variability of each run.

Monster Train is an interesting blend of parts of different genres in a very fun roguelite package. It is part deckbuilder, part tower defense, and part autobattler in various amounts. You play units onto a three-tiered train to hell which take turns attack enemies that enter from the bottom and try to destroy your pyre at the top. It is somewhat like Magic in the sense that you have permanent monsters and can use spells which are discarded when played. This style of gameplay gives the game a very unique feel and interesting play patterns I'm confident you won't get from other roguelite deckbuilders out there. You can't review a roguelite deckbuilder without mentioning Slay the Spire, so I won't try to avoid it. This game isn't balanced as well as StS, but it is very competent. Playing at very high challenge levels in the DLC makes some options in the game obsolete as they simply don't stack again the enemy scaling (Slay has this problem, just to a lesser degree) but if you are playing at that high of a difficulty, you won't have trouble spotting novel card choices/builds. I think the overall difficulty is less than StS as well, but the game features a covenant system similar to ascensions in StS and has additional challenge options and a new form of optional enemy scaling in the DLC (which is not necessary to get tens upon tens of hours out of the game). Overall, I think that Monster train is slightly easier game to get into without sacrificing the room to grow and improve that makes this genre so addicting. the TFT, Battlegrounds, or other autobattler inclined of you will enjoy the challenge of solving unit scaling which is a large part of what makes the gameplay feel so unique. Monster Train is one of the most fun and "go again-able" roguelite deckbuilders I have ever played, second only to the granddaddy of the genre itself.
P.S. I Have dozens of additional hours of this game on GamePass.

Highly recommendable! Solid, mechanics-driven rogue-like deckbuilder. Think Slay the Spire, but with a bit more emphasis on game-y mechanics: i.e. less variance, more power fantasy livin'.
1000 hours...

Choose between an interesting selection of monster clans (along with an allied clan), fight your way through eight increasingly difficult battles and reignite the fires of hell. Create the most broken unit and spell combinations, unlocking new cards and clans with each run.

With each victory the overall difficulty increases further with a selectable 'covenant' level, to a maximum of 25. With daily challenges and customised games using mutators, there's endless replayability.

The DLC adds a new clan, more complexity in deck building along the way and an optional ninth final boss battle.

The main downside is this game is so addictive.
It works just fine on the SteamDeck (proton 7.04, just press buttons on the black screen) and its a great deckbuilding game in the same vein as Slay thevSpire.

As of now, I find this game more fun <gasp> than Slay the Spire.  MT has a lot of depth, and the art style is more my taste that StS, which I personally find a bit bland.  If the devs stay active and continue to make adjustments/additions to the game, they will have a huge hit on their hands.

The multiplayer Hell Rush mode is also very fun and really underrated I think.

UPDATE:  I have now played 125 hours.  It's still really good, and the devs are keeping it fresh with updates.  I still like it better than StS.

UPDATE 2 (400 hours of playtime):  What an awesome game.

Overall, the game is fun, but this game... feels... too easy. It's like impossible to lose a run even when cranking up the difficulty. It's fun to mess around with combinations and try different strategies, but overall the game itself just feels too easy. 

There are so many safety nets to make almost anything work, which is great. But it feels like there is no challenge to the overall game loop until you really crank up the difficulty to something insane, and then you're just not sure what to do.

After playing this game for a lot more time, my impressions have shifted. 

I think the core issue is the same: the exponential ramp in enemy health means you're required to create a single super unit with a very particular strategy to win‚Äì especially at higher levels. The infrastructure with three floors and all these possible cards is pretty pointless. 

BUT, what this game excels at is variety. There are five base racials, ten heroes, and each hero has 3 build paths. Functionally, there are thirty different strategies give or take you can try out. In any given run, 50-90% of the cards are useless, but the specific cards you're using do change.

There's still a problem with about a quarter of the deck. When you need to deal 4k damage to the final boss, quite a few of the possibilities are simply useless and laughable. They literally serve no process outside of some early game fodder.

Overall, it's a unique defense based gameplay, a fun astethic, and the potential to have some fun and engaging gameplay, even if its often time a bit too luck based, praying that the right builds that you're commited to appear.

In a sea of games following the success of the deckbuilder roguelike genre, this game really makes the effort to stand above everything else and I'll go in detail of many mechanics and why they are so much more refined than what you'd expect from similar games. As a fan of the genre, I hope you'll appreciate the genius decisions made in this game as I do.

There are 6 different playable clans (1 from DLC) in the game and they are basically classes with their own themes and keyword mechanics, but there's a twist here already: you always play a combination of 2 clans, and each of them has 2 variations which add a few different cards to your base deck. One of the clans you choose will be your primary clan and with that comes an upgradable champion. Each champion is [b]completely unique[/b], including its upgrades, even when comparing the champions from the variations of the same clan.

Before a run even starts, you'll get a few more random cards added to your deck from the two clans you picked, complementing the clan cards from the variations you chose and the base minions that you always start with. Along with the starting upgrade you choose for your champion, you'll also get a free artifact and will be offered another reward but this one costs pact shards, a DLC mechanic that increases difficulty based on how many of these kind of rewards you take. So right off the bat you can already imagine the huge amount of possible combinations even before the first battle begins.

The amount of combinations is [b]really[/b] meaningful, making runs feel extremely different from one another, and of course it will only get more diverse as a run goes on. This game manages to actually translate the combinations into variety in gameplay, and there are two big factors that contribute to it: How the RNG is done, giving a lot of control to the player and the balanced viability of all game mechanics (and there are a lot of them).

Almost all cases of RNG will have the player pick from options, and even if you don't want any of the presented options, you'll still be compensated with gold, so even when you're unlucky you're still getting something back and this include events found on the map in between battles, which are mostly straight benefits and the ones that aren't that are challenges that reward you later for enduring them. But what's more special than using RNG well is choosing not to use it at times where normally it would be, and with great success, as variety is done through other means.

A form of control that tilts the RNG in a smart player's favor are the different upgrade systems. I've talked about the champion, but you can also upgrade cards (both minions and spells) and even your train after the mini bosses. The cards have two upgrade slots by default which can be filled by upgrades as simple as numeric changes and as complex as adding keyword mechanics, and you always choose where they go and how you stack them. There's even a brilliant purge mechanic that makes your card really strong the next time it is played and then remove it from the deck. The train upgrades can help accommodate different strategies by increasing the minion capacity on each floor, the amount of ember (your main resource to play cards) or the number of cards drawn each turn and there is much more depth to this than it seems.
 
I haven't mentioned yet how the battle is divided in 3 floors inside your train, and the enemies will start from the bottom and go their way up until they reach the 4th floor, where there's just your pyre to defend you, and if it's destroyed you lose. This 3-floor train layout allows for multiple layers of strategy for every deck and this goes really well with the preview feature that shows your enemies before every battle and even the mini bosses and last boss special ability right at the start of the run, so you can plan around that instead of being robbed of a win by being hard countered when you get to one of these encounters. You even have the option to give yourself a tougher challenge for great rewards during the preview screen every couple of battles.

In between battles, you'll interact with the world map by picking a path from two available options. Each path has 2-3 overworld entities (events) to interact with. Aside from merchants, none of them cost you any resources, making so that refining your deck is much easier to accomplish. One last important aspect of the world map is that there will always be 2 options and they always lead to the same next level. This map will generate really tough decisions because the options available in each path are all really valuable, but you must prioritize the essential ones for your strategy. To help even more with the planning you can see the entirety of the map from the get go, even before the first combat.

After playing with it, I can't help but compare Monster Train's world map to Slay the Spire's, which if I'm not wrong was the first world map with the branching paths but no real depth that was inspiration to many different games and most of these inspired implementations didn't change it at all as if it was an amazing mechanic. Don't get me wrong, it works just fine in StS but here there is a lot more thought that goes into every choice and the flexibility is much greater, allowing for multiple ways to strategize both short and long term. There's also the elegance of simplicity in two distinct paths but with much more depth instead of a tangle of branching paths that are either exactly the same or very close to each other like in these other games.

It's time to mention difficulty and how well it's implemented. The DLC is amazing regarding this, introducing the pact shards and a new final boss, which are both optional. Following that, there is the Covenant system, an option to increase the challenge unlocked after successfully completing a run. It has up to 25 cumulative ranks and each of them will increase the challenge by numeric values or interesting mechanics. But that's just the beginning, really. Having a fully unlocked 25th rank covenant means you can now add mutators to runs and do expert challenges. 

Mutators are modifiers to the run and they can be either beneficial or detrimental, changing the gameplay [b]drastically[/b]. The effects can alter starting options, grant buffs or debuffs to both allies and enemies, change the amount of resources gained, alter the way to modify your deck, add extra fun challenges only available in this mode and much more. The best thing is you can have up to 3 mutators turned on simultaneously. Building upon mutators, there are also expert challenges which are premade challenges consisting of specific combinations of mutators, which are extremely fun and they do a splendid job of highlighting how amazing mutators can be.

Last but not least, the multiplayer aspect of this game is done really well. You can build custom challenges and share with anyone, and they can be as restrictive as you want. You can also race your friends and compare wins using the leaderboards. There are also daily challenges and hell rush game modes so you can engage with a varied style right from the main menu. Speaking about the menu, the logbook is really complete and has an awesome collection of personal stats, along with your run history. And to top it all off it also has mod support.

I went into detail of a lot of mechanics not only for new players but also to highlight how much better this game can be at even the smallest things, and it all adds up. You can mix and match strategies every run into a unique and memorable one and the game never stops surprising me about how viable every different strategy can be, since it's not afraid of having a player become too powerful, which I love. I wholeheartedly think this is the best deckbuilding roguelike [b]by far[/b], as it builds spectacularly on concepts that worked really well and fixes many of the flaws that are present in similar games.

Monster Train does a great job on incentivising the player (me) on retrying with different variables, different items, different strategies.
Sometimes, it's tough, sometimes you're way too strong and you feel invincible.

I can't criticise it from a pro-player perspective, I know way too little about fairness on RNG. But for me, RNG is the main source of fun in this game.

Got the game expecting a long-term challenge, didn't quite get it. The covenant system suck the fun out instead of presenting a new challenge. It's a good pickup if you aren't going to tackle that part of the game, but otherwise there's not much replayability to have.

To elaborate:
You start with a number of basic card based on the clan you pick, a number of universal basic units, and a set of random cards that consist of one rare card and several copies of the same more common cards. A large number of the covenant levels simply add more cards to one or more of the aforementioned pools. Extra starting card from main clan, extra starting card from secondary clan, etc. You get the gist. The deck become more than half-fold larger when the base deck is already quite thick.

That all compounded into an increasingly bloated starter deck, where a bad RNG (which will happen sooner or later) will screw you over. Need a unit to be meat shield? Have a hand full of spells. Need spell to snipe an important enemy backline? Get a full hand of units. Sometimes the RNG screwup happens before you even enter your first battle when the random set of cards are total garbage. Not exactly a rare happenings either.

This wouldn't even be as bad if the combat style isn't so heavily snowball-based. Every turn, all surviving enemy units climb one (or more) levels of your train and a new wave enters the lowest floor. At best, a terrible hand will lead to an extra wave of unmolested enemies you'll need to deal with at the next turn. At worst, those unmolested enemies will murder your defenders which means next turn not only you'll have to deal with more enemies, you also have less defenders to deal with them.

This lead to the sheer necessity to prioritize card remove over all else. Beeline to card removal event and spend all your money on card remove, because a bad hand early at most lead to some damage to the core but a bad hand mid-late in a run might as well end it then and there. You'll have to do all that while also try to scrounge for a late-game victory condition, which already depends on what the RNG gives you, even though you're seeing less options due to the necessity of taking the deck-thinning path.

I'd take Slay the Spire over this any day. At least if I lose it's probably my fault somewhere instead of the RNG shitting on me over and over again.

Monster Train is a card game wherein cards are divided into clans and each clan has its own specialty. You choose a primary and secondary clan at the start allowing you to mix match different clans and see how they synchronize with each other. Each clan also has 2 different champion cards that you can choose between at the start which have their own skill set. These features allows players a variety of gameplay every run.

The game also has a covenant system which is similar to Slay the Spire's ascension levels wherein players can choose to play the game in a harder difficulty after they finished the difficulty level before it for a challenge.

Similar to Slay the Spire, Monster Train also has daily challenges that gives players different additional conditions in the game.

Bought at [b]-50%[/b] discount.


[h1] Graphics [/h1]

Very gorgeous graphics. Most animations are top notch.


[h1] Sounds [/h1]

The music fits the ambience, it's a lot of action and voice sound effects, so it fits the genre of fighting. There is enough variation to not get the player bored of listening.


[h1] Gameplay[/h1]

It's great for passing up time. You will have a game where difficulty between learning how to play the combination of cards/factions and how to master them rise up nicely and can brake if you feel it's going too fast for you. The challenge modes spice things up and you can unlock golden border of cards, which is nice because it's a purely cosmetic reward which doesn't impact on anything if you don't care.

Each run feels different if you try to experiment with different cards and heroes. Even if you go for the exact same strategy, it STILL can feel different due to a lot of random rewards / choices you have to do along the way. The mini bosses are varied too and the final boss behaves differently each time you run against him, so the same strategy might not work all the time.

It have a unique layer of customization/strategy which is the floor you put your units or cast your spells. It's better if you spend your last 'mana' kill that soon to be attacking minion which barely escaped your monsters or it's better to buff your units on the front?

There is also plenty of achievements and challenges to complete if one is interested on it. And even a few secrets.


[h1] Story [/h1]

Story is encouraging. You are responsible for maintaining alive the last piece of hell and to rekindle it. It also explains why you run a lot of monsters in your train and why they all team together despite being different races. There is a lot of lore to chug if you take your time to read the story of each card while not in combat.


[h1] Bugs / Troubleshooting [/h1]

My notebook is an Acer VX 15.  It ran smoothly to me, no stuttering, nothing. I didn't notice any bugs.


[h1] Final Verdict  [/h1]

9.0 / 10

A great rogue like which successfully maintains the variation and the action pumping, not getting you bored if you are willing to try different things.

Some cards DO feel underpowered compared to others. Like for example, card that just move your allies on the floors and heal for the cost of [2].

OBS: I didn't feel the need to buy the DLC as I believe it didn't really go well and is unnecessary.

Great mixture of deck builder and tower defense. A run lasts around 30-60 min, not too long for an evening, not too short to get absolutely overpowered with an equal measure of planning and luck.

Even with bad draws, most runs can be salvaged, but a lot of luck is needed on top of knowlegde and concentration for some of the harder achievements.

Cons:

-Not really PvP

-RNG mechanic can be unfair

Amazing card battle game with a unique twist: you play your cards on a train with 4 floors. Monsters always appear on the lowest floor, and ascend a floor when they survive your attacks. On the top floor there's a crystal that should be protected at all costs, so it's necessary that you beat all monsters before they reach that floor. This is done by playing cards, which spawn a creature on the floor of choice, or cast spells that can heal, apply buffs and debuffs etc. These mechanics work incredibly well, making Monster Train one of the most enjoying card battle games I've ever played.

The game contains 5 different decks, and you can combine two decks for each playthroughs. Each deck has a completely different playstyle, and also has two heroes to choose, who can be upgraded in several ways. To increase the replayability even more, you can switch to a higher covenant after beating the game, which adds extra challenges to your run. I have beaten the game with each faction for the first five covenants, but I'm sure I will do many more runs in the next few months. Oh and the game works great on the Steam Deck; just press a button when you see a black screen and change the video player in the settings screen. Next time you boot the game everything will work fine. 

Very, very recommended!

After going through half a dozen variations of roguelike deckbuilders, Monster Train is easily my favorite. The core mechanics -- unique deck archetypes, card drafting and artifact selection -- are all present, but to me the actual implementation feels simultaneously less restrictive and more consistent than other games in the genre.

Monster train does really well with providing player agency through multiple upgrade slots and always providing clear options in events. This often means that there are several viable paths to victory. And it definitely opens the door to building ridiculous combos than the more buttoned-up competitors.

Inevitably, this game gets compared to Slay the Spire. Both are great games. But StS is a tighter game that requires optimal decision-making at high ascensions (and luck helps). High-covenant Monster Train has many more viable deck builds than high-ascension StS, which increases the replayability and fun. I still frequently play Monster Train after beating its hardest difficulty;  I can't say the same of Slay the Spire.

Just Epic. You will combine two sets of decks (from which the battle rewards will be randomized from) and then have a GREAT time experimenting with builds and tactics. Each deck plays and synergize VERY differently. 

Unfortunately, as you progress in difficulty, you'll quickly notice that there's just a few combos that really works, and if you aren't lucky in your first few draws to get what you need for these few builds you need to just abandon your run.

Still, I'd very much recommend this.

To me this feels like a mix between a card battler and a tower defence almost, you place your minions in one of three levels on a train with the objective to stop the enemy reaching your core/heart. It's extremely addictive and great fun as you choose a main and sub-class for each run. The classes are distinct and unique enough to provide a lasting enjoyable experience as choosing a different sub or main class will substantially change your strategy. Runs are also the right length with it averaging 30-40 minutes for me with solid progression once you win/lose. These devs really understand what makes a roguelike good, short runs that are different each run and meaningful progression. Really recommend this one!

Coming from Slay the Spire, this card-based roguelite is well-polished, fun, and addicting.  The additional DLC definitely impacts the balancing of the game somewhat, but the creativity in trying out combinations of monster cards together allows for more compelling gameplay.

This game is way better than StS with MUCH DEEPER combat system and much more combinations or variations. After playing StS for about 40 hours, I'm done with it, but I feel I can continue playing Monster Train for at least 300 hours.

When you lose a run in StS, most of the time it's RNG's fault, you know there is no way you can win with such poor cards. But in Monster Train, you can come out with many different strategies with the same deck, using a creative idea to win a run which looks unable to win always makes me feel so good.

It's sad that only 16% players finished covenant level 15 (max 25), people don't wanna think too much nowadays, maybe that's why more people prefer StS which is much simpler than MT.

Verdict: 10/10

While enjoyable at times, victory is entirely too RNG reliant even for this genre, and it ultimately sours the experience. Losing early on and unlocking new tools is a staple of the genre, but there are so many ways even a well-made deck and unit setup can get royally screwed by sheer dumb luck in this. Even after maxing card clans and unlocking their relevant cards and relics, I always feel i'm fighting Lady Luck over any in-game enemy or boss, regardless of strategy employed. Avoid Monster Train if you prefer your own skill to be the determining factor in whether or not a run is successful. If you're just looking for another deckbuilding rogue-lite game to scratch that itch, I'd look at something cheaper before investing in this. It's not a bad game, per se...just VERY poorly balanced.

A pretty simple monster battling game where you place units and they auto battle every turn on 3 floors. There's a lot of depth to the game and quite a few viable strategies from frost bite stacking, multi attack stacking, meat sticks, thorn stacking, etc. I will say to avoid spell focused decks because during the boss phase you only get one draw per flow making spell decks EXTREMELY weak, at least spell decks that focus on raw damage instead of those that focus on frostbite and the like. Overall it's a pretty good game with a lot of things that mix it up. You can upgrade units and spells as you progress down runs as well and use harder modifiers as you progress as well for more of a challenge. Other than raw spell damage the game feels relatively balanced but you can get screwed over by RNG a lot easier in this game than other games though. Keep your deck size small as much as you can to lower the level of RNG and cycle through your deck more.

Obviously a good game, this review is more for my reference than to inform your purchase.

As someone with over 200 hours in Slay the Spire, this game is aimed right at my demographic and can sit comfortably in my library alongside Ring of Pain, Dicey Dungeons, and Inscryption as secondary choices that I'll resort to when I get bored of StS.

It's not that I think MT is inferior to StS, it's just that  I've always been more a fan of combat in games being 70% standard enemies and 30% boss fights. I never got into boss rush games because the learning curve feels more jerky whereas having a bunch of smaller enemies in your game that teach the player individual mechanics that are then consolidated into a boss fight feels more natural and smooth to me.

If you like, take this as more of a review of boss rush games vs games with standard enemies, as I know that comes down entirely to preference. Some may enjoy the relatively streamlined approach of just tackling a boss fight over and over until you learn their patterns and weak spots. That said, I feel that kind of play works better in a game without random elements as my ability to win a run of MT seems to come down mostly to how early in the run I find the super tanky spiky plant man and the large gem that gives him an absurd amount of heath and attack. Randomness is obviously an integral part of deck builders but games like StS balance out that randomness by giving the player dozens of choices between boss fights and standard enemies that offer a chance to test your deck and fix your build as you go.

TL;DR: game good, play game. StS is better.

Monster Train is a deckbuilder game designed around a custom mechanic: we put monsters on the floors of a train. Train has 3 floors, and after each turn our monsters fight against enemies on the same floor. Then, enemies ascend, trying to reach a Pyre, which is mounted on the top of our wagon.

The base game contains five fractions, and in each run, we choose two of them - a main one and a support one. These fractions vary a lot - each one of them is based on another mechanic (even two mechanics, in fact), and these mechanics are really fun and original, different from what can be seen in other games. Thus, each run may be a totally new experience, when the player has to discover a way to win from the ground.

And this is a point that requires emphasizing: Monster Train is designed to discover. Not only it has many fractions, but it also rewards the player for discovering - the game contains a logbook that marks each fraction combination we have won with, and even each single card we have won with. And I had much from filling this logbook, the game strongly encourages players to do so, so they are not bored by playing the same optimal tactic again and again.

And here comes main disadvantage of Monster Train: although fractions and cards vary a lot, enemies are not that different. Yeah, some of them have some special traits, but most of them are not very surprising or don't make that big difference.  That's why choosing the best fractions and cards every time may become boring very quickly. Even though the game has 25 ascension levels, each of them making the run slightly harder. In other words, if you are 100% focused on playing the best tactic every time and you don't have fun from experimenting or taking suboptimal choices to fill the logbook, Monster Train may be not for you.

A small, but appreciated accent is that the game likes to give the player many statistics. After each run, it shows us some records we broke (and there are so many records that you will almost surely break some), and compares us to friends.

Summarizing, I had lots of fun from playing Monster Train and I really recommend this game. It brings some fresh ideas to deckbuilding genre, and it executes them very well. It's a great choice for anyone who likes deckbuilders and wants to try something new.

To start with I am not thinking that this game is bad as for what you get as a game. It is finished product, the quality you get for the price is quite good and there are deckbuilding rogue elements in place. the reason people are buying this game for.. 

So what are the issues for me. Again I understand that this game is on its own but as it was inspired and grown on popularity of Slay the Spire I would compare those two.
The main problem I got while playing it for couple of hours that success in this game is just relying on big numbers of your units. More tanky units you have in frontline and more multi-damage units you have in backline more luckily you would be winning every run and this makes game a bit boring. There is no place to make interesting random builds based on situation or luck for certain scenario, there is very little or none chance to experiment as it is not rewarding at all but too risky instead and tbh you stick with one or two meta strategies that bring you easy wins what is just not fun in general. I can explain the A+ rate of the game in steam because it was made for casuals that don't wanna do heavy calculations and be destroyed by every other basic bandit gang on start of the game if unlucky like it was in Slay the Spire or win bosses with 1 life left while having meta build and best card drop ever on your last toss.. and the same I can tell about other game called Super Auto Pets what has more similar gameplay with Monster Train in part of battles but it feels so damn different. You never feel those adrenaline spikes and feeling of been smart and lucky at the same time by your last second decision of taking risk, changing unit or doing retoss of your deck and getting reward the unit or card you was in desperate need.. so you never would feel this in Monster Train. When Monster Train is more like walk in the park and not going through a storm. And I guess some people like this stability and prediction and using same meta to have wins, I am just not one of them.

Monster Train is a card-game cocktail with a sniff of tower defense and a large dose of strategy, resulting in one heck of a smooth drink with a long and intriguing aftertaste.

The story is as simple as weird: Hell has frozen over and it is up to you to drive an Sbowpiercer-like train through the Nine Circles of Hell and deliver the spark that can rekindle the infernal fires. During this journey you will battle angels and priests that invade your train and try to reach the top of your train through 3 vertical levels and attack the heart. Should this 'Pyre' be destroyed, it's game over, so better prevent the heavenly hordes from doing this by summoning your own fiends and other monsters to battle them. So better start drawing those cards and flinging those spells because there is an netherworld to save.

'Choice' is one of the main keywords for this game, since a lot is offered to the player. Which clans shall I choose to play with, and then which or the unique gameplay mechanics of the chosen clan will I focus on in my run? What difficulty shall I choose, which starting artifacts and powers and which route should the train take to pickup new units and loot? The balance of all this so very well done: when you lose a run you can usually see where you made a strategic error; rarely did I had the feeling I was unjustly punished by the RNG gods. 

So all this, together with a cartoony art style, some uniquely weird lore and a decent soundtrack means this is one of the better games I had the joy of playing.

BE AWARE. Monster Train is sickeningly addictive. Out of the 10 or so games i bought during the summer sale, this is the only one I've been playing. You have been warned.

Monster Train takes the now booming roguelike genre, into the card game genre. Others have done this before, like Slay the Spire, but what i like most about this game is how incredibly simple it is, but has massive depth as you earn new cards and clans. Like most card games, it looks super confusing because you dont know whats going on, but even after my first fight, i got the mechanics immediately and everything else followed close behind. Its just a really solid game, the 3 floors add depth that rewards planning ahead, the runs are fairly short but promotes multiple playthroughs with different clans. The mutators and covenants add some twists and turns. My only complaint is the lack of bosses. The final boss (if you dont buy the DLC) is always the same, same goes for the others minibosses. 

The last thing i will touch on is the only current DLC, The last Divinity. I looked up reviews and basically most if not all say it breaks the game. The new clan is neat, but the new additions to standard runs make the game very unenjoyable, compared to the base game anyways. I've opted to not buy it until i get bored or want more, but looking at gameplay it seems to be a little crappy. On sale, 100% a buy if you like card games or roguelikes, avoid the tempting DLC for now even on sale. I hope they add new DLC in the future but right now stick to the base game.
This game is more fun than Slay the Spire, although it's not as deep and certainly more RNG dependent.

At its heart, Monster Train has a castle defense foundation that adds deck building. The deck building is decent. You essentially get to pick two colors (clans) which offer different play styles, but I feel like there are only a few key win condition cards surrounded by mostly junk. It's usually quite easy to remove all the junk and duplicate the win condition cards. Then there is the ability to modify cards sometimes causing insane damage output or tanking defense making some runs just overly easy, broken and unbalanced. Occasionally you will get a run where those win condition cards aren't offered, but that is the nature of RNG.

The castle defense aspect though feels weak and ultimately gets repetitious. Each encounter starts to feel the same and it just becomes a question of "Do I have enough damage or not?"
