Have you ever played a game where every single aspect of it was exactly the opposite of what appealed to you?

This is that game for me.

I see the positive reviews and I wish it appealed to me.  I see people raving about how much fun overpowered combos are, but for me that is the opposite of fun - either not drawing useful things and struggling or breezing through without a challenge.

Every little thing here somehow manages to rub me exactly the wrong way.  I hate the three lane mechanic and I hate that enemies will automatically go up lanes.  I hate the stacking multiple units in each lane rather than having just one per.  I hate how after the last turn the battle just autoplays until it finishes.  I hate that there is a turn limit at all.  I hate the focus on upgrading cards to absurd degrees rather than outplaying enemies with your hand.  I hate the focus on having a single win condition that is the same for every fight.  Everything I enjoy about lane based card games (units that attack/defend different lanes, cross lane synergies, more lanes) this game just does not have.

I even hate the presentation.  I don't like the semi-animated units.  I find the music and sound effects grating enough that I turn them off.  I feel like the UI is terrible and busy.  I even dislike the artstyle for the enemies, which to me comes off as weirdly generic for something so fantastical.  The entire game would appeal to me more with just removing all the presentation work they did and putting actual cards down.

I was hoping for another Slay the Spire but this is its own thing.  The few times I have played feel much more akin to just pulling a lever on a slot machine - far more so than usual for a card game.  What I enjoy about card games is when they become a puzzle.  I like trying to think my way out of situations with what I have available to me, but this game has so far not given me even a single turn where I felt like there was a real "choice" about what cards I should be playing.  If I need to grind runs to get to that point, I am just not willing to.

I am glad other people enjoy this but it is astounding to me how much every aspect of this rubbed me the wrong way.  I wonder if the players that love this also enjoy auto battlers, because this game honestly reminds me of them.  I hate auto battlers.

Honestly, some poor balancing. The game has a habit of generating unwinnable enemies. Like damage shields combo'd with haste. (Blocks first hit, then enemies jump to the top.) Sometimes this is part of the risk/reward patterning of taking certain boons for more difficulty, but it's sudden and not gradual. The game seems to generate enemies based on your deck, for example the Stygian is based on spellcasting, but the enemies will generate with spellshields in response.

I'll probably keep playing because it tickles part of the brain that likes making creatures that feel broken, but ultimately the game doesn't deliver enough, tends to be very unrewarding and has a lot of poor design patterns. It lacks the variety of options when you strip away the facade that enemies are "random". You boil each faction down to a couple strategies and there's not much else. Create large creatures that can sweep all the enemies at once. Each faction just does that different. The spells are too often blocked for that to be consistent.

i'd heard this game was good but dang it really is really good. iterates on some StS mechanics in smart ways while directly copying others. it plays a bit faster due to the autobattle - your turns tend to become simpler as your units go out, whereas the pace of StS battles is a bit steadier/more methodical - but the battle rush -> upgrades -> boss rush loop is a great drip.

the music & aesthetics don't totally do it for me personally but they're cleanly produced and competent. i like the character art design and lore (there's a lot if you seek it out). i would probably recommend starting with StS first because it's so damn good and incredibly balanced, and I think Monster Train moves logically forward from the roguelite deckbuilder prototype it created, but you pretty much can't go wrong with this game. also appreciate that the covenant/ascension system is less grindy than the former.

Ever since Slay the Spire landed to critical and public acclaim way back in 2017, the Deckbuilding Roguelikes have flocked to copy its formula and emulate its success. Naturally, all these pretenders have failed. Along comes Monster Train by Shiny Shoe and suddenly, everything changed. 


Whilst on the surface Monster Train could be mistaken for a slay-the-spire-like, that initial belief and dismissal would result in you missing out on the best Roguelike to come out all year, and the best Deck Building in the last four. Monster Train can be summed up almost entirely by its title ‚Äì you are in control of a train, and it has monsters. Narrative ‚Äúdepth‚Äù comes from where the train is going, and who is assailing your demonic locomotive. Spoiler, it‚Äôs Hell, and they are Angels. 

Little to no time is spent on the story in Monster Train, and as is the genre staple, it is simply a means to an end. A backdrop to give the game a bit of thematic flair. Angels, demons, monsters, sentient wax people, and trains ‚Äì it all makes for quite the setting, even if it‚Äôs all surface level. Thankfully, Monster Train is much more than its fancy setting and steam-powered chugging.

Gameplay in Monster Train has you doing, as a general rule, two things. You are either picking where you are going on the bilinear map screen and engaging in whatever your path chooses OR, you are engaged in battle with the forces of Heaven. That‚Äôs it, but that ‚ÄúIT‚Äù is very compelling.   

Overall, Monster Train is outstanding. The few issues I have with it are minor at best, and what the game delivers shines through with ease. This is not only the best Roguelike I‚Äôve played all year, but quite possibly the best game. Period. It‚Äôs taken four long years for the genre to move beyond Spire, and Monster Train manages to stand beside that titan and carve its own path to greatness.

It's decent, but not the 96% overwhelmingly good that the steam reviews are currently averaging at. The thumbs down is very much in this context. I won't expound on what's good with the game because there's a lot of it and other reviewers have done that well already. But the key things I didn't like are:

1) The repetitiveness of the runs make this quickly feel like a chore. There are 9 battles in a run, and it's always the same battles with the same enemies in the same order every run, with only minor variations of the bosses. This removes a lot of the feeling of exploration and mystery of other roguelites.

2) The colours, special effects, and sound is all over the top; a kaleidoscope for every sense simultaneously. It's like if Michael Bay directed an anime. Not only was that distracting and overwhelming, making it hard to actually figure out whats happening in a turn, it also quickly gave me a headache.

3) There's a lot of feature bloat. Every playable clan has a slew of new mechanics which comes with their own counter that keeps track of a one-use quantity that stacks up for every unit. This gives it some replayability, but at a huge cost to cohesion as very few of these mechanics affect each other. Strategy comes from having a few simple elements that interact in uncountably many ways. Monster Train is often the opposite; like 8 different card games randomly mashed together.

That said, it's one of these games I might come back to for a game now and then. It's worth a few hours of game play for those really into deck-building rogelites, but I'd recommend playing Slay The Spire, Inscryption, and Griftlands first as I found those significantly better games in that genre in every regard.

To date, I have played this game on Steam for just under 20 hours, but I have additionally played this on Switch for at least 300 hours. Both versions I'm still happily playing; I got the Switch version first (on day 1) and later on I knew I had to double-dip for the Steam version as well.

Both Monster Train and Slay the Spire stand out as two of my favourite roguelite/card battlers out there. But if I honestly had to choose which one's better, I guess Monster Train takes my pick. Slay the Spire set a gold standard for the genre of roguelite card battling as a whole, but to me, Monster Train takes what made Slay the Spire so successful and improves on them in more ways than one, also adding its unique twist to the proceedings (tower defence).

So what improvements? The main one to note is greater flexibility on deckbuilding; each battle victory rewards you with two card drafts (instead of one in StS), options to remove cards are cheaper and more frequent, and upgrading cards (both units and spells) are not limited to a specific upgrade path; so you could choose to upgrade a unit card with increased HP and Damage Shield, or perhaps Quick and Multistrike, whatever you choose is entirely down to you.
Granted what I just mentioned may regard this game as 'not challenging enough' or 'almost mindless' to some, however this point alone is what encourages to keep me coming back for more. I like having runs where I'm already planning out an exciting deck build from the get-go (especially with 5 random cards that are given to you if playing on (difficulty) Covenant 1 onwards), compared to say Slay the Spire (more often than not) that starts you with just your basic deck and nothing else, leaving me in limbo for some time and trying to plan a strategy from there. It's almost as if Monster Train hands you a canvas, paints and paintbrushes, instantly getting your creative juices flowing to paint a most depressed Seraph (?) you can come up with.

Other positives include its art style (might look strange at first, but it'll grow on you), its soundtrack, its lore (every single card and artifact has its own lore paragraph), and additional 'main characters' known as champions (10 in total, plus 2 exclusive to DLC), noting especially the MVP [spoiler]Little Fade[/spoiler], because why not.

Overall, this isn't a review to say that Slay the Spire is bad in any way (on Switch alone, I've spent at least 1,100 hours on it) and I still play that game often. However though, Monster Train for me stands out just that bit more in quite a number of ways for the reasons I've mentioned. I still love Slay the Spire which continues to set the gold standard to this day, but perhaps now Monster Train is my platinum standard?

Monster Train's 3 lane gimmick is a welcome inclusion to the pantheon of deck building adventure card games. It offers a tower defense mentality along with the random nature of scraping together a collection of synergistic cards. You select 2 different factions which provide variety in strategy and style of play. The way shops allow you to buy modifications for each monster or spell in your deck is a delight, and seeing your desired upgrade in a shop is a rush every time. I like the way the map works, because instead of choosing every single stop along the path, you're choosing packages of locations on one fork or the other. It makes you weigh exactly what you want against what you need in more categories at once. As you start to identify your play style, you can add optional challenges and compare your successes to your Friends List.

It's extremely addictive at first, with you racing to unlock all the factions and then all of their cards and relics. The game starts to struggle once you've played that far, as an awful lot of the cards feel too niche or the faction mechanics are overly specific and unreliable. When you start to realize what works best, it's often the more simple and trustworthy cards you'll gravitate to over and over to see further successes. (Especially when the "covenant" bonus challenges stack up against you.) It's also disappointing that the bosses are always the same each run, with only small mutators to twist exactly what precise strategy is ideal.

I prefer Slay the Spire's depth, Trials of Fire's variety, and Griftland's narrative. I still recommend Monster Train, however, because it still does plenty that feels different and I could see it appealing more than those games to the right person. I was completely addicted to it for a good 20 hours before I started to slow down, and that means it's a good game even if it isn't a new lifelong friend.

It plays great on Steam Deck. At the time of this review, the intro video doesn't load, but it's nonessential, and likely to be fixed in the future.

This is the only really great roguelike deckbuilder thing. 

There's a ton of variation both within each faction's cards/units and in the combinations of such, even more variation in the (well-balanced) events and artifacts which are thrown up along your run, and the card upgrades you're offered - and even more variation in the combat system, which is inherently much deeper than the typical slay the spire setup a lot of these games have. 

I'm highlighting opportunities for variation, because that's what will make it worth coming back for run after run after run. You have many chances to try different strategies, and you WILL get the chance to try them because you have much greater control over how the gameplan of each run develops. You're almost always presented with multiple choices whenever you get new cards/artifacts/upgrades, and unlike many other games your runs will essentially never depend on specific high-rarity enabler cards to come together. 

The design of most factions and their mechanics is cunning enough to have them be viable in different strategies for completely different reasons, which makes it feel more like you're actually discovering archetypes and putting them together yourself versus following one of a few preset lanes. Unlocking more cards and seeing more of the rare events and archetypes over time keeps things fresh, as do the various challenge modes. Even having gone out of my way to try all the options the game has to offer, I find myself still as engaged at the end as I was at the start, as I'm able to enable challenge run modifiers which make things harder in interesting, beatable ways.

All the small bits of polish here help as well - the lore and aesthetics of the game, while not front and centre, are actually quite compelling. The UI is very readable, and the thoroughness and completeness of tooltips means I never feel lied to about what's happening in combat. Even complex interactions resolve along logical and consistent lines, and the designers have been quite open minded in how cards and upgrades can be used, so you never feel like your cool ideas have been shut down. The logbook makes it easy to keep your progress through the game tracked for when you get to the completionist phase of play. 

I can't speak to the quality of the expansion, but the base game is a 10/10 for me and my only complaint is that other deckbuilders look worse by comparison. Please make more games like this.

Edit : After more hours of play time, I noticed the game is lacking a story and/or a campaign mode, and is getting very repetitive. I'm on level 11 out of 25 difficulty levels and getting a bit bored. 

This game is absolutely fun and very addictive in nature. Easy to understand and play, but hard to master depending on the clans you choose to play. I do recommend!

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
You carry with you the last flame of hell on a train. You need to protect it while the good guys want to take it from you and kill you and your monsters. It's a strategy deck building game with random elements and card drops so each run is different. A run typically takes about 30 minutes so it's easy to play and if you need to leave the game automatically saves your progress so you can continue where you were without much issues.

[H1]The good[/H1]
It's colourful, the level design is great and the music is cool. It's super addictive as there is so much to unlock and then new mechanics are introduced after you progress making the game a little bit more complex but still rewarding. There are different races and you can combine them to make your ultimate deck. 
If that is not enough there are daily challenges and you can compete with others or try a custom challenge. You can also make your own challenges by adding mutators to runs.
I also enjoyed that there are multiple events that usually give you a nice reward. There are even some secrets to be found.

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
It's super addictive :-) you will end up spending hours on perfecting your run. Then you discover multiplayer and daily competitions and you can't stop playing :-)
As you progress in the game it feels the solution to a run, narrows down to a few units or combinations. If you have an unlucky hand, you will lose and have to restart; at times this can be a little frustrating. On the other hand, you will learn strategies as to remove cards you don‚Äôt need and not to pick all the cards that are being offered. This ensures your more desirable cards show up more often.

[H1]Summary[/H1]
It's a great rogue-lite deck building game. You become more efficient as you discover what combinations work well. The music is great and adds a lot to the game. Graphics are OK. The game is optimized for small 30 minutes runs. Highly recommend if you want to play in short runs (although admittingly I played for hours just to find the right solution üòä).

If you in any way enjoy roguelike deck builders, well worth looking into.

Very good roguelite card battler. You are the train and your deck is spells and creatures you can play into it. Your deck is made of cards from several factions and you begin each run by choosing your main faction, which also decides the champion, and a supporting faction. To begin only two factions are available but the choice is still meaningful as they play differently based on which is the main faction.

The train has three levels before the engine and each level of the train can only hold so much and stronger creatures take more room. Between fights you get the chance to upgrade via a choice between two tracks which offer different (mutually exclusive) options. If enemy reaches your engine, they attack it and it attacks back but if your engine dies, run over. Time for another.

I absolutely recommend Monster Train to anyone that enjoys digital card games!

The main thing that sticks out to me is how much influence you as a player have on your experience.  Although it's a rogue-like, you can decide to have the game automatically up the difficulty for you each win, or you can stick with the rank 1 difficulty and have fun unlocking new cards all the same.  Player choice is a core philosophy of this game's design and it shows.

Each run is made of two clans and it's a joy to unlock new cards and experiment with mad scientist brews. There's a constant unlocking of new cards and clans which keeps it fresh. There is some RNG, but there are so many countless winnable strategies that the game is more about tailoring choices to your ongoing strategy rather than hoping you find an OP artifact.

Compared to Slay the Spire, Monster Train is more forgiving.  If you're looking for a challenge though, the game can be set to up the difficulty with each win.  The higher levels of Covenant difficult require absolute mastery of card knowledge and a little bit of luck.

Overall, I'd say Monster Train is a must-play for any card game fan.

Immediately bought this game + DLC when I saw the reviews how it was similar to Slay the Spire. Slay the spire is probably the best roguelike deck builder I've ever played, and one of the best card games I've played as well. I can honestly say that Monster Train is probably even slightly [b] better [/b] than Slay the Spire (at least in my opinion). 

[b]The best comparison I can give is that Slay the Spire is a card game with strategy, while Monster Train is a strategy game with cards. What I mean by this is that  cards are simply used to convey what you can and cannot do, but the ultimate deciding factor is still up to you. In Slay the Spire when you play a card, thats the end of it. But in Monster Train you get to decide which lane to play the card, which lane to place your monsters, the order to place them, and possible synergies between them, this in itself adds many layers of depth not present in Slay the Spire.[/b]

For me this game is just a slight notch above Slay the Spire and thats why it is in my opinion the best roguelike deckbuilder out there and a top 5 roguelike game for me,.

I enjoyed this so much that I purchased it on the Switch as well so I could take it on the go. The general consensus is that Slay the Spire is the gold standard, then Monster Train, then a steep drop before you get to the next game. Personally, I prefer Monster Train a little more. 
Five clan (or 6 with the DLC), each uniquely different. Each has 2 champions, 9 units, and numerous spells. Each champion has 3 skills, each can be upgraded to level 3. But you only get 3 skillpoints per run so you have to decide how to distribute those skills. Units and spells have 2 upgrade spots with numerous options. Each run consists of 1 main clan (with a hero) and 1 support clan (no hero). Once you have beaten the game, the cards that you used will get special borders. So now, I run the game on random and lean toward cards that haven't earn the border. This forces me to change strategy to accommodate those cards.
The runs aren't as long as StS but I think they offer more variety.

Slay the Spire kicked off the rogue-like card battling craze and did it really well; there  is a reason the game has been seen as the pinnacle of the genre it carved out for itself since it was released. 

Then along came a Monster Train and in my opinion, finally dethroned Slay the Spire as the king of this weird and addictive game type. 

For those not in the know, the game mechanics are as follows:

Each run you choose two factions. You are then put on your monster train where you need to fight multiple battles to reach the end. Each confrontation sees the player vying for control of the three floors on your train. On the left are where you will play monster cards to populate the floors and fight, and on the right the computer will be doing the same. The final, 4th level has the heart of your train and if its health reaches zero it's game over. 

Sounds simple right? Your monsters fight whatever enemy monsters have been played on the same level. Any surviving enemies after that battle move up a floor so you generally try to defeat them before they reach the trains heart. 

Now here's where it gets more complicated (and fun): You also have spells that can influence your monsters, the enemies, or the way the round plays out by altering some of the basic mechanics and defaults (such as increasing the max amount of space on a floor so you can stuff more monsters on it). Each faction is very different too and after some successful runs you'll start to unlock extra goodies for each faction such as more cards and artefacts (which have a global influence on your runs). 

Like Slay the Spire you can also upgrade your cards or alternatively, get rid of cards that aren't working for you. 

But here is the big biggy; because the game forces you to choose two factions for each run, unlike Slay the Spire you now have an entirely new angle to think about in this game: Combing certain deck types and focusing on certain types of cards within those decks to create unique strategies. Really, the list of what you can pull off is extensive to the point that you'll be returning to this game ever so often with a new idea in mind. 

When that gets boring you can up the difficulty of your runs for even more unique unlocks and rewards and then there is multiplayer where you can speed run against other opponents or just take it slow and see (point wise) how you did in comparison to others. 

There is workshop support but it isn't nearly as extensive as Slay the Spires which has an insane library of mods. I suspect the biggest reason is takes far more work to mode in these cards with all their unique animations than the rather simple look Slay the Spire went for. As far as I know there is only one workshop faction that has a good user rating, and not ironically, it's from a user who made a lot of stuff for Slay the Spire. 

Anyways, this game is crazy addictive and fun; I haven't touched the DLC yet as I am still working through the main games content, but if you check the reviews they do not seem very favourable.  The base game though? Fantastic stuff.

To be honest the first time I installed it I played like only 10 minutes (just the tutorial i think?) then uninstalled it.

BUT SUPER FUN!!!

The game can be fun, if you overlook these:
1. There are very few units in the game
2. Many clan combinations don't synergize at all, and the rest are weakly synergized. The second clan often feels like they exist just to add dead cards to your deck. It is a VERY bad system if you consider that there are 20 clan combinations but it feels like you're playing 5 clans alone with different dead cards sprinkled on top.
3. There are very few opportunities to add units to your deck - in fact you can just randomly not get the unit as a choice during the first few fights.
4. Even in individual clans, the archetypes are very disjointed and don't synergize well with themselves.
5. It doesn't feel very much like a deckbuilding game: few opportunities to tweak your deck, few cards, some determinism in the draw pattern, lack of mid range cards that help pad out the randomness, fixed number of turns you can draw cards before the boss fight.
Overall it's a 6/10. It's playable but it doesn't have any depth to it.

A very solid rogue-like deck builder with tons of different options for play style and game modes. I would say this game has more depth than Slay the Spire, and the variety is much more on the player side rather than the enemy side. The base game comes with 5 factions that each have 2 "champion" characters so basically like 10 heroes from StS. Each faction has its own unique gameplay mechanics that make it fresh, and they are all quite fun to learn and play. A few are SUPER OP but all can be made to work fairly easily.

The combat plays a bit more like a tower defense game with your 3-level train housing all of the battles, and you needing to stop enemies from reaching the top. This allows for countless different strategies depending on where you place your monsters, cast your spells etc. I didn't buy or play the expansion DLCs since I felt like it just wasn't needed, the game has plenty of content on its own. There's also Daily Challenges with random mutators and Custom Challenges made by the community. These have an interesting soft PvP element where you can see the position and score of others who are doing the same challenge at the same time, but it can be easily ignored if you're not interested.

Overall a great game that's worth full price if you love deck building games, but even if not I would still give it a go on sale.

If what you like about deckbuilders and card battlers is discovering and exploiting broken combos, then Monster Train is likely to please. The factions combine in a variety of interesting and unique ways, and there is a lot to be gained from mastering all the mechanics and knowing where to look for cards and upgrades that will truly break a deck. Monster Train is less likely to please you if prefer subtle long-term strategic depth or a more serious setting. At the end of the day though, it's a silly card game on a train, what more do you want?

Very similiar gameplay to 'Slay the Spire' but a lot more involved. Has the same 'combolicious' feel as STS but taken to another level. Monster Train has built on top of the already brilliant game that we all know STS is, and just makes it so much better in my opinion. If you haven't played Slay the Spire or any deck-builder style games I recommend you go play that game first, unless you don't mind the extra learning curve. 

2 main reasons I currently dont want to go back to STS currently:

 1: I love the blending of 2 factions to create your Monsters for each run. Every game feels incredibly different just based on the 2 different faction combinations you choose to play with. PLUS, each faction has 2 different champions and 2 different starter cards you need to choose from (So you will be choosing 1 of 4 champions/starter cards). All of this on top the variable nature of the game itself, and i've only played 4 of the 6 factions in the game after almost 50 hours of gameplay...

2: The other main reason I love this game over STS is the 3 added floors that you will be playing your units onto. After battling at the end of your turns, the enemy units will be moving up the floors of your train until it gets to your 'pyre' which is basically the life of your train. If the enemy units deplete all of your pyre's hit points you will lose. So its important that you plan carefully and the order in which you place your units in this game matters. It basically feels like you are playing an added puzzle on top of also trying to synergize the correct combination of cards to make it all work. I love this addition and is the main reason I want to keep playing this game.

Too long, or didn't read: Such an incredible and variable game. But also has a pretty steep learning curve especially if you haven't played Slay the Spire. If you are new to the genre go play that first, but I do enjoy this game much more.

well done

Monster Train gets so much right: It's very easy to learn but has a deceptive amount of challenge, has an incredibly clean visual style, & there's enough variety in how you can choose to approach the game that you could theoretically play it for dozens of hours without running out of new things to try.

However, it's also a game where you're likely to get (close) to the final boss on your very first run of the game, if not beat it straight up. MT relies heavily on NG+ & a player driven desire for variety rather than between-run power creep to keep you interested - And it worked! Well, until I got to NG+8 or so. At that point I was failing to gain any satisfaction from runs & stopped playing the game, despite enjoying it overall.

It's a weird one: I can definitely see some reasons why it's a better system than other rogue-likes where you're not expected to beat the game until you have a decent amount of between-run power gained, but it can also feel a bit anti-climatic climbing up the ranks until you reach a point of genuine challenge. 

I'd still absolutely recommend it, however! Personal tastes in regards to progress aside, the game is easy to learn, difficult to master, & has enough tinkering with cards to do to keep you going for a while.

Genius of a game. I think I can summarize my praise for it by saying I've done more runs than I can count, and every run felt like an exciting story to tell. Every run has felt unique in some way that I want to share with my friends -- whether because I got an early Minor Refraction and was able to duplicate up a miniature army of demons or showing off a battle where I got exactly the right draws to load up Primordium with every kind of buff. Every run so far has managed to felt interesting and different in some crucial way: The perfect artifact early in the run or the keystone unit for defeating Seraph acquired right before confronting him. There hasn't been a run yet where I haven't felt compelled to take a few screenshots to remind myself of my build and the final composition of my units before landing the killing blow on Seraph. 

On that note, the UI is also extremely good, with everything you need to understand the run (artifacts, pyre health, covenant rank, mutators, etc.) present at all times. It's really clever: it's both useful to the player to make all that information constantly available, but also makes screenshots/streaming extremely informative. Every picture tells a story. 

I think it says a lot that I change my primary faction after nearly every run, not content with trying to find a single reliable build. It's too fun to try out new faction combinations in the hopes of finding some new synergy. And this is before even getting into Daily Challenges, which I adore. It's a game that is just delightful to play and I cannot recommend it highly enough to anyone who might conceivably be interested in a roguelite deckbuilding tower defense game.
There are a lot of good rogue-lite deckbuilders on the market, but Monster Train is the absolute best.

Easily one of the best games I've ever played. Combining deck building, with a roguelike, with an auto-battler was genius. Monster Train is well designed, highly engaging, and SUPER FUN and addictive. There's few things wrong with the game, as they've even minimized the RNG in a really clever way. It never feels like you're getting cheated and every loss feels like you made a mistake that you could learn from. The game just keeps you coming back for more over and over again, especially once you get to deeper covenant ranks and get into the daily challenge, which is also tons of fun. There's just a lot of content here between the 6 clans, challenges, and the covenant, that it's well worth your money. Please buy.

Monster Train is generous deckbuilder in many ways. Generous with its multitude of playstyles, mechanics and ideas. It certainly has enough originality to set it apart from the tide of games that have entered the market following the success of Slay the Spire. 

It's also a generous spirit. You will win a greater proportion of your runs in Monster Train than you will in Slay the Spire, but you will also find more varied playstyles between runs and a fewer 'dud' runs where nothing comes together soon enough to get a good run going. That's not to say that Monster Train is an easy game. It may give you more ways to succeed and break the game, but it will demand that maximise these opportunities and test your ability to react to unexpected challenges on the rails.

If you like roguelike deckbuilders and have want a break from the punishing ascension runs of Slay the Spire, you can do a lot worse the Monster Train

All the components are there for a good game but it just never really clicks together for me.  Everything about the game feels insanely smoothed-over, crowd-friendly and engineered not to offend, from the wow-style graphics and bland dialogue to the mechanics themselves.  The length of the core gameplay loop is frustrating - too long to be popcornable, too short to really get invested in the deck you're building before it's all over.  And ultimately there is just a crunchiness and johnny-like combo satisfaction to other deck battler games once you get your deck humming that seems to be missing here.  In most runs you're going to get a couple of 'combo pieces' (aka op cards that are even more op together, nothing actually clever about it), then spend the rest of your gold upgrading those cards and burning the rest of your deck so you can draw and play your key pieces consistently every turn for the rest of the game.  Pretty dull.

Replayability also just boils down to grinding out covenant ranks endlessly.  I usually like iterating through a game experience with ratcheting difficulty, but something about the very small incremental difficulty bumps with covenant makes the whole thing feel like a repetitive slog for repetition's sake.

So I do think Monster Train is a good rogue-like card deck builder, very similar to Slay The Spire. However, I would put it just a bit below Slay the Spire. The reason for that is that this game is just slower (at least for me). Generally, especially if you're new to the genre, there's just a lot of reading carefully involved to learn all the card effects. Also, what you play, while important, doesn't seem to be as important as deciding what gets put into your deck and what you can take out.

So you may have already lost a battle before even starting it. So a decision you made much earlier to create synergy within your deck, may have a hard counter at one of the random fights up to the boss. I ran into several such fights and only learned from running into those buzzsaws to be ready for these hard counters. Unfortunately, this makes you min / max everything and not get very creative with your deck building.

The pacing is just slow as well. Sometimes you have a lot of cards in your hand to play and where you will place your cards on the train is very important and requires much thought. Especially at the higher convenant (after beating the boss you can go for higher challenges), it seems to be very RNG dependent. You will get more random cards and sometimes they just don't have any synergy. Also, some cards and some artifacts are just overpowered that they make those games much easier than your other ones. I had one artifact at the beginning that made all my Stewards (starting pawn cards) just overpowered and the whole game was a breeze from the start. And then I had another one where I got the artifact late in the game, where I had already gotten rid of all my Stewards.

I had more fun with Slay the Spire. The pacing was just a lot better. I also had a lot more fun with Inscryption and Ring of Pain. This is not a bad card game. In fact, I think it's good and a bit addicting (I think I'm going cold Turkey though). It's just not among the best of this genre IMHO. Obviously though, it's rated overwhelmingly positive by Steam reviewers so I imagine there is disagreement on that conclusion.

Rate 7/10.

Genuinely addicting.

You can theoretically "Beat" this game in as short as 3 hours. But the fun of a deck-building game like this is experimentation.

I spent countless hours in this game just paring different demons, spells, races, and countless other techs in the game together. You lose yourself in the multitude of options you have presented and find yourself having a unique experience because of it.

Some may focus on debuffs, others may focus on wrecking angels with pure damage focus build. The best feeling that this game conveys is that all options are valid. Sure, some builds/techniques definitely work much better than others, but the feeling of being screwed by your build feels next to non-existent.

The core game-loop is amazing if you're looking to lose yourself in building the best deck possible. this is the game for you. Especially at its low price point on sale. (I think I paid like 12 bucks, but the full price is more than worth how much content you receive in the game)

I must purchase and easy to recommend

[b]Slay the Spire Lite[/b]
is the most apt one-line summary for Monster Train.

Mind you, the game does more than just copy the 'default hallmark for card-based combat rougelikes', as it offers you more setup choices (5 + 1 DLC 'color', combining two colors per run to form a unique choice of possible card combinations), simplifies the 'travel along routes gathering gimmicks in between combat' concept to it's core, and then adds in a multi-layered combat revolving not around a single character, but an army of card-summoned minions.

In many ways, Monster Train succeeds in removing filler and condensing down the gameplay to it's core elements, whilst not becoming too simplistic. However, it also means that 30 minutes per completed run isn't a 'speedrun', but the slow norm. It's very much a 'do a quick run in a break/lull' kind of game.

The major gripe I can find with this, is that the game balance is not as ripe as that of Slay the Spire: Whereas in the latter, you are expected to fail several times till you learn how to build a good deck to then maybe beat the tough bosses with, in Monster Train you can essentially build any kind of deck that has a strong combo/synergy, and then just need to execute that combo in each of the up to 9 combats, and that's about it. And it [i]is[/i] remarkably easy to build [i]insanely[/i] powerful combos. Sure, you can scale up the difficulty on later runs, but I think that both the entry level and the scaling of the difficulty is just way too lax for the insane combos the game makes available.

Another, lesser, issue, is the enemy diversity. Sure, there's a couple few with fancy special effects... but none which force you to truly change your strategy or approach. It's always 'wave of mooks', sometimes with offense-focus, sometimes with a defensive one, sometimes they skip a floor or have effects that trigger on death. There's no striking, powerful mechanical oddifties that force you to rethink your approach, and even the main bosses don't quite get there.


Overall, the game is nonetheless well-made, has solid production value (I particularly love the fact every single card is animated), and is a great provider of brief sessions of casual deck-building fun.

If you like deck-building games, you probably want to give this a try, and twice so if you want to get into the genre, but always figured the games are too hard to figure out.

Overall Score: 7.5/10

Monster Train is an incredibly well made, fun and fairly consistently challenging deckbuilder roguelike. I thoroughly enjoy the encouragement to break the game, get away with stupid stuff by cloning it into oblivion or leaning extremely hard into scaling mechanics such as Gorge or Harvest.

When I first saw Monster Train I wasn't necessarily impressed by the graphic style or the "lane system" and immediatly ditched it without trying it. 
After a good dozen of hours I can say it was wrong of me to judge it without giving it a go. 
Think pretty much "Slay the Spire" but relatively more customizable decks, and the lane system actually makes sense and makes for intriguing but not overly-complex gameplay choices. 
Game is polished enough and has a bunch of content with leaderboards, different run modifiers, dailies and whatnot.
Give it a shot.

So far 152 hours into the game. Still want to play more.

Here are a few comparisons to elements in other rogue-lite games that I like:

vs Into the Breach: You have complete control over combat. The outcome of the combat is previewed. The UI is intuitive. 

vs FTL: Games are FAST yet do not lack depth. Maybe I am a slow learner; I still feel like there is a lot of learn. My high score is still around 60% of my friend's best high score.

vs Slay the Spire: No confusing paths where I sometimes I have squint my eyes really hard at the screen to make sure what I am going into. You always get 1 of 2 sets of "encounters". Some might dislike it being so systematic. But I enjoy the simplicity and still the decision often less trivial. (i.e. do i need rest/elites?)

Also you get "elite" encounter "on-demand". Before a round, you get to choose whether you want to upgrade the combat and gain additional rewards; or not.
It's a really really good game, but it's not Slay the Spire good. Still a great game though.
Complex roguelike

I wanted to try another deck builder after playing and really enjoying Inscryption. This one seemed to rate highly so I tried it out. I'm not very experienced with deck building games or rougelike games but I was pretty instantly hooked. I've been playing for about 12 hours now and I'm having so much fun. There are so many combinations to try out. Plus I love that one run is just 8 rounds. That feels like just the right amount to me and doesn't make it too frustrating for me when/if I die.
Wish I could put it down to do something else with my life (can't).

Really a great game. Personally I find it scratches an itch that Slay the Spire just doesn't quite match. The combos and synergies feel more organic and controllable, and my decisions more informed and understood, something I find lacking in other similar games.

If you like roguelite deckbuilders, you owe it to yourself to at least give Monster Train a try. I just hope it gets new DLC!

(The DLC is a great end-game content bonus, so it's painless to pick it up if you found yourself enjoying the base game.)

It's not as good as Slay The Spire, but it's different enough that it is still fun. The graphics get old pretty fast, and it is largely easier the StS, but still worth your time. I bought it at full price, wish I had waited for a sale. There are better options out there, but if you own them all already, this game scratches that deck building roguelite itch.

[h1]Final Verdict: Solid Rogue-like Deck Builder That Is a Great Deal on Sale For Only $10 USD![/h1]

So I do think Monster Train is a good rogue-like card deck builder, very similar to Slay The Spire. However, I would put it just a bit below Slay the Spire. The reason for that is that this game is just slower (at least for me). Generally, especially if you're new to the genre, there's just a lot of reading carefully involved to learn all the card effects. Also, what you play, while important, doesn't seem to be as important as deciding what gets put into your deck and what you can take out.

So you may have already lost a battle before even starting it. So a decision you made much earlier to create synergy within your deck, may have a hard counter at one of the random fights up to the boss. I ran into several such fights and only learned from running into those buzzsaws to be ready for these hard counters. Unfortunately, this makes you min / max everything and not get very creative with your deck building. 

The pacing is just slow as well. Sometimes you have a lot of cards in your hand to play and where you will place your cards on the train is very important and requires much thought. Especially at the higher convenant (after beating the boss you can go for higher challenges), it seems to be very RNG dependent. You will get more random cards and sometimes they just don't have any synergy. Also, some cards and some artifacts are just overpowered that they make those games much easier than your other ones. I had one artifact at the beginning that made all  my Stewards (starting pawn cards) just overpowered and the whole game was a breeze from the start. And then I had another one where I got the artifact late in the game, where I had already gotten rid of all my Stewards.

I had more fun with Slay the Spire. The pacing was just a lot better. I also had a lot more fun with Inscryption and Ring of Pain. This is not a bad card game. In fact, I think it's good and a bit addicting (I think I'm going cold Turkey though). It's just not among the best of this genre IMHO. Obviously though, it's rated overwhelmingly positive by Steam reviewers so I imagine there is disagreement on that conclusion.

[b]Rate 7/10. [/b]

If you like Slay the Spire, this is better. This is a deckbuilding game that is also pseudo-tower defense (in that  you place your units on various levels of a train and they fight units as they go up) with auto-battle elements added in. The game is great for two major reasons:

1) Customization. As you progress you get spells and units, then you can augment these units at the various shops, by default you can enhance cards twice, but it can be increased. You also get to pick two factions to only get cards from those two factions, so you could for example go Melting Remnants with Awoken, Melting Remnants focuses on reviving dead units and Awoken is very durable allowing you to have a strong tank while throwing units at enemies and reviving them even stronger.

2) Controlled RNG. There are so many elements in your control that losing a run is really on you 95% of the time - I say this losing plenty because I dink around with cards and make enemies stronger at the same time - But it's enjoyable to do so sometimes just to watch a unit hit 8 times and return to the top of your deck when it dies. 

This is the best deck-building game I have played and will recommend it to anyone that likes the genre. 

Also - Melting Remnant's Exile Champion is fun as all hell, that is all.

This one is just a slight "not recommend", but if you are really into the genre I'd pick it up on a deep sale as you'd probably like it.  I think it is as good or better than Slay the Spire, but not nearly as good as Tainted Grail.  My two major complaints that make it a Not Recommend:

1) You can't bypass Covenant ranks, so if you want to try to "beat" the game (eg. Covenant 25) you have to grind out 25 wins.  This is extremely tedious, especially taking into account if you want to have the best chance of winning its just sticking to mostly the same builds.  You should have the option to just select whatever Rank you want.

2) Bit too much RNG.  Seems about 1/3 of the runs I'll get lucky and it will be trivially easy (but still time consuming), another 1/3 are challenging and require some good decision making, and another 1/3 are basically unwinnable, all due to RNG.  The kicker is you can fairly reliably guage how well the run is going to go just based off the artifact, extra cards, and possibly champion options you get at the very beginning.  The "best" strategy is just to immediately quit and restart the run a few times until you get something really good.

It's a real solid game, a lot of fun for sure.

The different combinations of Clans (Team/Faction) and Champions (Hero unit) offer a vast variety of build possibilites.

However, the game has a major fundamental flaw, each battle ends with a boss entering the board/battle field. After which, the game is an autobattler, no more taking turns (Though you do get use cards if the boss wipes you and moves up a floor), your units trade blows with the boss until either side dies. 
So builds that rely on usings spells or other strategies, while certainly being "viable" are a lot more clunky to play.

There's even a final boss which permanently (for the battle, but it is the last battle) removes the first spell you use each turn from your deck, leading you to unavoidably running out of spells, and having to rely on your minions to hold their ground.
The new DLC final boss, is also a build blocker. It will clear any debuffs after every turn, so builds that rely on stacking damage over time, or other status debuffs will struggle a lot.

So in my experience, builds that rely on building huge strong units are ultimately a lot more strong and easy to win with. Building up an imprenatable tank with damage dealing units behind, is a massively favored strategy. It also the type of strategy I enjoy the most, so good on that, but still unfortunate.

But despite the "flaw", the game is great fun. If there ever is a Monster Train 2, I'd be lining up to play it.

If you are a fan of rogue lites and deckbuilders (e.g., Slay the Spire or Dominion) this game will most likely be fun for you. It nicely combines the deckbuilding aspect with strategic elements of unit positioning and synergies (similar to Darkest Dungeon, but on three levels). Your overall goal is to avoid that enemy units move to the top floor, where your pyre rests. Once its destroyed, you're dead.

The replayability is huge, since there are different clans (i.e., card decks). The clans play very differently due to different card mechanics. Furthermore, you not only select one clan but two for each run. This increases the combinations further. And there are ascencions, steadily increasing the difficulty after each successful run. The difficulty is pretty challenging once you reach a certain ascencion level. Similar to other deckbuilders, it's very satisfying to find a powerful deck, but it can be a bit tiresome to get there. But there is no heavy grinding, most card unlocks happen pretty quickly.

Overall, the game is worth the money if you are up for a rogue lite challenge.

This is a great game. It falls into the roguelite deckbuilder genre, and it is one of the best games in that. 

You start with some basic cards depending on your clan combination, your primary clan champion, and a set of randomised cards again from your clans. You go through a gauntlet of 7 rings, each with a fight, and 2 paths you can choose, each offering opportunities for upgrades. Standard concepts, like thinning your deck and focusing it apply too (you can remove cards a couple of different ways.) There are 2 types of cards, creatures and spells. Both feature 2 slots for upgrades (3 with the respective artifact). Each battle consists of enemy waves entering the bottom floor of your train, and each turn they attack your creatures on that floor, your creatures attack back, then surviving enemies move up a floor. You have 3 floors to kill them, if they make it to the fourth they damage your pyre, if your pyre reaches 0 health game over.

The basic concepts are simple enough, but there is a hell of a lot of nuance to everything here. The randomized seed of each run provides with unique sets of challenges and opportunities each run, as does the combination of all the clans each with 2 variants. At high levels (the game makes use of a progressive difficulty increase mechanic like slay the spire, but you can always play at lower levels than the max unlocked if you feel you need practice) the game is quite tough and requires good knowledge of mechanics and what your options each represent, but it is very rewarding and enjoyable, even if you lose. 
I rank this game on the same level as slay the spire, which set the golden standard for roguelite deckbuilders, which speaks volumes for the quality of this game. It is heaps of fun, and even though I am not very good at it, I just keep coming back for more, with the goal of scoring a divinity kill with each clan combination (final boss of the dlc) Speaking of the dlc, I consider it mandatory, it offers a lot to the game, and there is no reason not to jump in the game with the dlc active straight away other than budget constraints. The main reason for that is that many of the strategies and tactics that work pre dlc, do not work that well post dlc, so you would be learning wrong things if you spend a ton of time playing without the dlc. At least that was my personal experience, having played a lot before the dlc released, and I know it is shared with a lot of the members of the community. Speaking of which, if you like the game, or have questions about it, the discord is full of friendly and knowledgeable people that can help.

All in all, I highly recommend this game, and I'm very keen to see where the devs go for their next game!

Wow. I was and still am pleasantly surprised by this. I had seen it a few times in the store because I'm a big Rouge-like deck builder games, but really the videos and screen shots just put me off. Then, Monster Train was on sale for some 60-80% off, so I was like what the heck... Boy am I glad I did give this a try, and my only regret is that I had not played this earlier ! For one, I am not one to write any review as not many games have impressed me over the last few years. A few things about Monster Train 
1. The first thing that you will notice when you start playing is the MUSIC and Sound effects. Normally after a few hours of any solo game, I turn the music off, however with Monster Train, I actually look forward to hearing it !! Far out !! 10/10
2. As it is a "Train" game (which I thought was a horrible idea) turns out this into a Tower D esq Rogue-like DeckBuilder game. I thought that it would add an unnecessary element to RL-DB games however, the way the game flows it triples your RL-DB experience. 9/10
3. Graphics - as I said earlier I was put off by the video and screenshots on steam. But after playing the game, the detail and animations was definitely way cooler than I thought. A big plus is that you are playing the "evil" "villainous" bad@$$ monsters with monstrous abilities. Even though, probably the lowest aspect of this game would be the graphics. All the positives totally outweigh this negative. 6/10
4. Game Play - The sheer amount of upgrades and changes to your deck ALWAYS guarantees a different play through each and every time (unless you aim for a certain type of build, but even then, the outcome always comes out different). Not only this but the sheer amount of combinations that you can manipulate in order to "break the game" or basically have god-like combos is well, damn near infinite. For this, I'm curious when I will ever get bored of this game. Probably never... 10/10

In the end is this game worth it? Hell yeah. Is it worth full price? Definitely. Would you recommend it to a friend? Every time.
If you like Slay the Spire and other roguelikes, this game is for you. I enjoy this more than any other roguelike because there is more strategy and less RNG. Great buy!
combos are fun, nice game
good progressions and interesting variations. similar to slay the spire but offers enough differences to stand on its own

This is probably one of the most unique deck based rogue-likes I've ever played. The dynamic between each of the clans is really fun, with a unique playstyle that keeps them distinct from one another, and the sheer number of combinations of said factions make for a really engaging experience. There's a plethora of different cards and artifacts to unlock, making progress worthwhile, and every faction has two champions that can be unlocked through gameplay, allowing for runs with the same faction feel different. The music and visual style are all also incredible. 

That said, the strongest part of this game is definitely the deck-building. Bosses and enemies feel very samey as you do more runs, with only a couple variant end bosses per tier (though the different modifiers they can get spice things up). In addition, there is only Seraph as the final boss for the base game; without the last divinity DLC, runs can sometimes end up feeling anticlimactic, since Seraph is honestly pretty easy compared to some of the normal final enemies you can get thrown at you.

Overall, fantastic game worth playing if you love rogue-like deck builders.
This game is full of content, and only 5 hours in im having a blast.

I tend to pick summoning classes in RPGs whenever possible. And once this aspect happened to met deckbuilding roguelikes, a special star was born for me.

Unlike other such deckbuilders like Slay the Spire, Griftlands or Tainted Grail, Monster Train requires you to defend the life points of the pyre not with just your main character and perhaps some minor extra help, but with an entire arsenal of monsters, which are also all upgraded separately and serve different functions on the various floors of defence. Granted, there's one hero monster you have and which can be built a strategy around if the chosen clans and artifacts favour this approach. However, Monster Train goes extreme in other directions too, from full-on spell support, extremely hardy defensive monster, floor manipulation, to really ramping up numbers in order to overcome the hellish life pools of the higher difficulty adversaries.    
Having cards of two different clans each run always offers a unique challenge to make a deck work, and while I admit that the RNG factor of getting good artifacts might be one bit too high, the feeling of success when you win against all odds becomes even better therefore. 
By the way, the Last Divinity DLC is an excellent addition!

Monster Train stands apart from other deckbuilders by making every decision exciting and bombastic. Where Slay the Spire decisions often give the player small and incremental benefits, Monster Train encourages you to break the game with absurd multipliers and combinations that feel fantastic to pull off. Monster Train focuses on minion combat rather than a main protagonist, which means that you build little connections with each card and you'll find yourself getting excited to find an Overgorger or a specific power-up (StS has this as well, but I think it shines through a bit brighter in Monster Train). The custom soundtrack has gone way under the radar and should really be appreciated more -- I think it's pretty neat.

In my opinion, this game can be enjoyed by two types of gamers:

For someone who is new to deck games or didn't like Slay the Spire:
If you aren't familiar with deckbuilders, this game has enough beginner elements that it's a good jumping-off point into the genre, and it isn't reliant on a ton of experience to get a few wins. If you didn't like Slay the Spire, Monster Train is a bit less math-y at the lower difficulties and the minion elements and sound effects give the game a lot more character. I recommend the base game to anyone who wants to try someone new, but I would save the DLC until you're beating the higher difficulties consistently. You can buy the DLC, switch it off within the main menu, and then save it for when you've gotten the hang of the game.

For the hardcore deck builder:
This game belongs in contention with StS for the best deckbuilder created as of 2021. The control that MT gives the player over your deck in each run, combined with the build-diversity and variety of random events make it infinitely replayable ang every run is winnable. The difficulty curve within a run and as you move up the difficulty tiers feels great, with enough random events and rotating bosses to break up "meta" builds from carrying each run. The Last Divinity DLC is another level of complex, for better or worse, but overall it accomplishes the goal of keeping MT fresh and adds an absolutely massive amount of new content and mechanics. There are daily challenges (using positive and negative modifiers) and the ability to create and share your own if that's your thing.

Overall, I'd say that if you're a fan of the genre then you already know whether you like this game or not. But if you're on the fence, I think Monster Train is an excellent introduction to the genre.

Monster Train is a roguelike, Slay The Spire like, PvE card game with slightly bland art, solid music, and tight game design.

You play by deploying monsters onto one of three floors of a train, enemies trickle in the front door, and then your monsters on each floor autobattle them before they can get to the core.

It's a simple foundation, but the game builds expertly on top of it. Gameplay feels fluid, cards are relatively simple, and everything is well explained.

In fact, if you struggled with Slay The Spire, you'll probably cruise through this. Monster Train makes its difficulty optional, and unlockable. You can slowly up the difficulty to make your runs harder, but all that does is unlock the option to make the difficulty even harder. Finishing your first run isn't momentous in Monster Train. It's a game you play because you enjoy playing it, not because you're trying to beat it.

I think some people may be turned off by that---myself among them. I play things partially for the feeling of completion, and Monster Train still has that in the form of new factions and new cards to unlock, but the story is thin and getting a game clear is not a struggle.

I still had a blast with what I've played, and I expect I'll play more before I'm done, but I also anticipate I'll burn out quicker than I did with Slay The Spire.

If you enjoy TCGs, I'd absolutely recommend checking this out. If you mostly just enjoy roguelikes, this might not be quite your cup of tea. And if you like games that are simply fun to fiddle with, explore, and master, this is probably going to be a perfect fit.

this game ,while having similar basic mechanics feels very different from slay the spire:
for starters you pick a race,champion and a secondary race and champion 
all of which give you different starting cards,
therefore it has about 16 different starting deck options(you could say 64 too) 
and from a certain covenant(ascension)  it gives you 5 random cards
which means every run starts differently.
every race gives different units and spells which offer you unique strategies
you use to defend your pyre from various angels.
the game is split to two parts one where you defend the train and one where 
you prepare from the next fight both offer many fun and interesting choices to make.
you can even make fights harder for extra gold which let's you upgrade your cards and buy items
during the preparation
all of which leads to a fun gameplay full of variance.
now the music is decent the game controls mostly fine but sometimes
when using spells on opponents i accidentally cast on a different floor
not sure if it's only me, what i think many would agree about is the problem with the visuals
and creature design many creature of the same race look a bit too similar which led me to have
problems identifying some creatures and angels until many hours later and even to 100 hours 
later two angel bosses are almost identical to me.
the game also looks too much like a phone game(a mobile version would be great btw)
in my opinion. not necessarily ugly but requires getting used to.
the covenant system works well and has a solid difficulty curve,i did use the fact you can reset combat
not using the reset might lead to greater frustration but using it might feel cheap.
early covenants might be too easy for more skilled players.
in the end the game is great for card game and strategy fans 
with the visuals as the only small downside

Probably the best deckbuilder I've ever played. Game starts out easy and lets you get the hang of the various race combos and mechanics before ramping up the difficulty through the standard ascension mechanics found in these games (each playthrough is harder after a victory, completely optional though!).

More dynamic than Slay The Spire with a stronger ability to save runs through player skill or a lucky card/artifact which leads to less restarts and more exciting moments. Add in the ability to configure a bunch of fun "mutations" that will make your run easier or harder and the fact that once you beat the highest ascension there are some pre-built mutation sets called elite challenges to keep you playing it is a must play if these kinds of games are your jam.

Monster train is an exceptionally well designed turn based, card game.

Very easy to get into and very easy to sink countless hours into also which offers great value for money.

Plenty of variety of decks (base game has 5) and you always have 2 decks per game. So 1 deck is your main with a  champion and the second deck is a support deck. As you progress in your run cards for both decks become available to choose from providing a lot of combinations and choice.

Bottom line is the game is very fun and is an easy recommend 8.5/10.

Two improvements I would like to see are : 
1. Higher resolution textures used on all graphics
2. When a floor is packed with units have them spaced out a little more so each unit is more easily identifiable (this is a minor gripe)

If a monster train 2 is in the works I would love to see some type of amazing 3d animation as units battle and spells are used. Sorta like that 3d chess type game in star wars or like the old Amiga game Battle Chess. Not sure if this is viable because animation may slow down the flow of the game but 3d graphics done well could make this amazing.

Monster Train is a great game, the kind of great game that has no right to be a great game.
From the moment you look at it on the store page, it looks like a half-finished Chinese mobile game with clunky animations, lazy voice acting, cheap artwork, boring lore and reused sound effects.
However, these small gripes are all there is when it comes to criticising it. A game should be judged by how it plays and Monster Train is no mobile game. It's a rare gem indeed, a great product that you can get tens of hours of enjoyment from for a good price.
As a long time fan of the Slay the Spire genre, I dare say Monster Train was a little too easy for me, having beaten it at covenant 25 in about 50 hours, whereas I'm well over 100 on Slay and still haven't passed Ascension 6.
Outside of the main game, which in itself can be replayed a lot , the title offers a series of challenges that can also be played in multiplayer, something unique to Monster Train.
If you are a fan of the genre or if you are looking for an easier game than Slay to get into it, I have no doubt Monster Train will be enjoyable to you.

I've played Slay the Spire, Darkest Dungeon, Iratus and enjoyed all of them.  I really wanted to get into Monster Train, but I just couldn't because:

1.  It feels like there's little to no diversity within single factions aka classes, and the game introduces you with only 2 factions so the game feels like the same exact build multiple times until different, similarly narrow-minded factions are unlocked.

2. The progression of deck strength after each fight is so insanely fast that many of the starting cards quickly become worthless and thus an element of in-combat strategy feels lost. First fight you'll have like 2/8 creatures and 2 damage spell cards.  Second fight you'll have a couple 20/10 creatures and a couple 12 damage spell cards.  Like... what?  "Hmm should I play this 2/8 creature or this 40/20 creature for the same cost?"

3. By the time it feels like building a well-rounded deck, it's over because there's maybe only 6 fights per run.

However, I'd say try the game and see how you like it.  Just because I didn't enjoy it doesn't mean that you won't too.

Monster Train is a creative twist on the deckbuilder. Managing a mini-tower defense within your locomotive is refreshing, and gives the player a more sense of options than the typical card dueler.

And unlike Slay the Spire, this is an easier game at face value. You likely won't spend dozens of tries just trying to complete a single run. Monster Train spreads out the difficulty, offering options to ramp up the challenge--and try new decks--later. 

Simply put, Monster Train is a less painful companion to StS with a neat twist. Recommended.

cleanly implemented evolution from Slay The Spire.  Adds a tower defence mechanic, removes a lot of the RNG (still plenty in there), lots more unlockable content.

Also does something to help the difficulty curve.  My first run through was pretty easy, but the challenge ramps up as you win more often
amazing card game having 3 levels of fighting is groundbreaking. This game is even better than slay the spire.

The game is a deep hole to sink into. A deck builder rougue-lite at its core, Monster train has stunning visuals, diverse strategy choices that keep your brain going, and a nice little chose your own adventure part between battles. It does all these elements right. What makes it especially cool, are the several different factions with unique mechanics, which also come with two different champions each, which also have unique upgrades that impact each run differently. As a rogue-lite, each run has to be somewhat different to stay entertaining, and Monster train nails that!
Must Buy for deck builder fans. But beware that this can spiral into an hours-devouring collectathon. If you are easily made addicted to such things, advance with caution.

I haven't played this game for too long, but in that time I've managed to beat it several times.

If you liked Slay the Spire, you will absolutely love this game. Very deep from the cards I've unlocked, but not so deep that your run can get screwed if you don't get the *ideal* cards for a particular build. 

With Slay the Spire, the issue I had was that, while the game was very fun, sometimes getting trash cards or a bad artifact meant that you would have a tough time later on. With Monster Train, that problem is mitigated by the ability to upgrade your cards.

I'm not typically a card-game player but this game has me hooked so far.
Excellent game play to get lost in.

[b]Intro[/b]

In MT there are three floors with the "pyre" room above it. Enemies start at the bottom and try to make their way to the room to attack the "pyre". You place units and cast spells to stop them. These are drawn from a deck that starts with basic cards then gets expanded or reduced in size by picking various options.

[b]The Good[/b]

I was discussing this game and STS on Reddit and suddenly it hit me. STS is a roguelike version of Northmark: Hour Of The Wolf and MT is a roguelike version of The Trouble With Robots.

Like TTWR it's a deckbuilding game in which you summon units and cast spells drawn randomly. This means it combines deckbuilding and tower defense - two of my favourite genres. The combination works so well because normally one of the weaker parts of the TD genre is the predictability of the towers, while deckbuilding tends to suffer from allies only being cards. MT gives you the variation of a card game and the engagement of building characters in a role-playing game.

Another strength of Monster Train, especially compared to Slay the Spire (which i thought was mediocre) is the amount of starting options. There are 6 factions (1 DLC) each with 2 paths each with a hero. You pick a faction and one of its heroes plus one of two path of a support faction. This gives you a ton of options to try out how things combine. And after that there are 26 difficulty levels (Covenant level 0-25) plus modifiers for non-official games (both boni and mali).

Some other points:

-    Games take only 25-50 minutes.
-    Optional bonus boss.
-    Tons of customisation options for both spells and units.
-    Cute theme in which the "heavenly" guys are the baddies.
-    All kinds of location events add more variety.
-    The game encourages taking weaker cards by giving special borders/stamps for completing a game with them.
-    Simple to learn, but with quickly ramping difficulty if you want it.
-    The mechanics are quite clever overall - this isn't Hearthstone.

[b]The Bad[/b]

-    Even at Covenant 1 the endboss has twice as much life, which i think is a bit much.
-    At higher Covenant levels you lose more easily to random bullshit like not getting the right upgrade.
-    The Endboss is a bit much at Covenant 25. You can breeze through the rest of the game and still lose.
-    Melting Remnant/Little Fade seems so much stronger than the other factions/heroes.
-    Some units/spells seem much stronger than others (i lost only once when i had a Bounty Stalker).
-    No second chances (though you can Alt+F4 before you lose and try again).
-    It's beyond annoying that you can't pick starting cards - sometimes you have to reroll a dozen times to get good ones.
-    Epic cards (purple dots) are overly rare. In 220 hours i've seen some units only 2-3 times.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Monster Train combines two genres i love with roguelikes, which i hate. Somehow it still manages to be one of my all-time favourite games. It offers nice, quick card/TD games with a lot of variety and progress to be made. After 60 hours i actually reset my progress to start from scratch, just because it was so much fun. I never do that.

I mean, in this game you can kill the endboss with a buffed oven while both have googly eyes, what more do you want?

Promising game, but falls flat in too many areas to really make it good. It shines when you only have 30 or so minutes to play a game and want something to jump into without having to get invested, but the gameplay becomes incredibly stale and predictable. The higher you go, the less viable options there are, to the point where you're basically doing the same thing to win each time. And you'll know you've won by either the second or third fight, everything after that is really just going through the motions.

The two clan system is great on paper, but only some of the clans have actual synergy. More often than not, the other clan cards are just dead weight in your deck that you quickly remove. At the end of most runs, your deck is roughly 90% one clan card, then 10% the other clan. And that's only because you ran out of removal options.

The DLC added a much needed challenge, but was poorly optimized around the base game, rendering several of the hero units as not only worthless, but actively harmful to your deck because you can't remove them and always start with them in your starting hand, effectively making you play with -1 card at the start. The new clan has a really fun mechanic, but again, it lacks any real synergy with the other clans.

Worth picking up on sale. The music is great and the artwork is pretty good. And, despite the criticisms, it really isn't a bad game persay, just feels incomplete and lacking in a lot of areas. You can still have some fun before the flaws really become apparent, and it's a great way to kill time or fiddle around with while you're watching/listening to something else.

Deckbuilders have been such a hard sell for me, and for a short while Monster Train broke that barrier.  The game is deep without being overcomplicated.  Fundamentals are easy to grasp.  The different playstyles of the clans are unique and cool to toy with.  What I'm lacking is any reason to keep doing over.  It wasn't hard to finish my first run and I think I did it on the second try.  But there's been no sign that the game expands in any way.  The different zones are just window dressing and might as well be blank.  The lore might be cool, but it's only in the text of the cards, not represented in-game.

I guess the biggest downfall for me is the sense that each level of progress is just 'same game, but harder'.  The fights aren't different enough to be memorable.  The routes are basically the same.  There's just not enough variety in here to hold my interest.
