I recently cracked a 100 rotating/random win streak in the DLC with Divine victories at the highest difficulty in the game, Covenant 25, and realized that I haven't reviewed the game on Steam. It's time to remedy that. Don't let my 1600 or so hours mislead you, I am actually well over 2000 across multiple profiles (and more if you include time spent modding).

This game deserves every bit of the praise it gets, and to say that I overwhelmingly recommend it is an understatement. It is the single best example of evolution of the roguelike deckbuilder genre since Slay the Spire, and differentiates itself so much in the feel, strategy, and design that the two can perfectly coexist for fans of the genre. Monster Train has a staggering amount of content diversity, with six clans in the DLC that can be mixed and matched for a truckload of combos, each playing uniquely. Couple that content diversity with the game's extremely satisfying exponential power curve and you can enjoy surprisingly difficult gameplay (for those seeking it) while still highrolling out of your mind on occasion and blowing your enemies out of the sky. Another crowning achievement of this game in my opinion is how consistent the tooltips are in describing exactly what happens and how things interact. Phrases like "play a card" and "summon" are precisely used to communicate exact behaviors, and once you understand the rules of the game you can predict nearly every other interaction, even some of the more esoteric ones. There are exceptions, of course, and it's not perfect, but it's 98% of the way there and leaps and bounds beyond other games in this regard. Lastly, while the balance isn't perfect and promotes power-swings from overwhelmingly strong to unbelievably cursed runs, I am a strong proponent that every run is winnable with perfect play, and some will truly test your ability to successfully reason through the decisions presented to you.

All of this isn't to say that the game doesn't have flaws. After 2000 hours, you have the remaining bugs and the design issues memorized by heart, but they're so small compared to the overall enjoyment I've received out of this game that they're barely even worth mentioning in a Steam review. Yes, they should do more regular balance patches; yes, the Umbra clan's Morsel mechanic needs help and is currently designed into a corner; yes, they should address some of the instances of overly punishing RNG like Plink. Despite all that, if you're reading this review looking for help in deciding whether to purchase this game, I can't help but recommend that you pick it up. It is so formative in understanding the hype of modern roguelike deckbuilders that skipping it is unthinkable to me.

I thundered through the campaign for both the base game and DLC in the space of 2-3 days. It's a deeply engaging experience with a lot of interesting challenges and typically resembles something between Hearthstone and a (less intense) darkest dungeon. The deck-building elements are great fun and combinatorial mechanics get really OP really fast if you're using certain factions (anything with Little Fade, honestly). 

The fact that the game lets this happen and promotes it is great. There's deliberate and sharp power creep for both your team and the opponent, and that only multiplies as you start playing up the covenant ranks and using the shards from the Last Divinity DLC. The DLC doesn't add as much game-time as I'd have liked for the fact it costs similar to what I paid for the base game, but the Wurmkin faction and the Last Divinity boss are cool. The shards are by far the most interesting aspect and really do contribute to an even-faster creep in power. 

Monster train has given me nearly 35 hours as of this review and I'll probably be achievement-hunting for another 15-25 over the next few weeks. It's a great game with a lot of charm and it has a bombastic setting that makes the nuttiness at least semi-believable, in its own irreverent way.

Great game, definitely worth the asking price (paid around 10 GBP), and really stands up on a joy-per-hour-per-dollar basis. I expect 50 hours of solid fun for ¬£10, and that seems more than fair to me.
I logged almost 10 hours on my first day of playing this. A perfect hybrid of card game and tower defense. If you are looking for something new to scratch that StS itch, then you found it.

I don't have a lot of fun playing most games in "the genre" (which i'm pretty sure is itself a euphemism for STS-clone when people don't want to actually reference STS?) but Monster Train is by far my favorite. It feels incredibly refined and polished unlike any other roguelite deckbuilder, its mechanics make every single card and upgrade weighty and impactful, it feels like a fucking struggle to make it to the end and you feel like you earn every step of the way. There's a serious sense of personal gameplay progression as you get into the game and learn the system, too. Boss challenges that initially seem utterly insurmountable, just a few playthroughs later look like weaknesses.
Fantastic.

Best roguelike or card game I've ever played on steam.  The wide variety of cards and vastly different mechanics of each faction plus the different ways to combine factions gives this game far more replayability than you would guess at first glance.  And that's before getting into the modifiers you can apply to each run and the expert challenges.  The sense of progress provided by climbing covenant ranks, earning card masteries, and unlocking card frame combined with the wide variety of each run has made this game last far longer than any other roguelike or card game for me.

I've played this game for a mere 41 hours, what a lot of Monster Train addicts would call zero hours. If you are aware that you are playing a card game, there is so much to do here. If you love card games, there is so much to do here and you want to do it all.

Before writing this review, I've perused the "community hub" discussions for this game and, as a consequence of this, have paid close attention to negative reviews for this game. Why? The people who have negatively reviewed this game have trolled the discussion forums on this game's community hub page. They claim to have "beaten the game" and that there is no point in playing the game more. It only took them 60 hours to "beat the game."

I don't know about you, but I've won at Klondike Solitaire, Spider Solitaire, Poker, Texas Hold'em, Cribbage, Pyramid Solitaire, Blackjack, Yahtzee, Monopoly, The Game of Life, Candyland, Operation, and a whole bunch more board and card games. I've played them non-digitally and digitally. I don't think I beat any of those games. I won a "hand of" or a "game of," but the game itself has no end. I can be good at playing such games, but I could still lose the next time I play. 

My recommendation is to not pay attention to people who claim to have "beaten" this game. In reality, what they have done is reach Covenant 25, the highest level possible. Does this mean you can't play the game some more? Ummmm huge nope. If you enjoy playing this game of cards, you can always do challenges and other interesting things and see how you rank among other players. You'll notice that the people who claim to have beaten the game don't talk about how they rank, or what their experience was on a challenge run. You can't beat this game, just like you can't beat any card game. You can become proficient at playing it and, if you enjoy it, you can play it a lot. You can progress through it, learn gradually about how it works. and unlock goodies along the way, and learn how the game works inside and out. You can most certainly level up quick if you wish. That really doesn't mean you beat the game. It means you got a win streak. I'd compare that to getting to the final round of a Texas Holde'em tournament. You didn't beat the game, because the game goes on after you won that particular instance of the game. Get what I mean?

The developers of Monster Train should really quit marketing the "more playability" in their advertising blurbs and just say you're playing a game of cards. It's really quite basic. It's a card game. Of course it's replayable. Until the end of time, if you wish. That's why Monster Train attracts trolls who repeatedly say, "I beat the game! No need to play it again! Got myself to Covenant 25! No point in playing this game anymore!" What they're saying is that they won a hand of Klondike Solitaire and they beat the game, no need to deal out another hand.

If you love card games and games of chance, this one is for you. If you like learning about how your decisions interact with the cards you choose for your deck (like in any trading card game), this game is for you. 

Monster Train is not for you if you wish to play a video game you can beat. There is no beating a game about playing cards. You can learn how to play it well, and win a lot of games of it, but that's it. 

If you disagree with me, show me how you definitively beat Pyramid Solitaire and Hearthstone and Klondike Solitaire and Poker. Feel free to show me you got to Covenant 25, then show me you know what that means and what the game is all about and really get into it. Randomize your clan alliances. Do a challenge. See how you rank among other players.

This game was clearly inspired by Slay the Spire and it wears this proudly, yet it brings enough different concepts/mechanics to the game to both feel familiar yet different and refreshing. All in all, great game for StS fans who want more or something familiar yet new.

I don't usually play card games, but I found this one enjoyable. Monster Train is one of those that falls under don't judge a book by its cover. I like how it has different approaches to whether or not you should thin your deck, stay away from buffs or debuffs depending on the various forms the last boss takes, Seraph. For example, Seraph the Diligent will cause each card played at the beginning of a turn to have the consume trait, and Seraph the Chaste will half all buffs and debuffs that do not benefit him. Taking this into consideration is necessary to have a successful run, and each run has its unique concerns. I recently played Roguebook, and the latter seemingly had more limited options; for example, their answer to disincentivize deck thining was to have cards that add damage based on how many cards are in the draw or discard pile. Overall, Monster train is the best deck-building game of the few that I have played.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
A lot of fun early in the game, but the higher the covenant rank goes, the more grindy it gets as only luck decides if a run will be winnable or not.
I still recommend the game for the first 70-ish hours of fun (which is great for the price tag!), [u]but it's a thumbs down for turning into a random-based gambling grind fest in the end game, so mind that before purchase[/u].


[b]Details[/b]
Early in the game, it's super fun: Looks great, feels great, runs great, wonderful atmosphere and the same price as Slay the Spire (which I refunded btw).

However, at and above covenant rank 22-ish the game is pure frustration, net grind and random decides if a run is winnable or not, nothing else.

Thanks to everything being random, there's little to no choice: cards, artifacts, Champion skills alike comes what the machine rolls, and on higher levels it's critical to have the right combination and boost of everything, otherwise simply the DPS or "reform-rate" or "boost-rate" are too low to win the game, no matter how good one plays.

For example, with Melting Remnant, Rector Flicker simply doesn't damage enough to be valuable vs the last boss. Little Fade it is then, right? Indeed, but Eternal Flame is a must have then, and there's a 33% chance it won't happen... One time it didn't come up as a choice about 10 times in a row...
The same applies to the rest of the cards. Most of them (again, on higher covenant levels) are weighless & useless or in the wrong combination, and mobs on higher ranks are so OP, losing is guaranteed with weaker spells and without a good combo of tank (e.g. Lady of XX) + sweep (e.g. Husk Hermit) + low-capacity multistrike DPS (e.g. Draff) units, and with dead weights like Restore or Wildwood Sap or Steelsinger (for a no-heal hand) just to mention a few, out of the 80% of trash cards, randomly rolled in or forced to the hand.
So the only way to win is with the perfect hand, or at least a fixable one, i.e. there's time to get rid of the trash cards, as well as random favors the player going forward in building a good deck.

All in all, the game basically turns into a brainless grindfest. It's very frustrating, as random decides about winning or losing a run, not the player
The game would be fun with little more choices and a little less random...


Adding to this the DLC is so annoying (see my review [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/unqlfife/recommended/1359320/][b]HERE[/b][/url]) I turned it off to play just the base game instead...


(On the side, I also don't like one is forced to mix clans. I'd like to play games with 100% Melting Remnant, or Hellhorned, or... But I can't. Bugs me for some reason.)

On first glance, Monster Train looked like some cheesy knock off of Slay the Spire, but after giving it some time I realised I was very wrong - it's probably one of the most mechanically interesting deckbuilders out there right now.  With multiple factions each having a unique playstyle (that synergise with each other since you can pick two) and a battle style almost like a card version of tower defense, it's a must play for any fans of the genre.

This is a really cool twist on the single-player deckbuilder roguelike genre, with other greats like Slay the Spire and Griftlands. Monster Train stands out because of it's floor mechanics and extremely fast pace; you'll notice that card upgrades are extremely powerful, and that is because there are only 9-10 battles per run. Compare this to the 50 floors in Slay the Spire and 3 acts in Griftlands. This fast pace and spin on the mechanics can be refreshing. Personally, I wouldn't start here to get used to the genre, but I have friends who did start with Monster Train and absolutely had a blast. Worth picking up if you have any inclination towards strategy or deckbuilders, especially if you enjoy finding synergies in games.
Good Roguelike Fun

TL:DR; A great take on the Sly the Spire genre, Monster Train provides more accessible tower defense gameplay (i.e. easier to get into). While less technically complex, Monster Train's skill ceiling isn't low so there's plenty of longevity.  The different clans (like Magic the Gathering's different mana colours) also provides plenty of variation to keep gameplay fresh.

----

Not going into too much detail in this review. Unlike say Griftlands (another game inspired by StS), I found that I could get into the gameplay for Monster Train almost immediately. It's that easy to grasp (at least for me), and it works well. A few points:


1. The main gameplay is tower defence-like. Kill enemies with static units on each floor (as in they don't chase the enemy) and spells, before they reach your pyre you are trying to protect,
2. The units & spells you use remind me of Magic the Gathering's summoned creatures and spells. There's limited place on each floor though, so choose and position your units carefully.
3. Also like M:tG, you can mix two clans (colours) to try different sterategies.
4. Each run is significantly shorter than StS, maybe a 1/3rd.
Lots of fun, pretty interesting take on the genre!

This is my first deck builder type game and I chose this cause a YouTuber I follow recommended it after agonising over which to play.

At first I was a bit worried when I saw the visuals, it looked like a mobile game and I wondered if it would be any good but by the time I cleared my first run I was hooked. The high level of reactive strategizing with the variety of options in each faction deck makes it very mechanically immersive. As I unlocked more and more cards and cleared more runs, I found synergy between factions I couldn't have thought of just by looking at them.

The game is also quite steep in it's difficulty, I had a fairly easy time hitting Covenant rank 7 but after that was a real trek. My last rogue like was Hades, which is more combat reactive (something I am more used to) and the cerebral reactions in this game gave a very different but just as satisfactory challenge.

Being new to these type of games, I don't have much more to say but I can very safely recommend it.

Edit : Now having cleared Covenant rank 25, my recommendation for this game goes even higher, if you are looking for a rogue like or a deck builder, this is a must play.

This game is a masterclass in balance. To an insane degree too. Probably the most balanced game I've ever played. Example. I thought I had the most unbeatable run. Had a card that had multistrike and gained attack after every strike. He had something like 200x7 attack by the end of one fight. I had prepared backup of other cards with high health. I was unstoppable. Thought I broke the game. But he had one weakness. Low health. I hit a boss that had a sweep attack. Lost the run. That's the kind of variability you'll experience here. 

You even have access to modding in case the game is too hard. Like having cheat codes. There is nothing I can complain about really. Maybe that it would be nice to have more clans. But that might break that perfect balance. Every clan and clan combination (you get a 2nd backup clan to combine two in a run) is worth a try and plays competently. Adds a new flavor to every run keeping every play different. Seems endless. I hope they do a sequel.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
If you're on the fence but you like deckbuilder roguelikes, I can safely tell you to go ahead and skip this review - you can buy Monster Train with confidence. It's fantastic and I can easily recommend it just as strongly as I would recommend Slay The Spire. The game plays great, the variance is excellently balanced, there are many valid builds for huge replayability, and overall everything is just about perfect for a game in this genre.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] The faction system allows you to mix and match decks for a new experience every time, or to stick with a combination of elements you feel comfortable with
[*] Unlockables add more variety to each faction as you play them but aren't necessary to win - they just add more spice
[*] Art is just excellent across the board. All of the cards, characters, and set pieces are beautifully illustrated
[*] Every single unit or spell deck in your card can be upgraded in a variety of fashions for even [i]more[/i] build depth - or with the DLC, you can even mash them together!
[*] Cards are clear in what they do, the UX is excellent. The cards read well and balance form and function. Tooltips abound for expanded information. This is simply deckbuilder UX done right.
[*] The UI works very well. You can check what's in your library, what's been discarded, what the results of your action will be, etc. You don't have to spend a bunch of time calculating action paths or doing math by hand, Monster Train is non-adversarial in that regard and arms you with knowledge to ease the playthrough rather than hoping you'll trip up with bad math.
[*] Difficulty seems spot on, and can be adjusted to suit your desired challenge level. Most runs are winnable if played smart, once you know what you're doing, but the game doesn't feel easy because of that. Winning runs are usually a result of proper setup, planning, and customization. If you push your luck at the wrong time or you neglect to apply what you've learned previously, it can all fall apart on you quickly.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
My cons are mostly minor quibbles, nothing here is a big deal. There aren't a lot of flaws, and to be honest, I really had to dig to think up things to put here.
[list]
[*] Initial build-up can be a little slow. Unlock the other clans, play around for a bit, really get to know the game before you judge it. The initial options are a bit tame and the difficulty may feel too easy while it lets you learn the first few games.
[*] Some balance issues - some clans, champions, or upgrade paths are just plain not as good as others (I'm looking at you, Hellhorned). It's good to have the variety, but I wish they were more functionally useful in a greater number of cases.
[*] The music while good, lacks variety. It is subtle enough that it won't grate on you, but there aren't a ton of tracks.
[*] Sound design in general is a bit of a mixed bag. Nothing is what I would classify as bad [i]per se[/i], just some of the effects seem like strange choices and/or get repetitive. The SFX get the job done and are inoffensive, but they're not great.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I can rarely recommend a game this strongly. If you like deckbuilder roguelikes, you will like this game. It takes elements you already know and love, adds in placement zones and defense mechanics, spices it up with heavy per-run customization, and lets you choose the experience you want on every run. If you've never played a deckbuilder-style roguelike here, this (or Slay The Spire) is an excellent place to start. There's a lot to unlock, huge replayability, and the experience is consistently enjoyable from start to finish. Monster Train is an excellent buy at full price, and if you see it on sale I'd snap it up right away.

Addicting as fuck.

Comparisons to Slay the Spire are inevitable, but ultimately this game plays differently enough to not feel like a clone. It's still squarely within the deckbuilder rougelite genre, so if you've played anything in the genre before you'll get up to speed quickly.

There's 5 clans/classes (each with an unlockable alternate sub-class) in the base game, and each one plays differently from the other. Before beginning a run you need to choose one of these, as well as a secondary allied clan from the same group of 5. This choice then determines the pool of cards and items you can run into throughout your run. Because each of the classes/clans play rather differently from each other, there's a fairly large amount of viable strategies.

Experimenting with these combinations is fun, and because each run isn't particularly lengthy (maybe anywhere from 30-60 minutes), the game seems to actively encourage this experimentation. As with all of these similar sorts of games, RNG of course plays a role, but I wouldn't say that I've ever felt quite as screwed over it by as I have in other similar games like this. Upon finishing a run, you'll level up the clans/classes you chose and unlock additional cards, challenges, and items that you might encounter in future runs.

All in all, a very solid option within this genre. Deep enough to keep veterans of the genre engaged, but still very approachable for newcomers.

Monster Train (MT) is another addition to the rogue-like deck-building genre. As such, comparisons with other games, like Slay the Spire, are inevitable. Personally, I would say that MT isn't all that different. But what it lacks in mechanical originality, it exceeds in streamlining the core experience of a deck builder; the variety of deck builds. Indeed, the base game comes with 10 different champions each with diverse upgrade paths. Throw in the fact that each run is based on a clan pairing, your pool of draftable cards has a sizeable amount of diversity. Your builds can be as varied as you like and the ability to customise mutators creates even more opportunity to experiment with your wildest theorycrafting.

I have to admit that the deciding factor between whether I enjoy a deck-building game or not is rooted in the thematic & aesthetic design. At first, the visual design did not hook me at all. I felt that the illustrations were far too exaggerated & 'cartoony'. There was a slight clash between the 3D rendered Boneshaker and its 2D occupants, the most egregious dissonance found with the train wheels. However, as I played more and more the characters started to grow on me. It's difficult to dislike the cute Umbra morsels.

Additionally, I appreciate the amount of care poured into writing the flavour text. Each card has a sizeable lore blurb that ties the MT world together. Admittedly, the story isn't particularly fleshed out but the subtle references that underpin the card descriptions, enemy encounters, and random events, truly sparks the world to life. [spoiler] Fel's Wings of Light theme seems to echo with the clang of a hammer & anvil, perhaps a nod to Heph's status as her purported daughter? [/spoiler] Ultimately, without the lore & aesthetic, you're just playing a numbers-generator.

I definitely recommend Monster Train as its given me some enjoyable experiences.

Such as, the first time you reach a bosses' Relentless phase. The moment when the words, "Relentless", appear evoke the Boss Warning trope √† la Mega Man. There's something visceral about seeing the boss launch themselves into your minions at Ultra speed and subsequently encase the defeated floor in solid ice.

However, the highlight of my experience would definitely be building the chonkiest, absolute unit of an Ember Forge. I found it a nice touch that there's many ways to increase both the stats and the physical size of a card unit. Seeing the Ember Forge width fill the entirety of the train floor and its chimney protruding into the floor above was particularly satisfying.

Did I complete the run successfully, of course not. But I definitely had fun!

‚ô™WE'RE ON THE RAILWAY TO HELL!‚ô´ RAILWAY TO HELL!‚ô™

You like card games? Like experiment? Like rogue-like RNG? Like board game like tactics? Deck building? 

If the answers were yes, then give this game a try. Your the last hope for hell as you try to relight the Pyre by driving the Boneshaker, the train on the railway, down the tracks through each ring of hell, and picking your path and resources, while fighting off the forces of Heaven trying to destroy the heart of your train.

Each ring has multiple bosses (with boss variants), the resources RNG'd between 2 paths, you also pick one of five (six with dlc) clans with unique gameplay plus one to support, each clan has a unique champion (2 champs with dlc) with 3 upgrade paths plus , you start with a semi random deck (a set base of cards, plus 5 random ones), Each clan has 40 (41 dlc) cards to use to build a unique deck each run. Plus random events, artifacts supplying passive buffs and effects, a 4 level train (3 areas to fight and the 4th being your pyre to defend), and you have a unique run every game. Did I mention you can modify (upgrade) card with random upgrades from the merchants?

this game is a GOD DAM DELIGHT to play if you love card and board games as it combines elements from both with lots of strategy.

Bonus! Daily challenges and community challenges to spice things up! What are you waiting for?! Let the train steward take your ticket before yeeting him into the nearest hole to optimize your deck today!

Beat it on my first run. Everything after that is you adding difficulty modifiers yourself before and during the game. Pretty easy way to design a game that you don't have to balance at all. Cant recommend this game, despite its good idea, flow and music. Not worth the full price for sure.

It is VERY short with a very low replayability. And I know this is simple "runs-based" roguelike, but it is still short and subpar comparing to many good roguelikes on the market.

There is no time for any real deck bulding (which was supposed to be the point of this game), so most runs are about picking up the copies of 2-3 best cards for a faction and getting rid of weaker cards whenever possible. 80% of cards and combos in this game are mostly useless, because the run will end before you upgrade your deck and "mana" enough. None of the playable combos is too sophisticated either - its mostly about putting same monsters in same places in every fight and then spamming same 1-2 cards over and over. The game is also very easy - once you discover best combos and effects, you will have no motivation to search harder. All replayability and difficulty in this game is artificial  - instead of longer, more challenging runs, deck building and new encounters, its up to the player to set himself some game modifiers or pick subpar champions/factions to make his life harder. Not fun and a very lazy idea.

Its all sad because when you start the game you can spend the whole evening playing, without even noticing. However, next day it becomes obvious that you discovered most of it and further play feels more and more pointless. Wasted opportunity to make realy unique and fun game.

When I first bought Monster Train I dumped 25 hours into it within my first two days. I left a quick review saying as such, and anointed it my Game of the Year 2020, which, to be honest, should really be all you need to give it a try if you have even a cursory interest in deckbuilding games.

I want to say a little more this time around, but for the most part my original thoughts are still basically the same, so I wouldn‚Äôt sweat my detailed review and instead just go get it.

Monster Train is a marvellous fusion of the tower defence and roguelite deckbuilder genres, which proves to be a jazztastic combination. Your run-to-run strategies focus on creating a defensive setup across three floors of your eponymous train; the ‚Äútowers‚Äù having been replaced by units. Once assigned to a floor it‚Äôs tricky to reassign creatures (exceptions apply), so your run is spent visualising which units will populate which floors, and in what order. You'll think about which monsters you're using to tank, and which are for damage or support, as well as what types of enemies your setup handles well, and what areas you still need to find solutions for.

Monster Train opts for a savvy design focus where the game [i]wants[/i] you to create a deck so hideously busted it threatens to collapse the train with its brilliance, and it isn‚Äôt coy about this fact. After every battle you‚Äôre given stopping points to buy powerful upgrades for your creatures and spells. Have an insane death machine that hurls out damage? How would you like to make it attack multiple times? Got a tank that can withstand a battering ram? How about making it so it always revives on death? And don‚Äôt forget the stops that let you straight up [i]duplicate a card in your deck[/i]. Got a spell that always comes back to your hand and forces enemies not to take a single attack in their journey through your train? Have another, treat yourself. Runs are about finding the thing that makes your strategy ludicrous and leaning into it‚Ä¶ [i][b]HARD[/b][/i].

And the crazy part is it never seems that unobtainable. It always feels like you‚Äôre just one draft or upgrade away from something utterly out of control. This is a far cry from Slay The Spire‚Äôs more measured progression, where something monstrous is a product of careful early choices and cautious balancing of options until later in a run. Seeing things come together in Monster Train makes you feel like a genius as your build not just hums but roars. 

And I think this has something to do with the pacing of each run. There‚Äôre only nine battles in Monster Train, and they blast past as your train rockets its way along the track towards Hell‚Äôs core. As a result, runs are a little quicker, but it‚Äôs also why you get so powerful so fast, as there‚Äôre only a handful of fights to get through before the final boss. There‚Äôs perhaps less variety in terms of opposition line-ups across the battles when compared to Slay the Spire (though some line-ups will force you to make small adjustments to your standard strategy), however I feel Monster Train avoids the tedium of the 40+ fights you endure on your way to Slay the Spire‚Äôs peak. Overall, I enjoyed the pacing and shorter timeframe for putting together a deck in the space of a run.

I haven‚Äôt even got to the glorious part of Monster Train. There‚Äôre five factions and you combine two each run (a primary and secondary). Each faction has its own keywords and basic interactions, but the mashup of two factions together means you get to combine their strengths or cover their weaknesses as you see fit. Incredibly, this combination approach provides such a vivid amount of replayability. You can be playing a run and feeling like one of the creatures you picked isn‚Äôt quite working and suddenly think ‚ÄúI wonder what it‚Äôd be like to have this other faction‚Äôs core keyword in combination with this?‚Äù And that‚Äôs your inspiration for your next run idea. There‚Äôre so many possibilities that form out of the combination system. Sure, deck design ideas sort of boil down to some core archetypes, but the process of getting there is always fascinating.

Progression in Monster Train is a bit of a mixed bag. There‚Äôre a lot of unlockables to aim for early on: additional factions, alternative champions, new cards; but you‚Äôll get most of this fairly quickly even if you‚Äôre a relatively casual player. After that you mostly focus on moving up the covenant (difficulty) ranks (more on this in a mo). There‚Äôre a few other goals you can do if you play a lot of the game e.g. winning a run gives every card used in that deck a special border to enjoy, so you can try and finish runs with cards you haven‚Äôt used before, or you can try and explore upgrade paths for champions you‚Äôve not revealed yet. But mostly the progression at this point feels a little bit like completionism more than anything else.

On the topic of the covenant ranks, they‚Äôre [i]okay[/i]. For the most part, the additional wrinkles they throw in [i]seem[/i] annoying, but winning decks rarely feel like the extra challenges are significant hurdles to them. There‚Äôre about three or four ranks that offer significant drawbacks that will really affect your play, but the fact that there‚Äôre another 21 ranks or so feels more like it would give people reasons to keep playing, rather than just lumping all the difficulty into a few tougher jumps. I don‚Äôt hate it, because there‚Äôs a lot to explore in the deckbuilding options Monster Train offers, but, for the most part, the covenant climb is more of a carrot than an obstacle.

That said, by the time you‚Äôre playing on the hardest levels of the covenant then it becomes really hard to tell whether you‚Äôre making good choices or whether you‚Äôre just being blessed by RNG. I often play runs and feel like I‚Äôm making super solid design decisions and then things just feel like they‚Äôre falling apart anyway. I try and think back on what I could‚Äôve changed and it isn‚Äôt always super clear if it would‚Äôve made any real difference. I could just be a bad player, and I know there‚Äôs for sure more I learn about strategy every time I play, but I‚Äôve played all the way to the top covenant and I feel like my decision making approach has been largely similar throughout (aside from learning what common pitfalls to avoid). Does this make the gameplay any less unsatisfying? Perhaps, but if you get that far then you‚Äôve probably got good value for money out of the game anyway.

As a final note, if you‚Äôve got a few friends (or even if not) then I‚Äôd highly recommend trying out the Hell Rush variant as well. It boggles my mind that no one thought of this mode before. Essentially, all players play the same seed run at the same time. Battles and post-battle rewards are all on a timer, and you‚Äôre forced to simply auto-resolve the remaining rounds of a fight if you run out of time. Playing along with your friends and discussing the choices you make along the way as you try and outlast them is such a wonderful experience, and you‚Äôll find your decks often diverge a lot more than you‚Äôd expect. Even more impressive is that Monster Train‚Äôs team managed to include this mode without taking resources away from the game‚Äôs overall experience at all.

Overall, I‚Äôve been massively impressed by Monster Train, and, while I don‚Äôt play it constantly, I go back to it every few months to do a little more, and it‚Äôs an enjoyable experience every time. Most recently, I‚Äôd never managed to find a reason to play Penumbra‚Äôs Architect upgrade path, and one of my most recent runs finally had a call for it, so I got to explore that area for the first time at around 120 hours of gameplay.

A quick note about the DLC: it‚Äôs good, but it‚Äôll take you a few runs to acclimatise to the changes it adds. Definitely only worth getting if you‚Äôve played a good chunk of the base game and want some more variety.

So far I'm not liking the game. I quite liked Slay the Spire, and I have been playing many roguelites recently. Many reviewers here will praise it for being fast paced and allow a lot of variety. I think it is too fast, and doesn't allow you to really do much deck building. Once you are getting close to a fun build, you are done. And a part of the difficulty scaling in the game is adding bad cards to your starting deck, that you have to spend the short game removing again. Very bad mechanic, in my opinion. I would also say, that there might be a decent amount of variety yes - but a lot of cards are deadweight if not in the correct build, meaning less flexibility. Overall I feel like there is more boring or wrong choices in this game, and many of the choices I get to make during a game is either: boring or meaningless.
I've been playing it a bit more to try to give it a fair chance - and maybe after 15 hours or more my thoughts will change. We'll see.

10/10 one of my favorite card battlers and probably the best card battler out there in my opinion. Other games like Slay the Spire of Ring of Pain rely too much on luck and random chance to be successful. Monster Train allows you to make strategic decisions on the fly to turn the tide and achieve the win. There are five unique champions (six if you get the DLC) and for every run you choose a primary champion and a secondary champion whose deck gets incorporated into your starting deck. The game challenges you to win the run using every combination of champion deck. Not only that but there are 25 different "covenant" challenges that change up the rules or increase the difficulty. 

If you get the DLC there is yet ANOTHER challenge to try to beat, once again with the challenge to beat it with every combination of champion deck. It's so satisfying to win a run with a new combo and get that little check mark in your logbook.
Better than Slay the Spire, unique mechanics, great music, 5 decks with mixing and matching, this game is a blast. If you like roguelike deckbuilders this is an absolute must

Slay the Spire comparisons are obvious, but it's a reasonably different game. The tower defense aspects are solid and it's significantly more forgiving than StS at lower difficulty levels. Those combos can be completely ridiculous and a lot of fun to pull off - they can also never materialise, leaving you completely unable to progress past roughly boss no. 2 on higher difficulties. TL:DR; Like Slay the Spire with tower defense. Lots of clan combinations for variety. StS is a survival game, and this makes me feel crummy sometimes.In MT, you make game breaking combos and decimate the bosses, except they scale exponentially too, and you can lose if you mess up. This makes it very satisfying to win but very challenging at the same time. DLC is a must, the infusion mechanic literally exponentiates the number of viable strategies.

I don't know why this game isn't more popular. I have never found a game with as much depth and replayability as Monster Train. It's like Slay the Spire + Tower defense. I like so many things about it:
1. Combination of 2 clans: You end up with 36 different overlapping card pools. Each clan has 2-3 main mechanics. Healing is primarily an Awoken thing, Spell damage is primarily Stygian and so on. This restriction also adds a lot of variety. Some runs, you will know you have no way to heal, but some runs you can go all in on tank and spank. Masterful game design.
2. Game length: 9 rounds, Each is 15 mins at most. I finish most runs in 45 mins.
3. Auto combat: The tower defense style means you don't need to painfully target each attack. (unlike Slay the Spire, which gets tedious)
4. Daily Challenges: For even more variety there are mutators you can apply to every run. And there are daily challenges with leaderboards. I have probably been playing 2 of these, the one without the DLC and the one with DLC almost daily for 2 months.
5. You can share seeds, adding a community aspect to the game.
6. Card design: I think the clans are done well. Maybe there is room for improvement, but there are very few cards that are powerless.
7. OP by design: Instead of trying to balance the cards, you win Monster Train by making an OP deck that can dish our thousands of damage in a turn. And there are many ways to make OP decks. I don't know if this was intentional, but it makes the game really satisfying. Your goal in every run is to exploit some combo and go completely out of control.
8. My recommendation would have been tepid for just the base game, but the DLC lets you infuse units into each other and exponentially explodes the number of viable strategies. Insanely good game design.

Cons:
1. Lore; There is some Hell vs Heaven lore going on but it's not super clear and not super interesting.
2. Too many bells and whistles. I like the variety but there are so many game modes. I would like to play Hell Rush, but there are often not enough people in that mode. There could be ways to fix this, e.g. have a global hell rush every 15 mins. I'm happy to wait that long to get a full lobby. Another thing is the covenants, you basically play only Cov 1 or 25, but the levels in between are just progression stages.
3. Limited variety in enemies, bosses and events: There are enough artifacts to keep runs interesting, but you start to realize that each ring can only have a few enemy types. The pool of bosses is limited. This is probably necessary to keep the game balanced w.r.t. your power level in each ring, but it feels a little too predictable after a while. This is not a shortcoming of the game implementation, but of the overall design. It'll be tough to add more enemies while still maintaining balance, and I don't see them doing it. But looking at what they did with the DLC, I wouldn't be surprised.
4. Limited variety in events: Some events like the one with the blacksmith or Dante are really fun, but you run out of events long long before you unlock all clan cards. I think this is actually a major shortcoming of the game, and realizing this was the first time I felt dissatisfied with the game.
4. Shard mechanics in the DLC are a little unclear. There seem to be 4 levels of threat, but I don't know what they do and this makes planning harder. I don't want to memorize impact of taking shards or looking it up on the wiki. If they made the impact more transparent, it would add another layer of strategy, and could resolve my complaint about lack of enemy variety.

One of the best of it's genre of Deck-builders.

Compared to slay the spire, it feels faster, and the combination of different clans makes for a lot of varied decks across runs.

Honestly this game is what I was looking for when playing Slay the Spire (StS).

I love the variety in the start of the game, something I felt StS lacked. You have 5 factions each with 2 champion sets. You get to choose 2 unique factions and champion sets to start the game (although you only use 1 champion). Once you get a covenant level or two you will also receive random starting cards which further change each run. Overall I think the starting situation removes the boring start that StS has at the beginning of each run. I played through with random/random selected each run which I highly recommend so you don't get hung up on 1 strong combination.

The ability to upgrade cards can make 1 card carry a lot of weight. There are a lot of fun possibilities with just the "Hold Over" upgrade for spells. This combined with the simpler choice tree make it so each run you feel powerful. The choices aren't impacted by battle choice either so you really get what you want each option. Overall I just felt more consistent than StS.

I felt the covenant system progressed with you as you got better at the game. Some of the final ones were a bit too big of a step but most of them were small changes that add up. I don't remember much about the ascension levels in StS but I actually enjoyed the grind in this one and I didn't really enjoy it in StS.

The covenant system also leads into my only real cons with the game:
1. I felt the final few ranks were a bit too steep. They really make me want to play at lower ranks than try to actually go the completionist route of winning with each faction/champion combination. After beating rank 25 once, I'm pretty much done with the game unless there is DLC released.

2. The expert challenges should have been unlocked prior to rank 25. I think they add a much needed variety for when you get frustrated with the covenant grind. I also wish you could play them not at rank 25.

3. I wish there was an undo button. A lot of strategy games do this but when my cat walks across my keyboard and hits the end turn button, I would really like to undo that instead of having quit the game and restart the fight which is pretty close to cheating imo. I also sometimes misplayed spells from either wanting to put them back into my hand or my mouse slid last minute and it casted on the wrong target. Overall I think if I'm playing a game solo, there should be no reason to not be able to undo your last action or even entire turn.

Overall for the price this game offers a fantastic deck builder that I feel like almost anyone can get their money's worth. I plan on buying the DLC next sale.

Monster Train is my favorite roguelike deckbuilder out there right now. This isn't a Slay the Spire clone, like most others are, it is its own beast entirely.
It fuses the elements that work from other popular deckbuilders and weaves them perfectly into its Tower Defense-like gameplay. I personally really love the upgrades system- each card has 2 slots for upgrades, and you can add basically any combination you can think of to them! This makes it really refreshing to what StS clones typically do, where they have the base card and a flat upgraded form, since YOU decide what the card's upgraded form does! 
On top of this, each clan leader card has three upgrade trees, each going to a level of 3, that you can mix and match to create some devestating combinations. I really love how no option feels awful, just not your style, at worst. Take the Melting Remnant's tree that gives him a large attack and health pool, as well as Burnout- sure, you lose out on Reform each turn, but if you get enough Reform spells later in your run, you now have an absolute beast of a unit to play!

Each of the clans in the game are insanely fun, to boot! I found the beginner clan options to be the worst, obviously, with complete duds that feel super hard to win with, but as you unlock more clans, you get to truly experience what makes Monster Train a master class in its genre. 

My favorite clan combination is Melting Remnant primary / Umbra secondary. They both play into themes of having units die in combat, and overall synergize really well. Melting Remnant is truly the hardest class to put down- something about it just clicks with me. It's part "number gets larger" and part "graveyard recursion" that just makes it so satiafying.

This is a 10/10 game for anyone that's a fan of roguelike deckbuilders. If you're looking for a game that isn't just a Slay the Spire clone, look no further!

(P.S. Monster Train is available on Xbox Game Pass Ultimate, and that's where I first played it after months of the game sitting on my steam wishlist and I highly recommend trying it there if you're unsure!)

Highly highly recommend this game.

I've played hundreds of hours of Slay the Spire, and I thought this game was going to be very similar, and I was right... kind of.

It's obviously similar in the way that you draw and play cards and turn-based combat happens, and the functions of some of the cards are similar/the same, as is the idea of using energy (ember) to play cards,  but there's a whole lot that's different too.

There are two types of cards - spell cards and unit cards. The primary means of combat is by spawning several units (by playing cards) which do the fighting for you, then you use your cards to heal, buff etc. those units using spells. Spells can also be used to damage enemies directly, and apply debuffs to them, but for most builds the units do most of the work.

There are 5 different "clans" in the base-game, each of which has 2 "champion" units. Each champion unit brings a different skillset, and different cards along with it (though there is some crossover between the two champions in each clan), and then for each run you also pick an "allied" clan and champion (though you don't actually *get* the champion card) which again influences the cards and units you get. This means there's a whole load of different combinations of "builds" that you can run with, just with the initial choice of which champion/allied clan (I think that's 80 combinations?), and then each of those clans has different combos of starter cards you can get randomly, and 3 different champion upgrades, of which you get a choice of 2 each time randomly. And I guess that's a lot of randomness but it's within set confines and it never feels like you're without good choices.

All of the clans and champions are very different. They've done a *really* good job of making the gameplay for each champion and clan different. There are a lot of mechanics which totally change the way you play for a run, and there's something for every play style.

Ultimately, I would say that, comparing it to Slay the Spire, there is probably more depth with Monster Train, though it's not so brutally hard,

The only real thing I've run into that's a bit frustrating is sometimes the abilities of the final boss in particular can *really* screw you over and it can feel like there's not that much you can do about it. Mostly, with careful play you can get around these abilities but once in a while it just feels like you get screwed.

Overall though, very fun, lots of replay value, and I think I'll keep coming back to it.

I'll probably go back to Slay the Spire too, though.

Great game, a tad on the easier/forgiving side. If you've played Slay the Spire, you'll have a MUCH easier time at this game. Spire can be downright brutal even at the early levels, but Monster Train is just more forgiving. The graphics are gorgeous, and I didn't see any inconsistencies with language or keywords - which is paramount for a card game that relies on such nuances.  

For the negatives here, balance of factions comes quickly to mind. Some are just obscenely easy to finish consistently with, and others rely on outright tons of RNG (both in what cards you take, what artifacts you gain, and your literal draw in a match). Overall though, the curve is much smoother even with the most RNG-based faction than Spire. 

The other big negative is the "roguelike" aspect where finishing and leveling up factions can actually hamper you - when you first unlock a faction, it's SUPER consistent because your card pool is so limited. You know what you are going to get in virtually every run. Once you level up and unlock more cards, well... that dilutes your card pool from the initial starting stock. Some of the additional cards can be great, others not so much. In the end, you play with what you are dealt, but it's an aspect of the game that feels out of place. Instead of earning more, it can feel like a punishment.

Very competent and fun deckbuilder, colourful and cheerful aesthetics, varied and interesting playstyles. Compared to e.g. Slay the Spire, it ramps up the power of your deck very fast, and there seems to be more of a choice in how to play as you between stages always divert your path to pick what kind of nodes you are interested in.

Nodes are spell upgrade, unit upgrade or artifact shops; main faction or allied faction unit drops; gold, health or artifact drops; card duplication; up to two card discard; and special events.

Factions are basically melee offence focused Hellhorned, restoration and growth focused Awoken, spell and debuff focused Stygian Guard, environmental and consumptive focused Umbra, and decay and replacement focused Melting Remnant. Each faction has two champions with different properties and starting cards, and in a run you choose one faction for your in-play champion and half your cards, and one allied faction out-of-play champion for the other half of your cards. Well, there are non-faction cards as well, but the main gist is still the same.

Each fight you have three floors with a non-combat fourth floor with the pyre you're trying to defend at the top. Fights are done by using your energy and cards from your hand to place units on the floors, cast spells or remove junk cards. Enemies normally move up a floor each turn they survive. Every fight is concluded by a boss fight, but every so often you get a major boss who is present outside the floor but moving between floors, having some effect on their current floor. Each of the major bosses has a few different modes.

In addition to that, the artifacts and special events, mutators, covenant levels and challenges provide ample variety.

[h1]Take a train ride and claim back hell[/h1]

Welcome to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1102190/Monster_Train/]Monster Train[/url], a deck building game where you have to summon creatures and cast spells to defeat invading enemies.

[h2]Visuals and Audio[/h2]

First off, the art style is very vibrant. The train and its creatures all stand out. Colours pop out, from the backgrounds to your cards in your hand. Your spells, like explosions, have effects that look like they fit in the game. Everything has that polished stylised artwork as it's a bit cartoony but not overly so. A plus is that the game does not take itself too seriously. It has a bit of humour with flavour text and the like. The music is great and fits the style of the game. The sound effects like ice crystalizing or hitting enemies with a tree trunk all all sound good as well.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
You get a starting deck of cards with basic creatures and spells that are based on one of the 5 clans (6 with the DLC). They all have different play styles. For example: The Hellhorned do high damage and have armour synergies while The Stygian Guard will have weaker units but have strong debuffs and spells.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2599405481 

Once you choose the starting deck you enter the core game loop. Battles and Deck Building.

[list][*]Battles are fought on 3 floors at a time. The bottom, middle and top parts of the train are all locations you can place creatures that you randomly draw from your deck. Once you play your turn, the enemies turn start by attacking on their floor followed by your creature counter attack. The invaders then move one level up if they survive. Your goal is to make them not go through the top floor as that's when they damage your train's life points. Lose all your life points and the game is over.

[*]After winning battles you get the chance to upgrade your cards. You can then customise your deck by getting new cards or upgrading current ones. And this part makes the game for me, you get to experiment a lot which is a big plus. The game is designed to create BIG damaging combos.[/list]

[h2]What's my Point of View[/h2]

This is one of the few games that I played that I cannot find a bad thing about it. Each time you try a run there is something new to discover like a new combo, new bonuses or even changing the rules of a battle in your opponents favour. Monster Train is simple and entertaining while offering just enough challenge.

[b]Recommended[/b]

Monster Train is fantastic! The graphics are colorful and well done, but the important part is that the gameplay is top notch. A unique take on a deck-builder, Monster Train twists the typical board by having a unique 3 floor play space. The ability to mix/match cards from two factions per run means that there are endless possible combinations to try and succeed with. Monster train (MT) is a Deck builder/tower defense/auto-battler. It is one of the first in this vein yet one of the best. What I find the most fun in MT is figuring out the puzzle of the run to make it a winning run, going from zero to ravaging monstruous steamroller.

The combat is also fun in its unique way, it is a constant balance between long-term and short-term decisions. I‚Äôm coming from Slay the Spire (StS), and I find it satisfies the same itch, but if you don‚Äôt like Slay the Spire you might be overlooking Monster Train because those two games are still very different.

MT has a unique approach to CCG (computer card game.) It is very consistent yet each run is unique and fun in their own way.  The map design is very restricted: Each run has 8 battles, 3 of which are bosses. Between each battle, you have to select between two sets of 3 event tiles (which can be shops, random events, card removal etc.) Your choice will most of the time be guided by the needs and opportunities you identified in your deck. This means [b]you improve through choices you made in event tiles[/b]. I would say the decisions you make in event tiles are more important than your combat abilities.

The way combat works in MT gives you a lot of room for planning. It looks like a tower defense game, where you have 3 floors to ready before invasion by enemies. The enemies spawn at the bottom and work their way up, you have to eliminate them all before they get to the top. Each combat ends with a midboss that has to kill everything on a floor before proceeding to the next. Preparing for the midboss is key to victory. This results in a more strategic gameplay than a StS. In StS each combat turn is basically a procedurally generated puzzle you have to solve, you have to do some planning within combats but it‚Äôs a minor part of it. In MT, because enemies move through your train one level at a time, and the game gives you a combat preview, it‚Äôs easy to know what is coming and you can plan accordingly.  The combat then becomes a fight to get your plan to execute properly, you have to balance short-term and long-term decisions in order to be ready for the ‚Äúfinal wave‚Äù and stomp on the midboss. It‚Äôs a very different feel but it‚Äôs equally fun!

Actually, I decided to write this review after a particularly fun run, I hope this doesn‚Äôt read like an alien language to someone who never played the game‚Ä¶ The run had an insane combination that made short work of the final boss. I had a [i]hellhorned brute[/i], and a [i]horned warrior[/i] that could hit twice per turn. [i]Rage[/i] gives +2 damage to your unit, and with [i]hellhorned brute[/i] it gives +5. I had [i]Ritual of battle[/i] which gives +10 rage to a unit when played. I could use that card to improve the damage of my [i]horned warrior[/i] by 100! (5 * 10 * 2 hits) I made sure to buff the HP of both units so they survive hits. I also upgraded my [i]Ritual of Battle[/i] to make it cheaper to play and with [i]Holdover[/i] which let me draw it each turn. So each turn, I would increase the damage output of my units by 100, plus whatever more I could do that turn (which amounted to about 100 more damage.) The result was that no enemy unit could pass the first level of my train and the final boss ate it at the second turn of the final wave. And this is pretty much the most basic interaction you can get working.

Each of the 5 classes in MT has their own mechanics that I feel can get out of control in their own way. It‚Äôs terribly fun and after 20 hours of gameplay I feel like I only scratched the surface.

I have a few very minor complaints with the game, but really nothing to detract from the fun it is:
[list]
[*] The music. I turned it off after my first run because I did not like it at all. And I‚Äôm someone very easy to please with game soundtracks. The sound effects are also not good, but not bad either.
[*] The graphics are no more than functional. I find the enemy units to be very ugly and boring, the player units are alright but no more. 
[*] The UI is sometimes a bit wonky. You have to navigate more menus than necessary to do things (especially starting a run.) The clickable areas are too small and I‚Äôve had one case of the wrong card being selected for an effect (although I could correct it before confirming.) But the core gameplay UI works well enough for the weirdness to not be noticeable when playing.
[*] The performance on 4K. It just requires way more resources for 4K than necessary. I have the GPU to run it, but for a CCG, I don‚Äôt see why a top of the line GPU is necessary. I manage to get better performance by using a custom Proton version on Linux with FSR upscaling injection. But direct support for FSR would be welcome, as the FSR injection hack makes the UI look uglier.
[/list]

This game is infuriating, addicting, attention grabbing, fun, stunning, etc, etc, etc. you get the point. This game is somewhat about RNG sure but most of it is literally you sitting there, playing a card expecting an amazing result only to realize that you didn't consider a consequence and now your unit is DEAD. Or you're doing amazing, so confident, your deck is perfect and all of the sudden, you lose, your pyre is dead. So you sit there and just stare at the screen because you have NO IDEA what just happened. My favorite is playing a card, it's awesome, you think you just made the game winning move, you figured it all out but.. you didn't read the fine print on a boss. They have stealth. You put alllll of your damage on your first row of enemies and they will all DIE and not do a single hit of the 400 DMG you thought they'd do so.. you sit there with your hands in your hair, your head leaned back and scream at the ceiling because what else are you gonna do. Quite literally, 80% of me playing this game is me going "WHY DID YOU JUST DO THAT!?" or "WHAT DID YOU JUST DO!!??" to myself and my cats staring at me like i'm insane. 

That is this game in a nut shell. Some RNG but most is completely you and going back and trying to be better. 18 hours and I only have 2 victories. This is my first deck builder ever so I'm sure that people out there with a ton of experience think that's pretty sad but man, those 2 victories, man did they feel good. Monster Train is a deckbuilding roguelike, meaning that each run of the game involves building a deck of spells and monsters that you play onto the floors of the train that you are piloting through Hell.
Your objective is to make it through the nine circles of Hell and relight the pyres that the angels have snuffed out. The angelic hordes will attack your train in waves, climbing the three floors where you play your demonic defenders and eventually attacking the Pyre at the top. If the Pyre loses all health, your run is over and you lose. If you can survive all the fights and defeat the final boss, you win.

Each game will involve cards from two of the demonic clans, which give a good variety of mechanics that will play the game substantially differently. One of the two clans will also give you a champion, a very powerful unit that starts each fight in your hand.

This is a well crafted game that takes the formula that Slay the Spire put together and iterates on it in several ways. Earning access to more cards and relics as you go keeps you coming back for more, and the variety of the various clan combinations does a lot to keep the game fresh

I typically don't write reviews, but after 1400 hours of playing this game, I feel compelled to say something about Monster Train. This game perfectly fits my personality and play-style: I am a control freak who wants to build the perfect deck and destroy my enemies DECISIVELY. Monster Train usually let's you do this (especially in the lower difficulty levels). This is because there are things that the game ALWAYS allows you to do at specific points in the game: remove cards, increase card draw, reduce card cost, etc. I can usually get my deck down to just the (very powerful) cards I want and have them drawn each turn. The game also has a fixed number of levels with some bosses visible to you from the beginning. So after playing a couple dozen times, you get a sense of the game's rhythm and can start to think several steps ahead.

Compare this to STS which has many different paths, no guaranteed upgrades, unknown bosses, and lots of randomness. Sure it's quite satisfying when you get that amazing run, but for me, I play this game as a stress reliever and a release (i.e. I want the satisfaction of WINNING and winning OVERWHELMINGLY). I really don't mind win streaks that are hundreds of games long. The thing is, even though I can reliably win runs in Monster Train, it ALWAYS feels like a fresh and unique accomplishment each time. And I am always finding new, game-breaking combos even after a thousand hours. And even though it's obviously designed this way, it always feels like the combo was truly a bug in the code and something that I "discovered."

And on that note about game-breaking combos. I think the funnest part of the game is the clan-synergizing (sorry, can't think of a better term). In each run, you choose two clans, where each clan has their own specialties. The game-breaking aspect comes when you take the specialty of one clan and magnify it with the specialty of the other. For example, one clan helps you draw many, many cards while another clan increases your attack and damage every time you play a card. Or one clan benefits from summoning and killing units, while another clan resurrects killed units and upgrades them.

The last thing I'll say is that the devs know exactly what makes this game good. Case in point: the DLC, the Last Divinity. This DLC adds a whole lot of gasoline to the fire: it gives you EVEN MORE control over your units and cards; allowing you to create even more absurd decks (with mega units, overpowered spells) to fight even more difficult enemies. All that said, if you're like me and would like to micromanage your way to the perfect deck, there really is no other option.

Three rows of brutal demon vs angel combat. The deckbuilding layer is comprehensive and lends itself to interesting inter-faction combos and some solid long-term decision making. The strategic side is tight and well-designed, with crisp animations of your demons crushing their angelic enemies (hopefully). The overmap is well-designed: you can see ahead of you an infinite amount so if you're into planning (I am not) then you can map out your every move. All of your rewards are randomized, so typically you really just need to pick left or right path, and you gain the three little perks of that side. 

It ties together seamlessly, and I want to have a special HUGE SHOUTOUT to the world design team and the writers. The world is always in the background, told through flavor text on enemies, artifacts, and items. Most things, really. Everybody's got a little backstory, and it ties together beautifully. The world feels alive and vibrant in a way that you don't often see in video games. The Melting Remnant is my favorite- a faction of candle-folks who melt away and are reborn again. The cards depict a society that's rough but hopeful, equal parts oppressed and oppressive. 

Anyways, it's a hell of a game. My gaming time is tight and I love games that let me get right to the good stuff, and this is that. There's a lot of game here. You should check it out.

[b]Short version:[/b]   Very similar gameplay to Slay the Spire (deckbuilding roguelike) - then added upon to be even better in so many ways.  I love this game.  Go buy it.  Now.  Rawr! 

-----

In Monster Train, you play 30-120 minute games where you build out a deck with creatures and spells to beat up evil birdies that are invading your train... of monsters...  

Every round you choose a main clan with a playable 'champion', and a sub-clan.  Your starting cards (creatures and spells) as well as most cards found along the way will be from these two clans.  The game + DLC (which I highly recommend) offer 6 different clans, each with 2 different champions, for a huuuge variety of possible combinations.  You unlock access to these clans as you play, as well as 25 difficulty levels that greatly increase the challenge - but only gradually, with a very nice difficulty curve due to the single minor hardship added by each  new difficulty.

Everything is (mostly) well balanced and extremely well-polished, with nice graphics, music/sound, and even a fun semi-story that you only discover by reading the battle quips and lore included on every card (TURN ON THE LORE TOOLTIPS.  DO IT NOW!)  The devs have also kept up with patches to fix things that are too out of whack and add even more content.

[b] IMPORTANT TIP:[/b]  For those who hate the idea of investing an hour into building the perfect deck and then losing due to a single mistaken decision, you can even restart a battle by quitting to the main menu and retrying - at higher levels this may be necessary unless you can tolerate a lot of punishment.   Of course, the RNG and deck order is determined at the start of the battle and remains mostly the same when you reload, so you still need to avoid poor life choices as you build and upgrade your deck.   However, this can help you learn the best way to position units, or simply retry a battle when you accidentally play your spells in the wrong order - without losing an hour of progress.   This also allows you to play the higher difficulty levels as sort of a 'strategy-puzzle-rpg', figuring out which placement of units/spells will let you solve a given battle.  (Yes, some people will see this as evil savescumming cheatery, but use it or don't at your own discretion to whatever amount you feel is fair - it's a single player game, so do whatever you find to be fun!)

-----

[b]To summarize:[/b]  This game is nifty.  I like it.  You will too!  Probably.

Story: 2/10 
Similar to slay the spire, there's only a brief overall story-line. However, the encounters feel extra bland to me and there are very limited unique encounters. Thus, repetitions happen a lot quicker and there's less excitement after a few playthroughs.

Character/Art: 6/10 
Monster's trains "monsters" all look fairly generic to me. There isn't a specific character I find that looks incredibly unique. 
If other players ask me what main characters there are, I just have a vague memory of "well there's a red one, then a green one.."and so forth. The same goes for bosses where there is a lack of uniqueness and I never found myself immersed or shocked by one of their designs.

Gameplay: 9/10 
This is obviously the most important of them all. There is great balance in this deck-building game providing a lot of variety. You can mix and match the starting synergies you would like as well.

Once you get into it, by it I mean: get used to the gameplay, mechanics, memorize the Races, the overall deck builds, spells, combinations, shop items, artifacts; then you will be overwhelmed by the insane amount of the replayability. Not only the fact that most run can be totally different, starting from the Champion Card upgrade path right to the overall cards drawn after the mission, but also due to the fact, that there is Covenant system, which changes the game every time you beat it.
Basically, if you want "truly" beat the game, you need to do it with a Covenant system active 25 times, and each time pick the higher Covenant for the run.

Verdict - If you like rogue card games, deck building, replayability, challenges, randomized runs, unpredictable outcomes and fast pace (the average run will take you around 30-40 minutes or less), then it is a definitely a game that you need to play.

There's obviously a lot of good reviews for this game. At the time of writing it's sitting at 96%. And make no mistake, it's a very good game. But if you're reading the reviews you're probably looking for something a bit more informative than "DIS GAME GUD", no?

If that's the case, then let me start off by saying that the only real 'bad' things in this game are:
 - it has this mobile game aesthetic 
 - there really is a lot to learn. The skill ceiling is incredibly high and it takes a very long time to reach it - even though I beat the main game (Covenant 25) I'm 100% sure there's still more for me to learn, and there are expert challenges to boot

There. Now all I'm going to say is good things, but I'll also attempt to dive a little deeper.

[h1]Breaking the game: The Game[/h1]
Obviously, this is a roguelike deckbuilder. What makes this one special is it's 'breakability' and it's relationship to being broken. Let me explain.

Each card can be upgraded twice (thrice in special cases). There are 'low tier upgrades' and 'high tier upgrades' (the latter are, for example, making the monster attack one more time or the spell appearing in your next hand after you've used it, making it possible to cast it every turn). As you can probably imagine, those upgrades when coupled with particular cards can totally 'break' the game. As in, the challenge seems to disappear. You think you're all set. But no, turns out that what was game-breaking up to now, is barely enough for the upcoming part. So you build your deck further: you duplicate the card. Ok, two game breaking cards, this gotta be enough, right? Well, yes. Up until it isn't. And so on.

After you beat the final boss once, you unlock "covenant" - small incrementing increases in difficulty after every win. This is the main progression of the game. You will notice that what you thought OP before is barely cutting it now. You constantly have to be on the lookout for making the best out of your build. "Forcing" a build almost always end in a disaster: you have to keep going with the flow. And the difficulty curve is very pleasant. There's one spike around Cov-19 (heh), but apart from that it always feels fair.

[h1]The music and the lore[/h1]
Music is probably not why you're playing this, but let me just say that this game's music has no business being as good as it is. It's very musically complex, and there's a very nice use of leitmotifs here and there. This is not one of those games where you'll just turn off the music and rock your own playlist.

Now for the more important part: The lore. You're on a train, trying to save the last shard of hellfire from the invading forces of the Winged (think angels). That doesn't mean you're the bad guys - the Winged are shown as ruthless, cunning and traitorous. The hellborne (demons - you) are shown as a very complex bunch of many clans, living in something resembling harmony. But that's not even the lore that I'm talking about.

Every card has its own description, clearly all authored by the same individual. Who are they? The game very nonchalantly ignores such questions, leaving you to think for yourself. The characters - in particular the bosses and your champions - often say stuff. Some of those tidbits throw your entire understanding of the game world into question. Some unique events also can be very revelatory. And most importantly - the game -does not care-. It's all treated as inconsequential chatter. You're just supposed to get your damn train to the final ring of hell. And that's what makes it so appealing.

I can't stress this enough: it's GREAT. It's Dark Souls approach, except taken a step further. And the lore itself is incredibly interesting as well. It's filled with characters and events that have no real appearance in the game, all echoes of history. Or... maybe that's not even true either?

[h1]Endless unlocks[/h1]
To wrap things up: there are so, so many unlocks. There are 5 clans of hell (initially only 2 are available), all of them have their own EXP levels, and every level up you gain new cards, new artifacts, and at level 5 a new champion. You always play as 2 clans at once - one primary and one secondary. That determines what sort of cards and artifacts you can find. That means there's quite a few combinations - 5 clans x 4 secondary = 20 combinations. With the DLC there's a 6th clan, so there's 6 x 5 = 30. (And no, having clan A primary and B secondary is not the same as B primary and A secondary - the balance is different and you play as different champions)

Well, here you go. It really is a no brainer, even if you're not that fond of deckbuilder roguelikes. It's just a damn fine game.

With over 600 hours invested in this game and tons of content still to "achieve", I can honestly say this is my favorite of the rogue-like deck building games. As a huge fan of Slay the Spire, which introduced me to this genre, I didn't have a lot of hope that any game thereafter would give me the same sense of excitement and dedication as it did. That was until I played Monster Train. One of the things I appreciate the most about Monster Train is that there's always something new to explore: some combination of clans, cards, or some other game-breaking combos. I didn't really feel that about Slay the Spire beyond the initial leveling of the 3 main characters (and eventually 4th). Once I gave up on ever defeating the heart (is it even possible?) I never felt like there was anything else out there driving me to continue to play the game. With Monster Train I feel like there is always something to do--some combo to complete, covenant rank to unlock, or expert challenge to beat. All of this is accompanied by a logbook that clearly shows you what you have achieved and what you still need to complete. I love this concept--as a perfectionist in games I really want to see all of it lit up. I never had something like it in Slay the Spire, so the addition of it in Monster Train is really what keeps me coming back game after game. My one criticism of the game is its level of difficulty. I either know that I'm going to lose the game by floor 3 OR I think I have an awesome thing going and then get totally destroyed when I get to the last boss. This is similar to what frustrated me about Slay the Spire's final heart. With no rewards at the higher levels it's sometimes hard not to feel like you just spent an hour+ of your life on something that you had no chance of winning from the beginning, However, Monster Train's logbook has me coming back time and time again and I'm glad it does.
