In comparison to Slay the Spire, this game is much less strategic, but has better graphics, and may feel more satisfying/fun despite its relative shallowness. There's surprisingly few decisions in a run of Monster Train that aren't obvious and little need to consider the odds or take risk/reward gambles. As a simple example, cards taht make you draw will increase your draw for next turn, so you don't need to consider the chances oif what you will draw this turn and if a draw card is worth it.

Further, there are only a few viable builds/archetypes (often just one, with some variations) for each clan pair, which means you know going in roughly what you're shooting for, instead of needing to cobble together a deck along the way, which can make it feel "less RNG". I'm not convinced it's *actually* less RNG once you know what you're doing in each respective game, but Monster Train makes it harder to blame the game for your own failures.

If all that sounds appealing, then go for it. Monster Train's graphics, music, and setting won't dissapoint and there's still some strategy in optimizing your runs for win streaks. You don't have the depth or variety of options that other games in the genre can offer, but that's not always a bad thing. This is a noob-friendly way to get into the genre that still provides challenge.

I came to Monster Train having already played 70 hours of Slay the Spire, so I can't speak to the experience of playing the game if you are new to roguelike card battlers. 
In my opinion, Monster Train is a superb card battler. Instead of a single health pool that you have to zealously guard, you summon units on your train to defend your health pool. Each battle the units reset, allowing you to build up unit combinations to defend against the waves of enemies that threaten you. Instead of locking into a single playstyle when you start a run, you pick two clans (decks) and can develop a strategy with the synergies. Each deck has some really powerful characteristics, so you really get the power fantasy feeling from your first 3 runs, as opposed to StS where it takes like 15 runs to finally feel accomplished.
Biggggg Yeh

[h1] Amazingly fun game with endless replayability! [/h1]

There are 5 clans in total, and for each run, you need to select a primary clan and an allied clan, where the primary clan decides your champion. That gives you 20 clan combinations to choose from. Each clan can be levelled up to lvl 10, with each level unlocking new cards, and when a clan reaches lvl 6, you unlock its exiled champion as well as its exiled starter card. 

For a standard run, there are 25 Covenant Ranks available, which basically decide the difficulty of each run. Each additional Covenant Rank adds a new rule to make the game more difficult, such as giving enemies more health or adding deadweight cards to your deck, and so on. You must win a run on one Covenant Rank in order to unlock the next Covenant Rank. It doesn't matter which clan combination you use, and you are free to replay any unlocked Covenant Rank. The game doesn't force you to play on the highest available Covenant Rank. When you first play the game, you start with Covenant Ranks turned off, and you only unlock Covenant 1 by beating the game for the first time, so technically there are 26 difficulty levels if you count the default difficulty with no Covenants. Beating the game on Covenant 25 will unlock Expert Challenges. It took me 80+ hours just to beat Covenant 25 for the first time, and I've only ever beaten it twice. I haven't even attempted any of the Expert Challenges yet.

Apart from the standard mode, you have 3 challenge modes to choose from: Hell Rush, Daily Challenge and Community Challenges. I've only tried the Daily Challenge, and it's pretty fun playing those randomised challenges with some wacky rules added. Daily Challenges have a fixed difficulty of Covenant 1, so they are fairly easy to beat, but the real challenge comes from trying to get the highest score to top the leaderboard.

All of the above combined results in a game with amazing replayability! You might have noticed that I didn't mention how the gameplay works, but that's because I don't think I can do it justice! All I can say is that it's a turn-based strategy roguelike card battler, and it's fun as hell!

Great game that's easy to learn and hard to master. Gameplay is straightforward and there are plenty of different synergies to explore within and outside of the same factions, cards, and artifacts. If you like roguelites and deckbuilders, this is an easy buy.

I really want to like this game but I really, really don't. You need to scale so much that it rarely feels like my decisions matter in the fights. Fighting all of the enemies feels exactly the same because the answer is always "scale as quickly as possible or get overwhelmed". The only decisions I make that really feel like they matter are deckbuilding decisions, and while it's cool to assemble a strong deck, it got old for me really quickly. I have 100 hours in Slay the Spire and 8 hours in this one, and I have no plans to play it more.

You drive your train toward the center of hell while battling monsters and upgrading your deck. TLDR: If you're considering buying this or Slay the Spire, buy this.

I got into Monster Train on a recommendation and loved it, then got Slay the Spire because hey, it has amazing reviews and it started the deckbuilder/roguelike genre! About half an hour in my jaw had almost hit the floor - I was shocked by how poorly StS compared to this game. It's improved on nearly every basic feature: more exciting items! More character choices! Better turn flow! I credit the StS devs with inventing a new genre, but hey...I'd rather buy the new and improved version than the first stab at the concept.

Monster Train is perfect for strategy gamers and trading card players (I'm a longtime Magic fan). It might be hard to beat the bosses if you don't have much experience with card games specifically, I'm not sure - Slay the Spire might be the better game for new players. But MT has it beat on depth of mechanics and overall quality of life. 

The one major drawback is the lack of boss variety - you ultimately "beat" the game by beating the final boss 25 times, which is a 30+ hour time commitment and starts to feel repetitive (although they add modifiers to the gameplay as you go). I'd really like some sort of built-in Endless Mode or just more boss variety to make for a longer, crazier experience.

Packed full of charm and personality. It's sharp and snappy in a way Slay The Spire never managed to be.

Always exciting because you never quite know if you are going to win until you do because even a single turn or new item can be a huge swing in either direction for or against you.
Slay the spire but you play as the heart

After a fair bit of time with Monster Train, I've got to say I think it's the best iteration on card-based roguelites that I've played (in comparison to Slay the Spire, Griftlands or Roguebook).

The devs put a lot of care into tuning the game, and its managed to keep me engaged for a huge amount of time for the price tag.

The art style feels a little simplistic at times, but the design of the factions and the world do a lot of heavy lifting to make up for it.

With a large number of factions to mix and match (with or without the DLC), there's a lot to sink your teeth into with Monster Train that keeps me coming back for more after similar games wear out their welcome. 

Highly recommended!

The game is divided into character pools where you choose a primary and secondary card pool. 

The major problem is in every blend there tends to be about two directions you can go with your character choice card pool blend; Ex: direct damage magic ramp, or multi hit damage ramp.

It doesn't sound bad put simply, but it is. There are repeat synergies and underwhelming lack of complexities in the cards and their interactions that make success bland. But what is worse is that for the two interactions that will work there are ten that wont to get in the way.

Their poor game play design choosing a short campaign means that you don't have enough time to bend the shape of your deck to one that suits your vision, forcing your to rely heavily on the very few random node rolls and random results to offer you what you need to fit your particular cookie cutter.

Worse is as if in acknowledgment of this games lack of luster the modding community is tiny. I have no idea how it gets reviews as good as it does.

My hours in this were much like opening a giant christmas present to find another box inside each successive box packed in increasingly wet aerosolized dog crap packing peanuts.

Monster Train is an innovative rogue-lite which interestingly combines deck-building and tower defense in a coherent and engaging manner.  Deep, and often subtle, interactivity provides a fertile terrain for mastering synergies.  The system of added run difficulty after each win makes the initial games forgiving to new players, but slowly ramps up the challenge as players master the challenges it presents.

I think many people are gonna compare Slay the Spire against this game while deciding whether to pick this game up or not. My take is that they are different enough to be their own thing, and if you're looking for something different but still having that roguelite deckbuilder experience, then pick this game up.

I found myself actually enjoying this game more because it wasn't as difficult as Slay the Spire to start off with, but I can definitely feel the difficulty creeping up with the "Covenant" levels (this game's version of Ascension). Somehow, the losses just don't feel as bad as the losses I get in StS, and I'm more inclined to jump back into another run.  This is further incentivized with the way you can combine two different clans/factions as well as having a different champions for each of these factions. It makes for a lot of build variety that makes me want to keep playing to try out more builds to beat the run.

All in all, I highly recommend this game.

There are 2 heroes for each 5 classes; choose you primary class which will define your base deck and hero then complete your deck by selecting another secondary class and you get this awesome deck building game. This allows for more deck-building fun than in Slay the Spire which istelf is an excellent game. The pacing is excellent, I don't know how it could get better in fact. Gaming sessions in Monster Train truly feels like "runs" after many tries, you know your deck, you have an idea of what's coming and all you will want to see are the cards that you'll earn and select to complement your deck and discover new or create your favorite combos. There is of course a strong RNG element but you have enough deck customization steps to mitigate this RNG that bring you the element of surprise that is all part of the fun. You can have fun for 5 minutes as you can spend half a day trying to beat the game under selectable challenging conditions with your new favorite deck of choice. Monster Train is a highly enjoyable game that still respects your time. Monster train is hands down, one of the best video game card games I've ever played. It's a perfect blend of risk, reward, luck mitigation and replayability all neatly packaged together in a solid core gameplay loop.

Firstly, the game offers a lot of different combinations. You pick your main deck which has a powerful, free and scaling champion unit you get at the start of every combat. You then pick a secondary faction which opens up a roster of card and game play mechanics exclusive to them such as unit upgrades, card upgrades and artifacts to augment your abilities. Your goal is to find syngeries and abuse the hell out of them. In the base game, there's 5 factions (an extra sixth is included in the dlc), and all the factions have an alternate side which replace the starting card and champion. Furthermore, the champion units themselves have 3 different paths to upgrade as you progress. Admittedly, some of these are more niche, less viable and ultimately less reliable than others which becomes more apparent as you scale difficulty. Although, this only mildly undermines just how much the game gives you to play with in terms of content.

The general gameplay loop is you pick one of two paths before each combat, get stronger and then fight. What makes this so crucial is that the game gives you near complete information of what rewards you'll get in the future. At any time you can scroll further down the map to see what your options are, including the kind of flavour the end boss is and what his mechanics are. There are some fixed reward types and general flow to each run and unlike slay the spire, there is absolutely no negative events to worry about. You feel completely in control of your decisions and most of your failures will be your own rather than at the mercy of the game. Certain rewards can also be skipped and will give you some gold to use as compensation such as cards and artifacts. Even better is that the game generously gives multiple draw pick 1 reward types so you always get strong choices to make.

Before each combat you get the choice to add an additional modifier to your fight to get extra goodies. The DLC also adds shards which you can take to get more rewards at the cost of fighting randomly buffed enemies depending on many shards you've willingly taken on. Most of my failed runs are out of making bad calls without consulting what information the game was giving me OR by biting off way more than I could chew. This is what makes the game so immensely fun.

Combat is fairly simple. You control 3 levels and a core level. You plonk down dudes to defend and play cards to buff or kill foes. Enemies pop in the bottom floor and will ascend a level after each round of fighting until they die or reach the core. Once you take too much core damage, you lose. After you end your turn, your enemies attack FIRST then you. You'll need to make clever use of your units and cards to either mitigate the attrition or plan around it. After some rounds of combat you'll fight a boss who will make his way to the core and the cycle repeats. The game will tell you who dies and damage before you end the turn so you know how badly you're losing or well you're winning so you can better make decisions.

Finally, after a successful run you'll unlock a new covenant level up to the max of 25. These add additional handicaps to keep the game challenging as you push through to new heights. The first covenant in particular adds random cards to your deck from your factions as a way to incentivise you trying them out or making a strategy with those draws in mind.

Monster train is hands down the most cleverly designed card games. It's addictive, challenging and all the while makes it so most losses will boil down to you rather than bad RNG. You can't ask for much better than this. Even if the main game gets tiresome, there's the daily challenge and mutators to make runs more wacky. An absolute gem packed full of content.

Yeah, this game is pretty good, I like it.

The comparison to StS is inevitable, so let's get it out of the way: as a fan of both, this game feels a lot more... dense, which is not to say it's harder (I haven't reached covenant 25 but ascension 20 in StS is pretty hard), but while the base systems feel similar, StS is a lot more streamlined. Where StS has one shop, Monster Train has three. Where StS has 4 room types, MT has.. 7? 8? Something like that. Where StS has 3 classes/unique deck pools, MT has 6, and every run combines two of them, and has a unique champion on top of it. Whereas StS has your main character fight enemies, MT has you engaging in this tower defense mini game with a lot of interesting positioning elements... You get the point. This leads to a game that just feels like "a lot".

Personally I prefer the simpler, more stripped down style of StS (not to say it is a simple game, StS has A LOT of content), but this game and its complexity has a certain charm, and works surprisingly well. The decks feel orthogonal enough in unique ways, that combining them feels interesting and good and allows ridiculous combos and makes you want to try all of them, while forcing the player to adapt to the cards offered. The champions feel really good, they're often strong enough to allow you to create a strategy around them, while not completely eclipsing your other cards. Overall I feel this game must have been a heck to balance but it just feels really good, when you get a good deck going you feel really powerful but the enemies still feel potent and close to overwhelming you.

In the end, I like this game a lot and feel all its moving parts work surprisingly well together. I would recommend to fans of the genre and people who like somewhat dense games that you can dive really deep into.

The deck-building strategy and overall aesthetic of Monster Train call to mind Slay the Spire in a favorable way. Comparatively, at least at the default level, Monster Train is a much easier game. Path choices are a straightforward dichotomy each time (although the choices between the two have more different consequences so are sometimes a difficulty call). More to the point. I have played dozens of runs of Monster Train and lost only a handful of times, whereas with Slay the Spire I'm pretty sure I've lost the majority of the runs I've attempted. That being said, this perhaps makes Monster Train a more favorable game for relative beginners in this genre (or someone you want to introduce to the genre).

What stands out to me about Monster Train, though, is the customization options for your play experience. The many different factions with different playstyles are interesting, especially since you combine two strategies for any one run, with different "Champion" options which in turn have different ability tree choices, but also different build style options even within one particular pairing. This is far wider variety than the 4 classes of Slay the Spire even considering the distinct build styles you can pursue within each of those classes. You can also increase the difficulty of any particular encounter in exchange for greater rewards. And like Slay the Spire you can "ascend" the overall difficulty. I'm sure there are other options that I'm forgetting as well.

This review centers on a comparison with Slay the Spire, but that's a compliment. Although overall I would say StS ranks higher among my favorite games, Monster Train is a worthy member of the family and a game I anticipate continuing to play around with for quite some time and seems likely to earn a "favorite" status long-term as well.

This is everything a roguelike should be. Extremely simple mechanics. The tutorial is almost non-existent. You learn everything you need to learn from a single initial run with almost no training rails. The simplicity is both beautiful and deceptive, simultaneously allowing you to feel challenged, while still providing enough strength and variation to allow the crafting of some 'broken' strategies. The balance of risk and reward is perfect. You never feel cheated or frustrated by a loss. I want to write something more detailed, but I think that the best way to properly represent the enjoyment you get from this game, is to review it with the same core simplicity that is borne out in it's playstyle.

Sometimes frustrating due to RNG going entirely wrong for you in a particular run to the point of being unwinnable, but one of the greatest joys comes from salvaging a bad run by adapting your tactics to whatever RNG threw at you even if it forces you to play in a horribly sub-optimal fashion. Definitely in the style of/inspired by Slay the Spire, but I would say this is a significantly more enjoyable game, and it is certainly one I've sunk more hours into playing.

The only problem I've had is that the more you ramp up the difficulty, the more likely it is that your success hinges less on your tactics/knowledge of the game and more on RNG giving you the cards you need to succeed(or even just drawing your cards in the right order). There is always an element of player tactics and knowledge, but after beating Covenant 25 I can say it often felt like my success or failure was 30% me and 70% RNG at the highest difficulties.

Wow! This is the game that puts all essentials from other deck builders together. In a very good way. I tried a lot of rougelike games "Slay the Spire", "Darkest Dungeon", "Banners of Ruin"... you name it... They are all good, but not as good as this one. 
"Monster Train" is not too hard to beat, but not too easy either. The idea and the graphics are amazing.
The concept is a tower (in this case train) defense with deck building. The use of different races give lots of opportunities and card combinations. You always use 2 of the 5 (with DLC 6) races.
You can raise the difficulty by doing challenges or by ascending in the covenant path.
I love this game, but I would say 20 bucks is a bit too much. I bought it for half the price on sale.

Easily one of the best deckbuilder roguelikes, so many different builds to go with 5(6 with dlc) clans to play with 10(12 with dlc) heroes to choose from, every run is different enough for it to be fun everytime.

I avoided this initially due to the complexity of the multiple floors, but it's everything I like about Slay the Spire, just a bit more fair - you know more about what your run will be like from the beginning - including which final boss you will face - and you can start embracing deck strategies earlier on as a result. This makes the whole game feel more strategic. The addition of clans adds a magic the gathering vibe to the game as well, with some cool metrics associated with it.

While I "won" on my second playthrough, it's clear that mastery of this game takes an intense investment, but it's a great and fun journey with each run taking around an hour or so.

Excellent deckbuilder, definitely the best I've played.  Didn't think anything would ever replace Slay The Spire as my go-to quick play game, but this is it!

This game is a LOT of fun.  It's an appropriate recommendation if you like Slay the Spire, but it plays VERY differently.

It still has PLENTY of challenge if that last sentence made you worry, as not only are your opportunities to get cards more limited, but the level of your train AND the front-middle-back placing of your units can make or break a boss encounter.

There are so many different possibilities given how you can mix clans.  The clans you choose even influence what relics you can get AND what unit upgrades you can get (besides the pool of "Clanless" general units and upgrades.  Each of the major bosses have 3-4 different abilities they can have, and you can even increase the difficulty of each encounter between bosses for more rewards.

I do think there are some cards in the game that need to be refined because they aren't very good (in MY opinion), and it'd be nice if you could have a completely hybrid Champion (there are 3 possible upgrade trees for each Champion, and you can only have 3 ranks in one, or a 2/1 or 1/2 split between two different trees), but there's already just SO MUCH POSSIBILITY.

I REALLY REALLY hope there's more DLC in the works, although I'll have to update this review after I've bought the first DLC.

Monster Train is an incredibly fun and sometimes challenging roguelike card game, where player assembles a deck to beat powerful opponents as the game progress. While it is not as technical as Slay the Spire, Monster Train is more liberal for players to pursue and discover different strategies, card combinations and clan combinations, which adds tons of freshness to the game. While some clan combinations are significantly stronger than others, the game is still quite balanced and you should be able to finish a game with any clan combination. Overall, this game is definitely worth playing and I am sure you can find a lot of fun in it, regardless of whether you are just a casual player or trying to play at the top level.

I have not yet tried out the DLC as I heard there are certain balance issues surrounding the last boss TLD, but I will certainly give it a try if the developers can eventually fix on it.

Looks may be deceiving. At first I thought this was some kind of cash grab mobile game, after all, there seems to be a wave of idle monster training mobile games coming to PC that's unreal.

But, this is a Card Game about a Hellish Train, riding on a railroad to re-ignite the Hell Pyre. The art style is unique and well done, the game is roguelike, just like Slay the Spire and I'm inclined to say, I've had more fun with this game than with Slay the Spire for a main reasons:

- The replayability is super well made, with the starting cards being random and with so many clans to choose from, you have a huge number of combinations that will keep you entertained for a long time.

The clans are super charming and feel very unique, I'm having a blast trying stuff out in the daily challenges as well as the community challenges.

I may only have 4 hours of playtime as of now, but usually card games bore the hell out of me way earlier than that and I have no intentions of stop playing Monster Train any time soon.

Overall, it's a hidden gemstone amongst card games. 10/10
Anyone who likes turn based card games would be foolish to pass this up!

When I first got this game I thought it was so awesome. The mechanics are fun, the races amusingly different from each other.. However, I think that one of the best indicators of a good game is that it gets more fun as it gets more difficult. This game fails that test in a rather epic fashion. 

Firstly, the decks seem to get worse the more cards that you get. The increasing number of cards means that you never seem to get the right combination of cards that were already present in the starter deck. It is very frustrating that you cannot curate your deck. I feel I should feel stronger with better cards, not weaker!

Secondly, difficulty mechanic is pretty bad. It simply adds more difficult 'facets' as you progress without adding any new mechanics. So as your deck gets worse, the game gets harder until it feels more frustrating than fun.

 Finally, the wormkin expansion deck just seems worse than almost any other race. It's just disappointing. Certain mechanics can be powerful, but they require such specific cards so that it most often just falls on its face. 

All in all, I had a great 50 hrs on this game, a frustrating 19 hours trying to relive the glory days, and sadly I can't see myself playing this anymore.

Monster Train brings something new to the roguelite card battlers. Everything has a purpose and everything feels like it was designed to be effective. There are very few cards that you look at and go "maybe if I get this one trinket/card/upgrade this will be good" and that is how a card battler should be. The only concern I have is how pigeon-held you are into certain strategies but there is enough variety that it doesn't get too wrote.

This is such an interesting spin on the whole roguelite card game thing. Being a whole team of monsters instead of just one character makes it play differently, (hello, ablative Stewards, your sacrifice will definitely be forgotten) and the progress through the covenants and the unlocks of the various tribes- each with a handful of gimmicks and mechanics- is very satisfying. My only complaint is that maybe multiattack is a *little* bit cheesey, especially if you can stack it with Quick (makes your monster attack before the angels boarding your train) and it will easily carry you throughout the game if you know how to build around it.

But let's be honest, we play these kinds of games to pull off OP combos and wombo-combo bosses to death. It's like Hearthstone's adventure mode- the aim of the balance isn't competitive, but rather to be fun.

This game is superb! It is a roguelite deckbuilder, which means you start a run with a set of weak cards and get new cards or upgrade your existing cards during the run. Each run takes approximately an hour if you take your time and make it all the way through. 

The game's most compelling feature is the focus on choice - after each battle you get several opportunities to modify your deck. You'll be given a random set of upgrades or cards to choose from, but your choices determine which sets of upgrades you might get. The execution is really smooth though, it is even better than it sounds.

The only real negative is that the DLC is quite unbalanced, with the new clan being by far the worst, the difficulty too high, and the balance being pretty far off the mark. If you stick to the base game, though, you're in for a real treat! There is a whole lot of replayability, with tons of possible combinations of heroes and clans to choose from before you even begin a run, growing into a new experience each time.

Runs are diverse, as you can select a main clan and a sub clan that will alter what cards you have and what champion you will have.  Clans are diverse and figuring out the synergy between clans is fun and rewarding.  

As you progress and play a clan you will level it up, giving you access to more cards and artifacts.

Overall a great deckbuilding game.  Highly recommended.

I definitely experienced an enjoyment curve with this game. I had a lot of fun discovering synergies across the different groups of monsters, there's wild variety between and within the groups, and you can run into some really interesting interactions with enemies. That said, in my experience, skill can only carry you so far. 

As with Slay the Spire, you can eventually hit an RNG wall that means you're going to repeat runs ad nauseum because you didn't get some artifact you need or you didn't pull one of the cards required for high damage attacks against the increasingly difficult bosses. Certain groups, eg the stygian guard, tend to develop more slowly than others, and have trouble keeping up with the curve of the enemies. It sucks to stomp the first encounters and then get completely dominated by the last one, then try again, fail, try again, fail, and keep doing that for like 10 hours. 

I'd recommend this game, but I think brace yourself for frustration. I'm putting this down for the same reason I put down Slay the Spire, -RNG- but I really do feel like I got my money's worth out of it.

My hours are not reflective of in game time, over 30 hours at the time of this review. Let me tell you about Monster Train. I am not a roguelite player. I am not in to deck building. I don't know what made me try out this game but I'm sure glad I did. Forget these reviewers that say "Who wants to play the same game over and over again?" It's not! Every run I've done so far has been new and challenging. Every time you click you are making a decision with consequences. Most of those consequences you will feel the weight of at some point. 

Keep passing up a card because it doesn't appeal to you? Pick it! Pick it and watch how you play the game change. My first round with Morsel Units...abysmal. My third round with them....one of the best runs I've ever had. 

Kicking Fel's ass never fails to satisfy me. I love the sound design in this game. There are moments when all seems lost and you throw a hail mary out there in hopes of doing something useful and it changes the entire course of the round. Sometimes when I sit down to play I have a run that is exploding with artifacts that either help or hinder me. Sometimes I have runs where I barely pick up any artifacts at all and I have to really rely on numbers and strategy to succeed. I love the choosing which side of the rails to visit after each battle. Need a little pyre health? Or risk the health to go shopping and beef up your warriors? Good stuff. 

Play for hours or pick it up for short periods of time. 

I haven't even tapped into covenant features, mutators or challenges yet so there are whole parts of this game waiting for me if I ever tire of standard runs.

It's kind of like StS but also with monster cards and a nice card upgrade system. It's a little easier than StS but still poses a nice challenge. I think the increased ease comes from increased control over your deck, with more opportunities to purge cards, a super handy card-duplicate event, and the versatile upgrades.

The completionist screen is the most glorious panoply of unlockable and achievable doodads I have ever seen.
Deck building AND a rogue-like?  Sign me up!  Very very fun game.  Don't have any gripes after only 22 hours in.  I'm hooked.

Following much in the footsteps Slay the Spire, Monster Train continues to evolve the Roguelite + Card Battle mixture.  Like StS you follow a path of somewhat your own selection (in the vein of FTL) selecting what way along a map (or in this case rail) you want to go, you can see more though in Monster Train what awaits you than in Slay the Spire as far as which fork in the road will lead to a shop to increase your spells vs. increase your monsters, however there is still choices to be made and you can still pick the wrong route.

Also Monster Train adds a neat twist of giving you three levels two defend and (at least as far as what I saw during my hour and a half play time) seven waves of mobs to fight against, each with different twist on them.   Some may half you buffs and debuffs, some you may have to kill a particular mob to avoid multistrike and so on.   All in all it adds more tactical depth than StS to some extent.

I can't believe I waited so long to try the game out.  I purchased it a while back but it has been sitting in my backlog and I finally got around to trying it and I am glad I did.  I didn't have any game breaking errors, however for some reason on the opening cinematic it went laggy and I thought it was going to lock up.  I didn't close out and retry and had no further problems past that graphical or otherwise so I think it was just a fluke.   I was on a machine with a 1060 GTX 3GB with up to date GeForce drivers at the time.      

Anyway, otherwise the game was a blast and I look forward to playing more of it.   This is the type of game like Slay the Spire that I would enjoy  playing on my Switch so I hope they port it like Slay the Spire got ported as I would certainly pick it up again for that system as well.

I got this game on sale and I was instantly interested by the fact it was a roguelike deck-builder just like Slay the Spire, but with a twist. Now it has an element of tower defense which it handles amazingly well!

First, the story. Hell has frozen over and you are tasked with saving it by delivering the last spark via a pyre crystal inside the Monster Train. It's not gonna be easy, as the forces of heaven are trying to stop you from reaching your destination. Different factions of Hell are coming together to assist you, can you save Hell?

The gameplay looks complicated, but is really simple to grasp. There are five factions to choose from (but you start off with 2), each with their own champions. You choose 2 per run, a main faction, and supporting faction. This changes your starting deck of cards that consist of units, spells, buffs, etc. With each stop you can use acquired gold to upgrade units, spells, your champion (every few stations), and more. There are branching pathways you have to decide from to give your deck varying advantages (or disadvantages). 

Combat is fun as you have 3 floors you have to defend. Enemies come in from the bottom floor, and work their way up one floor at a time each turn. You have to place your units carefully and stop the enemy from destroying the pyre. Each faction plays differently which adds soooo much fun to the gameplay. One is all about brute strength, another is about healing and sustaining hits, the other is about casting spells, and the last two are super unique! One is about using these tiny throwaway units that are used to be consumed by your other units to make them stronger, and the last faction gives you strong units who burn away after a set amount of turns. Each faction also has two different champions, with different upgrade trees that you can mix and match. Needless to say, the combinations are plentiful and makes for very fun and varied runs!
If this seems overwhelming, do not worry. The game does an excellent job of slowly introducing new cards to you as you keep playing. The first few runs will seem nearly impossible to beat, but as you keep playing and unlocking new units, spells, artifacts, etc., you'll start beating back the forces of heaven with new vigor!

Feel like the game is getting too easy and want a challenge? No worries, you can take on special challenges with each stage, there are challenge modes to play, and you can compare your stats with you friends and others on the leaderboards!

Gripes with the game? I have none. Even when I lose runs, I find myself having a great time and eagerly waiting to try the run again. Heck, I'm at the point where I choose random and just work with whatever the game gives me just because it's fun to challenge myself and see how far I can make it.

Final verdict? If you want a strategic deck-building game or if you liked Slay the Spire, then you NEED to play this game. It's so addictive and fun that I can't put it down. There is even a DLC faction that adds a new spin on everything (but I suggest waiting til you unlock more things before tackling that). So stop reading this, and get on the train to save Hell! Thanks for reading!

[h1] 100% Monster Train Review [/h1]

Game was a complete blast to play, and enjoyed many and many hours in this, from trying to master every card, to finding out how some team comps work and play. A lot of the achievements are easy to get and many guides to help you get some of the more harder or RNG reliant ones with a pre-made map and letting you know how to run it. I love this game - SO MUCH, so this recommendation comes with a warning. 

IF YOU ARE EPILEPTIC (LIKE I AM), DO NOT GET OR PLAY THIS GAME, no other game has ever fucked with my epilepsy like this one does and I have over 1000 hours on Warframe logged, idunno if it's just how this game is animated or whatever, but after like an hour of playing this game, I get shakey as hell. 

With that out of the way... *Ahem* 

This game is fucking amazing, it takes what Slay the Spire does and improves on it 10 fold by mixing in some hearthstone elements, and there is a level of depth to this game I cannot reach due to limited ability to play such a game, do yourselves a favour and dive deep into this game, it's definitely going to be worth it.

Monster Train is a special game. It channels everything players love about deckbuilders into a slick and polished experience. I am constantly blown away by the design of this game. So many cool and interesting mechanics that feel like something I haven't seen before, and that totally just gel with the rule set. This game makes you feel like a badass, it does not shy away from making the player overpowered. From the ground up, it's clear that Monster Train was designed to allow the player to break the game, and it's just a hell of a good time. 

Monster Train is a game that lets the player be creative. Yes, you are pushed into certain directions depending on the RNG, but I feel like in each and every run I can build in multiple directions and the upgrade systems allow for immense player agency and creativity in the deckbuilding process. You aren't just making do with what you happened to find, you are BUILDING something with the tools at your disposal. I love this.

The card design is super fun; I continuously unlock new cards and exclaim "wow! That is awesome. I can't wait to try that with x or y in another run." The sheer variety in the game is INSANE. The enemy encounters are fun. The lore and flavor is very enjoyable. The music and sound is on point. It feels great to play cards and navigate the UI.

I just can't say enough good things about this game... I love it.
One of the best rogue lite card battlers around. Lots of fun.
yeh love it
Similar to slay the spire if you have already played it. but it does enough different to be an easy recommend, very fun game.

[h1] How to Train your Monsters [/h1]

This review has been a long time coming.

Monster Train is a game about the last denizens of Hell travelling to the source of the heat. Citizens of Heaven are attempting to stop them by any means necessary, and (With the recent addition of The Last Divinity), it created a time loop where the same thing repeats over and over again. It's up to you to help your chosen clan fight through Heaven's Finest, picking up creatures and critters along the way to assist you in that task.

What kind of playstyle do you prefer? Do you prefer the hyper-aggressive style of the Hellhorned, Devils and Imp with Armour and Rage? Do you enjoy being a tactical healer, the Wildwood being your bread and butter with healing and regen? Would you much rather a tactical onslaught with your spells? In that case, you should pick the Water-Bound Stygian, who have Incant and Frostbite to build units up over time or push the enemies towards their graves. Would you rather a virtual army of buffs and stat gain? Snag yourself the Umbra, who focus around the Morsels and Constructs of the mines. If you'd enjoy a go at a fast-paced, all-around power, then the Melting Remnants have your back- From the slums of Dregs to the Vanity of the rich, they all focus around Burnout and how to counter it. Or, if you want to play with fire and enjoy watching it burn, the Wurmkin are fit to the nines with Inspire and Etch and Crystals abound.

It's up to you how you want to play, and it's up to you who joins your train. There's a fair amount of dicerolling involved, but when it slots together just right and you get that victory, it never gets old- it's like a rush of dopamine, directly to the system. You deserve to feel that victory, because you worked to earn it.

Which brings us to why I've played Monster Train for so long. As of writing, I am 171 hours in with all achievements- however, I am NOWHERE near finished with the game, about 50% of the way in. A game like Monster Train has Slay the Spire in its blood, but enough differences to make it feel unique and fresh. So many units, so many cards assigned to each clan, as well as many events and modifiers that can keep you playing for a long, long time.

And it never gets dull. That's something I was worried about- I was worried that around Covenant 10 (The game's version of levels of difficulty), I was going to get sick of repeating the same thing over and over, but that simply never came up. Sure, I got frustrated. I lost several times in a row, would rage quit, come back to it in a week; not to mention the new final boss is COMPLETE ASS in difficulty scaling, but besides all of that, I never broke with the game and stopped enjoying it.

So yes, I highly recommend the game. I think that for it's price, it's better than most triple A games. Just be aware that this game will eat away at you until all you can see are the train wheels spinning.

However, a few weeks ago I decided to give it another chance and after a couple of hours I was hooked. Climbing the covenant ranks and unlocking the new factions is great. The game is basically a rip-off of Slay the Spire, but despite that, it's actually a pretty fun deck-builder and I rather enjoy it as it did add a lot of original gameplay mechanics. It's all about optimising the power of a few cards through custom enhancements that you acquire over the course of a run. The power gap between an un-upgraded card and an upgraded card is enormous, so a thin deck is essential. It plays a lot like a tower defense, where enemies will run a gauntlet through your monsters and spells trying to rush towards your train's heart to destroy it. It's a good game for people who are into tower defense or deckbuilders, basically.

This is a very fun roguelite/like type game in the same sub-genre as Slay the Spire. The demon factions and their card sets are distinct and flavorful, and it's a nice feature that you can ally with one of them each run and thus have multiple possible card-type combinations to draw on each run.

The music is good too, but what really appeals to me is the animations. ESPECIALLY of the angel bosses and sub-bosses. The effects of their mana wings, and movements are well-done and the auras of light around their bodies or from their wings feels dramatic and powerful. Like they are literally oozing or gushing out light which contrasts with their obvious flaws and how it's inferred many are fallen angels (like the clipped) and that their actions may have disrupted the natural order and balance.

It's a challenging game, but it has lots of replayability as there are lots of cards and artifacts and so on to reveal and discover and unlock via multiple runs.

This game has great production value, lots of factions and cards to discover and just lots of variety of combinations and a nice, vocalized soundtrack. It's very addictive and fun though very challenging once attempting to clear higher tiers of runs.

 If I had a complaint it would be that there is not much incentive to try the "pvp" mode which is really just a race vs other players against the ai. Multiplayer really needs a boost of some sort - Maybe some co-op or rewards that break away from the main concept in an interesting and/or fun way.

 I bought the Divinity expansion and it really opens the game up a bit but also forces me to play segregated from those who don't have the expansion unless I de-activate the expansion. The purchasable faction offers more variety while not really giving me an unbalanced advantage so why can I not flex my pretty Wyrmkin in general population? It's a small complaint though.

All in all, hours and hours of fun, gameplay and discovery and I'm glad I plunked down the change for such a well made project. (The artwork is pretty amazing too)

Still addicting to play even now and the Divinity just upped the end game even more. Still needs a few tweaks here and there, but the DLC did offer some nice improvements to the game, even if it also introduced a few problem areas. Overall, I've gotten more than my money's worth out of it, and I'll probably be playing it for many more months to come.

Pros:
1. Quirky, friendly vibrant artstyle.
2. New spin on the roguelite tower defence genre, 3 lanes (floors) to manage and defend but keeps it incredibly simplistic.
3. This game has a lot of charm, great freedom of choice and a massive selection of cards.
4. Customisable playstyle, no run is ever the same and multiple Monster Factions (Clans) to choose from.
5. All aboard, Choo choo!

Cons:
1. There is no story line to the game just pure gameplay.
2. The gameplay loop felt a tiny bit slow, there is always the setup period before things start happening.
3. A lot of the cards can be quite useless compared to others, some balancing issues and tweaks needed.
4. I was not as addicted to this as I have been other card game roguelites.

Overall:
Monster train was a treat to playthrough as every faction, they all play vastly different from each other in terms of mechanics. I just felt it wasn't as addictive as it should have been and I can't quite place my finger on what was missing. 
All in all great game and worth playing if this genre is your thing.

This was a delight, an impressively addictive mix of tower defense, roguelike and deckbuilding.  There's definite balance stories where certain champions are VASTLY better than others (requiring less things to come together or just practically carrying their side by themselves) but they're all playable and there's nice mixtures.

The constant randomness is both a joy and at the same time can make late cov25 play feel like it has a 20% up/down based on if the dice like you.  A variety of champions or setups have aligned artifacts that are significant force multipliers for them, so there's definitely a level of fishing for them.  Getting the wrong third tier enchantment showing up can also considerably sway the flow of a run.   It lends to skill and awareness of the options (what do you do with bad hands or when not to take challenges) but there's absolutely an unevenness between runs at the same difficulty.

Playing the Imp Queen?  Well this run we won't spawn any high rarity Imps and you'll run into quick or multistrike.  Playing a heavy hitter?  How about endless regularly?  Totally happens.  Still quite fun and causes for creative problem solving but means there can be massive difficulty shifts going on too.
Great game, high replay value indeed. Well balanced.

My wife hated slay the spire. She loves this. I also like it better than slay, mainly because of the more-conventional artwork, and relatable monsters. Although you can see similarities to slay in every element of the game, the differences are much more significant, and stretch the similarities thin, almost to the point of simple homage, and no longer just "copying the game". The content here is deep, DO buy the expansion. The difficulty level is radical, and will have you saying WTF over and over till you suddenly "get it", and beat that boss like a bad imp. Highly recommended!

At first I thought this was another game going on the hype of Slay the Spire. Well, it does but it certainly does its own thing to warrant your attention.

To make it simple:
[list]
    [*]Fun from the very first run and it only gets better as you unlock more cards and clans
    [*]Some clans are certainly straightforward but I was surprised how diverse the later ones you unlock are. They are fun as hell and allow you to have a very diverse gameplay since you can combine clans in your runs.
    [*]The game is easy at first. Very easy in my opinion but you can do runs that keep getting progressively more challening.
    [*]The random events you find are fun.
    [*]The moving train remind me of the movie Snowpiercer!
    [*]The music is really something else. It really does bring each run up a notch.
    [*]Since you only need a mouse to play and there's no need reaction needed, it's good to play to relax, listen to your own  music or podcast and it is easy to come back to it at any time.
[/list]

Overall [b]Monster Train[/b] is very fun. As of right now it is among my favorites alongside [b]Slay the Spire[/b] and [b]One Step From Eden[/b] and if you are even slightly interested, give it a chance and I bet you won't regret it.

One of the top card games on Steam. Games does a great job of revealing new content at a brisk pace without being overwhelming.  Varied game play through different factions, each faction having two classes. Play as the hard hitting Hellborned, the regenerative thorny Awoken, the magical and frosty Stygian Guard, the ravenous and gluttonous Umbra or the waxy and ephemeral Melting Remnant. Hell has frozen over, let's thaw it out.

Game is well executed, challenging, and offers 'speed chess' style competitive game play, daily challenges, as well as the ability to challenge others based on your first run of a seed.  I have not yet picked up the expansion so I can't speak much to it yet. Design your own run and challenge others.

If you like rogue-like deck builders, give this one a shot.

Scoring mechanic leaves a little to be desired. Opt in for all the hard stuff, beat the boss on the first endless wave, and save your coin and you get a high score. It is not how I would have implemented scoring but its simple and effective.  Some factions have an unbalanced advantage via score due to their cash generating options.

On a scale of 0-10, with a 5 being recommend buy and you'll get minimum 1 Hour/$ spent, this one is a solid 8. (Shout out to Schmug Marfman for the price metric).

Bonus points for being walk away capable for the primary game mode.  Those of you gamer parents or low key gamers that can't devote 1-2 hours non stop attention will be pleased with this style of game play. It can be quite addictive though.  Stats are very well executed, comparing you to your Steam Friends.

In Monster Train, you're in charge of guarding a moving fortress, protecting the pyre at the top which carries hell's final hope at reigniting! Big time fans of Slay The Spire, Griftlands, etc. will find this is similar in the "build a deck, do a few battles, unlock more stuff" sequence. 

This one, though, moves at a MUCH quicker pace - you want to decide your core play style, i.e. spells vs creatures, early on, and build for it hard. There are relics you can acquire that will alter your playstyle, and your creatures & spells can be upgraded twice (more, with relics). Focus on upgrading a few key creatures and keeping them alive. Creatures enter the train at the bottom and travel up 3 floors before hitting the pyre, and you want to kill them before they reach the pyre so it can safely reach the depths of hell. 

I definitely see myself putting a ton more hours into this, it's scratches that same itch the the aforementioned games do - trying new builds, taking a crack at old favorites, and nailing 5head plays.

The only thing I would add are some more bosses over time, as I think I have seen them all all ready. This is not to say I have been able to beat them after figuring out what they do, though. There is a pretty good difficulty scale after your first victory.

EDIT: After having this game for a year and putting in another 65hrs, my stance has not changed at all. This is a phenominal example of the roguelike deckbuilder genre.

First of all, props to anybody who reads Dante's Inferno and immediately thinks "ooh, this should be roguelite! with a train!".  :)  

Okay, on to gameplay. Like most folks here say, if you like Slay the Spire, you'll probably like this. I like it better, because the art style works more for me, plus there's a train. The logbook, granular difficulty levels, and wealth of achievements don't hurt either. My only critique is that it would be nice if there were a way to access the backstory in written form (see below about intro vid).

Game runs well in Steamplay (Mint 20, Nvidia proprietary), except that the opening vid doesn't play. You get a black screen, which you click on and then the game loads.

Literally the best Rougelite ever created and the most Original too! I have played this game time and time again since the free beta/demo (i still paid full price for the game on launch.) Even if i don't have the most hours, i always come back, always. the replay-ability is the some of best i've ever seen

If you like Slay the Spire you will like Monster Train

Update:
Well I have 500+ hours clocked now. This game has gotten only better. The last divinity DLC adds a whole new layer to the strategy.

Really though, the most fun is competing in the daily challenges.
This game has renowned actor Samuel L. Jackson doing all the voices, you have to get all the monsters off the motherfuc*in train.

It starts very nice, with great possibilities to actually build your deck, unlike Slay the spire which is more like a slot machine with cards than an actual "deckbuilder" game.
So I go on playing, and I finally beat the last boss and,.... That's it? I get a score recap screen and I am invited to play on the next level (or "covenant rank").
Okay....Whatever, I keep playing because I'm thinking, maybe there are hidden bosses or narrative rewards, so let's see....

It starts a bit too easy if you're familiar with StS, and although it automatically upgrades you to the next difficulty on every win, you feel like you're always running ahead in the first alliance rounds. That is until you reach a wall of difficulty because on every new difficulty the games just keeps upping the enemies' health and damage, giving you handicaps, and putting so much garbage cards into your deck that toward the end you have little more strategy than turning your deck into a machine gun of low-quality spells.

You can feel tempted to try to specialize in one strategy and try to refine it, but out of the 8 leaders the base game offers, there is one that makes the game very easy with a 75% win rate, and the seven other are extremely difficult to bring to victory after a certain level of difficulty.

As much as I dislike StS, I have to recognize it's pretty smart in the mechanics department, the enemies offer many challenging problems to solve and your own cards can offer you (when RNGeesus allows it) a lot of different tactics to overcome.
Here sadly, it's just a game of numbers, you mostly buff your allies and debuff the enemy on every round, and you spend alot of time doing mental arithmetics to the point where it can become a bit tedious.
The enemy systematically puts tank enemies on the front line with huge health and armor, and hides the big hitters and buffing units on the back line with low health but huge damage.
Some enemy units or bosses will stop your run dead in its tracks if you are unlucky enough to have them appear (like that very hard to kill last boss assistant, which reduce all your mana to zero on every turn).

The core gameplay of MT is a tower defense game, and most of the time it feels more like you're playing tower defense with randomized units than a deckbuilder game. There is something very repetitive and boring about it. Just big numbers against big numbers.
Every level plays like a round with every unit attacking in turn and is resolved at the end with the ascension of the surviving enemies to the higher floor.

I REALLY don't like the grind you have to do to unlock every card and artifact. It was acceptable in StS because it was very short. Here, it took me about 60 hours to unlock all the cards and artifacts of the game, which prevented me from deploying some strategies because the cards were hidden.

The graphics are okay, but I don't know why they decided to make parts of the level in 3D. It doesn't look as good as if it was all 2D.
The music is very nice, but a bit too present at times and I found myself muting it.

In conclusion, it manages to be even more autistic and unfun than StS, which is some kind of achievement....

[h1](follow my curator page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33882793/]GenXPlayers[/url] for more retro and indie reviews)[/h1]
It's a good game, you should play it.
A variant on the success of StS that is both fresh and holds its own. Well worth the asking price for content and I find it to be very enjoyable.

In my current list of games, there are none that can casually suck up a few hours than this one.  It is perfect for when I have a few moments to spare.  I can dip in and out.  That said, it is genuinely engaging, and even though formulaic in many ways, always seems to offer enough variation that I don't feel I'm doing the same thing over and over.  I enjoy the idea of trying a different theme of run each time, and the varying factions, and individual strategies within each faction do a great job of this.  I would very much recommend and look forward to more DLC in the future.
I simply loved the mechanics, and how quickly I was able to learn the game, while the strategy was still outright great, and many times still hard.

Solid card game that feels very polished. The ability to mix and match the different clans gives it a lot of replay value. Base game is great and the DLC is a good expansion on it. There is a lot of variety and multiple viable ways to play the different champions and clans along with a lot of depth and choices regarding the different difficulty scaling options throughout each run.

A couple hundred hours later after my initial extremely positive review, I'd recommend Monster Train MORE heavily than I initially did, if anything. It's overtaken Slay the Spire as my favourite deckbuilder, Enter the Gungeon as my favourite roguelite (by a very slim margin, granted), and comfortably nestled itself near the top of the list of my favourite games of all time. It's not perfect, but it's not far off it. Can't recommend this game highly enough.

Why I prefer Monster Train to Slay the Spire or other deckbuilders: you usually can can salvage runs even if you don't get the best cards/artifacts. Makes every run feel different, compared to StS where it often feels like if a certain boss appears or if you don't get the right artifacts for your deck the entire run was a waste. My biggest problem with the last three clans is it feels like you have to build your entire deck around them, whereas the first three clans could mix and match gameplans a bit easier.

It's better than Slay The Spire. It's also different enough - More fun, quicker feeling games, more experimentation and less risk, and I'd expect to put at least another 35 hours in before I even consider myself ready for something different. The power up/buffs are varied and enjoyable to play with and every new formation changes up the game just enough. Heartily recommend.

I really like deckbuilders and also really like rogue-likes.  I wish I could say something great about this game, but I can't really.  I even bought the DLC after playing it for 4-5 hours to see if it added any significant changes.  It does make it better in some ways, but the gameplay loop is still incredibly unsatisfying.  As soon as you start to put together something decent in terms of monster and deck composition, the run ends and you have to start over.  A lot of the cards in the game and keywords are identical copies of things I've already done in Slay the Spire, which did it better.  The animations take so long sometimes that you have to turn up the speed or wait literal minutes watching animations to play out that you already know the result of.  The bosses are basically the same every time without any unique or interesting mechanics and the random events that happen seem to be selected from a small list of about half a dozen.

A decent roguelike deckbuilder card battler game in the genre. Not quite as complex as Slay the Spire and does not require trial and error like most roquelike games to forehand knowledge of what to be expecting so you don't get absolutely rekt out of nowhere for not knowing.

The game has 25 challenge difficulties with handicaps you can increasingly climb to with a successful run on a highest challenge level you've unlocked. On the most part the game is fun until either you grow tired of it or if you're like me feel salty I lose certain runs because the RNG elements didn't offer me the opportunity to draft the necessary pieces of cards to win a run. 

To elaborate further to win a successful run in this game: You need basically to meet 3 conditions:
1) Enough damage output from  your units to kill enemy tanks fast enough
2) Someway to deal direct damage or AOE damage to consistently get rid of Glass Cannon units in the enemies back line behind their tank
3) Some method of consistently tanking the damage output  from the aforementioned enemy Glass Cannon units if you can't kill them before they attack your units.

The basics of the game is you choose a primary clan and secondary clan and throughout the run you draft cards and artifacts (passive items with support effects) predominantly from the the clans chosen. Unfortunately the synergy between certain clans don't work as well and so RNG can determine your successful your run can be. Of course you can always just continuously do runs with only the 2 clans of your choice that synergize well...but what is the fun in that?

8/10. A solid game but RNG elements can still ruin your day.

PS: Some of the cards and Champions abilities could use quality of balancing update. (buffing)

Very fun game, it really helped me get over my emptiness after playing Slay the Spire. You can mix and build lots of different strategies, playing in random is not even boring since you find out different possibilities. If you use your brain you can make OP builds too! I really enjoy playing it

A blend of Slay the spire and Hearthstone with a bunch of new mechanics on top. Not a fan of the art style but the gameplay is top notch. Cards and factions are interesting and fairly balanced. With the well thought out progression system and difficulty scaling, there is a ton of replayability.

If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, you might enjoy this.

Unlike Slay the Spire, you do not play as "your character". Instead, think of all the characters as minions, and yourself as the "Boss". If your minions do not stop the enemies ascend through 3 floors, the enemies then attack you directly and damage you. 

Every faction offers different minions, spells, and mechanics. 
Some focus on healing and buffing, others on giving your minions temporary health (Armour) and damage, others focus on using LOTS of throw-away minions that they can remake again and again, and those minions grow stronger with every remake. 

The spells are a nice advance from Slay the Spire. You have the standard fare of damage dealing, healing, buffing, and debuffing cards, you have cards that have strong effects but require you discard cards, you have cards that affect your minions and the enemy minions, there's an evne that lets you build your own card from a selection, and there's cards that grow permanently (as in during that run, not between runs), as well as cards you can only play in specific floors, albeit there's only 1 or 2 of those. Overall, a very good selecton of effects, and quite a few that allow you to really strategize your turn.

Without the DLC, the base game has, basically, NG+25, as every successful run unlocks a new difficulty, with different effects. Up to Level 25. the DLC adds a new, tough endboss, a new mechanic, and new cards, as well as a whole new faction to play as.

I whole-heartedly recommend it. 

The game is very stable (for me, I have not had a single crash or freeze in all my hours). I did have two instances of the game not reacting for a few seconds, but I cannot reproduce those.

The difficulty curve is smooth, the factions you play as are all very interesting, the learning curve is not too steep, but you will repeatedly find yourself thinking "Hmm, I wonder if this combination works" and it will work more often than not. Cards are well-explained and tooltips are precise. All mechanics work well together

The translation seems good, but I cannot say much about it, as I usually play my games in english.

I bought this game not really knowing what to expect. I was weary because it was a deck-builder but it turned out to be a really fun game, which left me saying "Okay, one more run", until I lost track of time.

It's challenging, but not to the point where it's unbeatable, or annoying. 
7/10.

This is a very fun deck building game with an interesting twist. I really enjoy building your units up and make busted combos when pairing up two different clans.

Definitely my favourite rogue-like card game. The sheer number of decks that you can come up with even between the same two clans selected multiple times over ensures amazing replayability. Combined with the fact that there are now 6 clans to pick from, each with two champions that greatly alter your playstyle, makes it very hard to say that you're always going to be finding something new to try out.

I never thought I would find a better deckbuilding rogue-like than Slay the Spire but then I discovered Monster Train.

I [b]love[/b] this game. From the gameplay to the crazy synergies to the visual design. Everything in this game amazes me.

So what is Monster Train about? As I wrote above, it's a deckbuilding rogue-like. This means you start with a weak starter deck and during your run you add different cards to the deck that make it stronger. The runs are always randomized and you never know what kind of cards or enemies you will get and the idea is to make the best out of what the game gives you.
In monster Train you don't have a single character but instead have to defend a train from boarding enemies. You summon units on one of three floors and cast spells on either your units or the enemies. Each round a wave of enemies spawns on the lowest floor, you get a chance to play your cards and once you end the round, the enemies will attack, then your units attack, then the enemies will move up one floor. This repeats until you win or loose the fight. To win you have to kill all waves but the last wave contains a strong boss which attacks until every unit is dead. You loose if you cannot defeat the enemies and they reach and destroy the pyre room which reprents your health bar.
Each run has exactly 8 battles with 3 being major boss battles which have fixed bosses with different variant types. The finbal boss has 4 different variants and during the start of the run the game will tell you what type of variant he will be so you can build your deck around it.

Cards in monster train have two different upgrade slots which can be filled with upgrades bought in shops. Spells and units have each their own unique upgrades. Spells can cost less energy to play, monsters generally get stat improvements. 
During your run you will stop at different rings and each ring has a selection of two routes, each with its own rewards. This way you can decide if you want to take healing, meet a shop, remove cards from your deck and more. Additionally you always get gold and card rewards for beaten battles.

A special card in your deck is your champion which is the closet thing to represent your character in this game. The champion is a super powerful unit that has better stats than most units and unique abilities. Champions can be upgraded at the start of the run and after the first two major bosses with one of three different upgrade paths. These all fit into different strategies and can synergize greatly with your deck.

Monster Train features 5 different clans which determine what cards you can find during the run. You can select two different clans for your run, the first clan you take also decides what Champion you get. If you start the game, you will have to unlock three of the five clans. The other two, Hellhorned and Awoken, are beginner friendly and help  new players to get a good understanding of the game. They are also less specific in their type of strategies and gimmicks.
Hellhorned are generally strong units with high attack or high armor for protection. They are the most straightforward clan, having both attackers and tanks and even some damage spells. They can summon imps, small and weak units, that provide different summon effects.
Awoken are mainly tanks and healers. They have super toughj tanks with a lot of HP and these tanks activate abilities if they are healed.
Stygian, for most the first unlocked clan, are spellcasters. Hhey have the most damaging spells in the game and have both high instant damage and damage over time. Their units also get buffs when you activate spells.
Umbra summon small units, that are eaten by other units to give them better stats and buffs. They also come with damage shields and lifesteal and are overall good in protecting your units.
Melting remnant on the other hand does not care for death in your ranks. Their units are disposable and meant to die. They can revive and improve your units but in return those units have a short lifespan. Some of their units activate effects only when they die.

Experimenting with the clans and finding out how they play together is part of the charme of the game. For players who like many different combinations that you can try out this is a very welcome sight. Each clan also has its own set of artifacts which will also improveyour playstyle and makes up for crazy strategies. Melting Remnant has an artifact that gives +10 damage to units when they die, Awoken has a unit with 3 attacks. Let this unit die over and over and revive it again and again and suddenly you have a unit with 90 attack damage and 3 attacks. You can be even crazier and use another units who auto-revives cards for you when it dies and give them 40 extra attack. That way you can create a loop of dying and buffing.

This is just the tip of the iceberg and I could go on how great the synergies in this game are. Best way to find this out is play for yourself which is why you shoudl get this game.
You will get a lot of hours into the game, just winning with every clan bombination can take you a long time. Not to mention that the game features 25 difficulty ranks. These ranks are designed that they increase the difficulty over time so you get better and understand better what combinations work well tgether.
I also think this is one of the best balanced games. Every card has its own value even if it does not look like it at first. Of course there are always cards that have more value than others but I actually think there is no useless card in the game that I would never pick.

Also, I love the soundtrack of this game. It fits the game perfectly. When I played Slay the Spire, I found myself to deactivate the soundtrack because I foudn it distracting. In this game I always play with the music enabled.

Hell yeah, one of the most fun and addictive single player card game.

This game is much more forgiving than Slay the Spire for beginners. There are 25 levels of difficulty and each of them is just slightly harder than the previous. This system allows us to try new things and still have a chance at winning the run. Build diversity is also another strong advantage of this game as there are 5 base clans (6 with DLC) and we have to combine 2 clans making 30 clan combos. Highly recommend this game for anyone new to the roguelike card battler genre. Slay the spire is also a good one but it is much harder and the run tend to be way longer too

Absolutely fantastic. It's like Slay the Spire had a baby with a Tower Defense game and Magic: The Gathering. Everything works. The game has a huge skill ceiling which can be chipped away at deliberately.

The pacing is on point. Sessions last exactly as long as they're welcome. It rains upgrades, delicious little decisions, and then you're back in the battle machine. Content unlocks at the right pace, and there's a huge amount of it. The five clans (six with DLC) are similar to the elemental colors of MTG and each have their own well-realized tricks.

The balance is in a great place. As the difficulty gets higher, the game intentionally, deliberately becomes more and more about finding something to exploit, and doing so scratches that itch every lover of this kind of strategy chases across genres. The disgusting combos are real and they are glorious.

This is a large, top-shelf strategy game at a reasonable price, without cash shop nonsense (literally the only thing I dislike is the awful mobile-game library banner). It's such a safe recommendation. What are you doing still reading this. You could be playing Monster Train.

You know the game is TERRIBLE when you finish it 6 times in 12 hours with very little new content per run (new unbalanced cards ???) and each new "run" is supposed to be more difficult but the last 2 runs you literally pressed "End Turn" at the beginning of the FINAL BOSS FIGHT because it was going to be dead by the end of the turn EVEN IF YOU DON'T PLAY A SINGLE CARD -- "because numbers".

This game require no skill. Just fill up floors with units with good defense in front and good attack in the back. Other than that, "stack stuff". That's pretty much it.

Try Hadean Tactics or Vault of the Void instead. Unless you haven't played StS yet, of course ;)

I very rarely rate any game, in fact i rarely even play on steam. I usually play MMOs but sometimes, i try something new and i am happy i did. I have not much experience in neither Roguelikes nor Card games. I played some Darkest Dungeon before, but thats about. Oh well i finished For the King once. 

However, this game really got me. I love it and i hope that there will be more DLCs coming. I have yet to buy the DLC and i will, but i am still trying to complete every possible combination at rank 25 etc etc and i have a lot of fun. Every run feels different, every "Class" feels different. The devs really put in so many different mechanics and those mechanics mix up pretty darn good with others.

I also love that it just takes about an hour to finish one round so it is nice to just hop in and play 1 round or 2... or maybe 10 lol. I cant stop it and this happens rarely to me. I have spent 60 hrs by now which at least for me, is pretty solid for 1 week. As i said, every run feels different, lots of things you can try and work towards, long time motivation and it is not too punishing. I mean not punishing at all cause you just lose maybe 1 hr of a run and than you start over again. 

So yeah, i didnt enjoy a game like this since ehm, i played Mutant Year Zero, which ofc you cant compare because it is a different genre but i am having a blast. So please Devs, i read the DLC is awesome as well and i am excited, hopefully you continue on this game with more good content. Worth every penny and got more than enough out of my money, thank you

The most addicting deck-builder i've ever played. I've played Slay the Spire before and I could confidently say I personally like Monster Train a lot more.

> Gameplay - 9/10 - perfectly encapsulates the 'easy to learn, hard to master' gameplay. The deck-building process feels very organic and rewarding.
> Replayability - 10/10 - every run feels very very different even though I've been using the same deck and champion for more than 90% of my runs. Very impressive.
> Presentation - 9/10 - their cover art personally was the thing holding me back but once you enter the game itself everything is top notch. UI, card art, battle presentation; all of these fells very polishedd and "alive". This keeps me saying 'one more run' over and over again.
> Performance - 9/10 - very fast on my average PC (Dell Inspiron 7559)

This game is excellent. One part deck builder, one part tower defense, one part roguelike. Very similar to Slay the Spire but I found this game much more enjoyable. It's faster and I feel I have far greater control over managing my deck of cards. Combos and wacky synergies are a blast to find. Writing this review after about 50 hours in the game and about 2 hours with the DLC. The DLC feels light on content but it adds a much better difficulty scaling feature. The covenant system is kinda lame with how it just keeps adding useless cards or adding health/damage to enemies but it's inclusion is necessary as the game's difficulty at lower levels becomes trivial once you know what the cards are. These are minor gripes though, overall the game is a blast and purchasing the DLC was an easy decision considering how much mileage I had already gotten out of the game.
