Monster Train is a fun game. It's a roguelike deckbuilder, but the thing that distinguishes it from other games of its ilk is its approach to crazy combos. Where most games like it give the sense that the designers put together a playtest draft and then adjusted the rules on any card that proved too powerful, I get the sense that after they finished the playtest version, the designers of this game buffed or removed the cards people found useless and then set the difficulty appropriately for the assumption that you'd get getting up to some kind of game-breaking shenanigans.

Great Rogue deck builder, fast paced and with an whole lot a replayability. Clan system is excellent to change up your playthroughs and make runs very distinct from each other. Great game, highly recommend it!
Great game.

This is a review for the game as it is after the Last Divinity DLC.

So, there's not a lot of deckbuilding Roguelike games out there but with this latest update this is basically the best one. Also, if you are a fan of more turn based games where you can mull over your decisions, this is the best one of those with a roguelike bent (not even sure if that's a thing). The amount of new decisions added in this latest expansion increase what was already a deep game to upper tiers of deep thought you don't always see in solo card games.

With 6 factions and now a second final (optional) boss and new ways to upgrade your run, even the same starting point will be drastically different from the last end point you reached last time with that same configuration.

Simply put, this is a great game that the reviews aren't BS'ing you on. It may look less exciting when you watch streamers play it but only in the same way that watching someone read a book isn't anywhere near as interesting as reading it yourself.
It's a game that is as challenging as a player wants it to be. For the Hard-Core Gamers it can be and is as punishing as they could want. But also fun and easy going for casuals like me.
Very addicting and runs are usually always unique!

What can I say? It's great. No long review needed. A lot of diversity, cool art style, cool combat, lots of replayability ... you can easily sink 100s of hours into this if you want to. And one run is only about 1 hour. A highly tactical and yet easy to get into game with an enormous amount of unlocks and things to achieve.

Last Divinity DLC is also more than worth the asking price, adding one whole new clan (2 champions), as well as a completely new gameplay mechanic, a completely new "secret" boss, as well as new enemies, new cards, new events and new artifacts of course.

In the vein of Slay the Spire, about as addictive, and actually has more replayability since there are more decks (6 including the DLC as opposed to 4 in STS) and also you are able to choose a primary and secondary deck for each run, so there are many different combinations you can try.  

Has the standard roguelike pros and cons--sometimes you get bad RNG and it feels like you wasted time, sometimes you get amazing RNG and you essentially break the game, but in any case you still sway the outcome with each decision you make.  One thing I like about this game is that artifacts you obtain are incredibly powerful, and since you get one at the start of every run they can often times give you a good direction to move towards in crafting your deck from the very beginning.
Great deck building rogue-lite. A true rival to Slay the Spire.

Heres the deal. The game is fun, a lot of fun infact. Only problem is it doesn't work anymore. Tried to verify integrity of files, reinstalled the game entirlely and scoured fourms for how to fix it. In case you don't allready know this game is known to have the black screen on launch issue. It has always been a problem and affects some users more aggresivly than others. I was preaty lucky to not have any techniqual issues until now where it flat out refuses to run anymore no matter what i do.

So take it from me. Don't purchase this game if you value your money not being taken from you for shoddy products that don't actually do the bare minimum of whats expected and you know actually work.

Edit: this review will stay up unless this company's lackluster customer service finally decides to listen and fix the issue.

Edit 2.0: game works now. If you have any issues with black screen of death unsubscribe from all your mods. They are causing the game to be unstable and a lot of others have had similer issues. Their customer service still sucks though so just don't expect any help from them if you run into any issues.

Fun & different take on the roguelike/deckbuilder genre. 
The 5 (6 with DLC) clans each have pretty distinct mechanics, and the secondary champions for each clan open up even more build options.

This game keeps me saying "Just one more run" whether I win or lose. There are so many ways to mix and match the different factions, and even within a single faction there are different viable builds, so much that pretty much any run can be winnable as long as you make the right decisions along the way and manage your risks vs. rewards.

There are some things that I absolutely love about this game compared to others of similar genre that might get overlooked by some reviewers.  One is the logbook and the sheer amount of collectibles.  Once you get the gist of the game, it shouldn't take you that long to eventually beat your first run, but the game doesn't really end there as you are unlocking new difficulty levels (called covenants) and leveling up your factions to unlock more cards. And the cards you win a run with now get a Mastered card backing, and there are other achievements that unlock additional card backings.  The logbook is beautiful and is loaded with your stats and everything you've seen and mastered, and for game completionists it's a dream come true, and there is a LOT to unlock.

Next is the multiplayer aspects, which really doesn't need to exist at all but I'm glad it does.  Hell rush is fun speedrun mode where you compete with other players to see who can get the highest score, or just survive, though recently it's been difficult to get games populated to enjoy it sometimes.  But the daily runs are also done with the same multiplayer aspect where you can see everyone else who is playing at the same time as you.  It's honestly pointless but I just think it's cool and makes it feel less lonely I guess.

The game's a blast and I think I'll be playing this a little bit every day trying to fill out my logbook.

A very fun and interesting rogue lite based on deck building and turn based strategy. Very well made with interesting cards and interactions. Makes you want to replay the game not for meaningless tedious progression, but for trying out different combinations and builds. The game is also flexible and lets you experiment with different builds, cards, abilities and heroes without making you get frustrated at the RNG. Monster Train is also simple and easy to learn, but its simple mechanics cascade and add complexity giving players room for improvement and mastery by learning different cards and their interactions. I highly recommend the game, especially if you're a sucker for card games and/or roguelites.

After playing this game a bit and progressing through the game a bit, I can say that it doesn't have the depth of other turn based strategy games in this category. While you can certainly influence the game by placing your units in different ways on the levels decks and the decisions you make about which cards to keep and play in your run are very important, if you don't get the right drops of items, units or special effects throughout the run, it will be very difficult for you. I know this feature is present in many other games, but in this game it feels heavily present and effectual. Each run just feels like a lottery, hoping for the right items or drops. If you don't get them, it will very hard for you and  perhaps no fun for you (or less). If you do get them, you will steam roll to victory and the margin for error will be so high. It can be a bit boring that way. You know if you get the right items, it will be easy. Or that if you don't it will be hard and a grind. There is no mystery to the run. I don't feel like I can pull myself up by my bootstraps and make a bad run good. I just feel like if it is bad, it is bad, if it is good, it is good. There isn't a lot of complexity there to the game

While I get that that art of this game is good and they have put effort into the class system, ultimately it feels a bit 2 dimensional, especially compared to some in the genre. Once you understand how each champion works, whether you will win the run just depends on what items you get in the run. You can't turn a good run bad, or a bad run good. Or at least, it is very difficult to do so. You will either be having a party on round 2 cause you are steamrolling your enemies without any effort on your behalf, or you will be sweating away round by round, hoping not too much damage gets done to your pyre in that one..
beautifully done game. The devs have a great relationship with the community and are constantly reacting to feedback which is one of the best things you can ask for.

The game is addictive and fun to play. But there is one tragic flaw with this game, and the reason for my negative review: the randomness of the cards being dealt will be the reason you lose a run nine times out of ten. You won't lose because you did something wrong that you can learn from, you will lose because the game isn't giving you the cards you need. For instance, with the first hand of the battle, you should be given mostly units, but most of the time you'll be dealt your champion and maybe one other unit, along with some other cards you don't yet need. Well, if in the first round of battle the enemies outnumber the two units you were dealt, you can most likely say goodbye to your champion right off the bat, greatly reducing your chances of winning that battle -- or at least, your pyre keeping much of its health before winning that battle. Also, I can't count how many times I needed a card to replenish a unit's health to only be dealt a health card after the unit dies. 

As I said before, it's addictive and fun and I do appreciate the art style. The game does have its redeeming qualities, and I think anyone who plays it will enjoy it, but I can't give it a positive review as anyone who plays it will also find a lot of frustration.

However, as I began experimenting with combinations and floor setups starting with the first run, I quickly realized the depth Monster Train offers to each battle. Due to the aforementioned light card library, more opportunities to draft and purge the cards I want, and the triple floor train that allows units to have a large effect even if I don't draw them off the bat, Monster Train offers itself to strategy over RNG better than other deckbuilders I have played.

Short looping games with escalating difficulty only work when they are about player skill, whereas watching an avatar grow stronger is only satisfying when it's a single long journey/story. Monster Train, though, like many such games, quickly ends and restarts with escalated difficulty but immediately undermines this by strengthening my deck too. Instead of me or at least a character experiencing progress, the one "getting better" at the game is the game itself--a faceless deck locked in a short loop. So, [i]nobody[/i] is going [i]anywhere[/i] in this game's design philosophy. It's a quagmire. Monster Train is faulty on the foundational level.

Where to start, where to start:
I was one of the  people that played Slay the Spire and thought "Man i love the game, and i would love it even more if it was not as dense as it is" , if you are in a very similar situation, congratulations, you may enjoy this game, i'm not 100% sure, but you know, at least i think that way, the game still gives a couple of kick square in the Nuts, so you better prepare some extra ice.
Lets start complaining:

-Seraph the patient: almost all my problems begin and end with this absolute unit of RNG curses, it will come a time when you are used to go full "RNGesus is my lord and savior." and you will only ask to not have your run halted by it's presence, he is just so much more tedious to figth compared to any other enemy in the game, he is the only seraph that attacks your units when you are building you "army", he is the only one wich true penalty is still in effect when you start the final wave, he is the only one that complatly changes the way you buld you deck, so yeah he is not fun, you could say that i writed this entire review just to say f*ck him, anyways.

-The cards as a whole feel over-balanced; that can be either a positive or a negative depending in what kind of person you are, to me there is nothing really explosive about the way combos work in this game, combos in on themseselves are non-existent, instead we have synergies, and you know, in a mostly sigle player game that is kinda boring in my humble opinion.

-The game as a whole feels completely explored, each clan highligths a system of the game and thus you find your favorite synergy rather quick, i personally dont feel like is anything else to explore and as any modern deck building game it feels like there is no point in keep playing it; there is not a lot WOW moments after the 20 hour mark it's all primitive pattern finding satisfaction and that may get old fast if you are the kind of person that hates busy work.

As always this is my personal opinnion and you may not see these points as a negative, feel free curse me all you want, nothing new there.

Great deckbuilding rogue-lite that is similar to Slay the Spire with a few noticeable differences.

The runs turn around much faster, averaging around 45 minutes depending on how you play. Because of this, you are less "locked-in" each run and there is less emphasis on building an enormous deck. You also have much more control over what you pick, so you have a lot more flexibility and seemingly mediocre run can turn around rather quickly.

The card types are split into Minions and Spells, and you can choose to emphasize either one or both; the minions offer a huge variety is probably my favorite difference from Slay the Spire. The minions vary widely in terms of their stats and many of them have some unique mechanics that can really change a run.

You have the progression and the deck types, which is probably my favorite part of the game. Each run, you'll choose a Primary faction that gives you one of two heroes to start with as well as the deck you'll draw from. You'll also pick a  Secondary faction from which you will also draw cards. Each faction has two heroes, and each hero has three specializations that will get upgraded along the run. If you've done the math, that's a lot of widely varied playstyles. The faction are also widely different to play at a fundamental level. I won't spoil the fun, but the three unlocked factions are super interesting from a design perspective and dramatically change the way you approach each run.

Overall, this game is a fantastic rogue-lite that is most easily compared to Slay the Spire, but manages to improve on that game and also carve out a niche for itself. If you even slightly enjoyed Slay the Spire or other deckbuilding games for even a moment, buy this game - you won't regret it.

I purchased this game on a whim when it was on sale after hearing good things about it from some youtubers. Since then it has been consuming as there is so much depth and interaction that makes the game unique.

Monster Train is a CCG where you struggle to play anything other than draft fodder to survive while slowly unlocking card and artifact options from finishing runs. At first I was afraid it was too easy because I would frequently get far into the game with little effort and I won my first game after only five runs. Like other Rogue-lites, there's several hurdles of grind you have to jump over to progress because of the difficulty ramping up with every win. Once I unlocked everything for most clans, I blew through difficulty levels with no issue until about Covenant 10, with Covenant 12 filtering me for a few days. 

Unfortunately this game turns from playing a FNM draft to a top tier tournament where you have to run abusive strategies of playing your whole deck in one turn. When you use a non-creature card, it will go into your "discard" pile which gets shuffled into your draw pile if your draw pile is emptied, similar to a non-CCG tabletop card game. This results in easy loops on top of some clans getting access to playing cards removed from the game (the actual discard piles). Tryharding can still be difficult because of the randomized starting cards you are assigned; some bosses are just broken garbage that require very specific strategies to beat which might not be available to you depending on your clan picks. Overall the clans are decently balanced but I feel Hellhorned & Stygian primaries require *very* specific strategies to win with (Stygian especially likes to screw my runs with bad RNG).

Outside of the card game elements, this game is pretty average except for the good soundtrack. Animations are barebones, sound effects sound like library edits, and the graphics (from technical and art style standpoints) look like something from a mobile game. There is technically multiplayer (but I don't think anyone ever cared for it judging by the Steam forum) and you have your typical daily challenges and custom community challenges, but the meat of the game is still climbing difficulties in Standard Runs.

It might sound like I'm really bashing Monster Train but I actually I really enjoyed this game until I got filtered by higher difficulties. I'm looking forward to future patches and DLC bring balancing improvements to certain bosses and the narrower clans with any new content. This is an easy recommend to CCG fans but Rogue-lite fans need to realize this is more of a CCG with harder RNG than a Rogue-lite with cards.

Monster Train is a deck building game that decided, "What if Hell got beaten into a cold slumber, and then a bunch of demons took a train and tried to light everything on fire?", and ran with it. It is un-ironically my favorite deck builder game, period. 

What really sells it for me though is how much it differs from Slay the Spire, an extremely popular deck builder that I don't quite like that much. For example, in Spire you pick a character and the deck you get almost solely relies on their card drops to be built. Monster Train instead lets you pick a faction with it's hero, card etc. BUT THEN, they let you draft another faction to help add more variety to the deck, and even than through random events you can get cards related to other factions you didn't pick for true variety. You can even see the bosses that you will face in the run, to properly be able to build your deck around it, instead of being blindsided by a boss that counters your deck after 40 minutes of playing. *cough* Time Eater *cough*

Seriously though, it's an excellent game in almost every aspect. I won't stay here all day ragging on Slay the Spire and talking this game up. It's seriously good regardless of whether you like deck builders or not. Give it a go.

One of the strongest roguelites I've played in terms of replayability. The unlocks progress in a very satisfying manner for new players, revealing new, more complex mechanics without any sense of grinding or incremental +1's. Each of the clans is very mechanically distinct, and the ability to combine two for each run means there are 20 possible combinations of clans to choose from, and each combination has unique synergies and interactions, which makes for a ton of interesting strategic options. And for long-time players, the Covenant system rewards dedicated fans with incremental increases in difficulty, and the diverse range of mutators and wild daily challenges keep the game reliably fresh.

Monster Train is a deck builder / tower defense that invites comparison to Slay the Spire. This game is less elegant (the numbers are much bigger) but far more mechanically dense (summoned units and limited capacity thereof, multiple floors on which fights play out, activated effects that you'll need to chain together in order to succeed, finer control over your starting conditions). 

This is disorienting if you try to play like in StS (or Dominion or any other deck builder), but not overwhelming, and new mechanics are parceled out at a good pace. With 20 hours, I have most of the major unlocks but plenty of minor ones are still out there, and I'm still encountering new events, artifacts, and cards. 

Most importantly, when the game copy uses gift as a verb, it does so correctly, describing a gift given to a stranger in a hospitality-exchange: https://imgur.com/7PrdiXc

It means so much to me, devs. Thank you.

Monster Train is a unique take on roguelikes as a whole. Having played this game after Slay the Spire, I can say that this game triumphs in many aspects. The soundtrack is beautiful, the strategy element is more complex but not too confusing to comprehend, luck plays less of a factor here, there are just so many categories that this game tops StS.

Starting with combat, each game, you have a train with 4 floors- Three base floors, followed by your Pyre Room (acting as the heart of your run- It's health is your health). The base floors can have units placed on them to defend your Pyre room, and enemy units flood into your train starting with the bottom floor. If they aren't defeated when comparing health and power, they will move up a floor the following turn. Some enemies have abilities like Thorns (deals damage when hurt) and Haste (Skips the second base room when ascending a floor after combat) making strategies require more thinking than just blindly playing cards. On top of these units, each run gives you a set of spell cards that allows you to hurt the enemies, augment your own creatures, draw cards, and heal your allies among many other effects.

Units and spells can be upgraded at the expense of some money you pick up along the way, either boosting their overall power, or giving them a new ability. However, this money can instead be saved in the event that a shop in the future of your current run possesses better items to buy.

Bosses all have random abilities per run, making each playthrough unique. Sometimes you get an enemy that strongly opposes your current strategy, like one of the bosses negating the buffs of your allies. If you played a run that supports buffs, it becomes more difficult, but still doable. 

When playing, you have the choice of five (and counting!) different clans, all with different playstyles and cards that come with them. Each clan has one extra strong unit called a champion, that you upgrade as the run progresses for free. This champion always starts in your opening hand, and provides some more unique elements to deckbuilding. As you play, each clan unlocks an additional champion, which allows you to tap into the different playstyles of each clan. After choosing your main clan, you can select a supporting clan, which you won't get a champion from, but supporting cards in your deck and as the run progresses. Try out unique combinations like Hellhorned and Awakened, to heal your tanky creatures, or Umbra and Awakened to buff your multistrike and quick units, so on and so forth. 

The game provides Artifacts, which are passive buffs that help you in battle, whether they increase your unit capacity per floor or how many cards you can use in a turn. Some encourage unique strategies like playing a bunch of units at once, or playing with higher cost spells at the expense that they have random casting costs.

By far, this game is one of the better deckbuilding roguelikes I have played in a while, the art and music are stunning, and variations per run are very high. There is so much more to this game that I didn't even get to mention, too, so I recommend you give the game a shot and see it for yourself. If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, you will love this game- Try it out, and explore all of the nooks and crannies this game has making it so unique!

If you liked the "oh my god my deck is now broken!!" part of Slay the Spire, this game is for you. It has at this point of time 5 unique factions, each with their own very much distinct playstyle and you get to always mix two of them. The strategies are plentiful and each is very fun to explore.

I don't know - it doesn't really do it for me. I love Slay the Spire, but Monster Train somehow lacks that game's fluidity: perhaps it's the way the battles and the upgrade stages of the game feel like they're separate from one another, so you lose your angel-killin' rhythm; perhaps it's that there are only eight battles per run, so you rarely get the same feeling that you're on a roll.

The variety of the different decks is great, make no mistake: I love the way that they encourage different strategies, and mixing and matching your allies is a brilliant idea. At the same time the baddies can't match this variety: the mooks feel like much of a muchness, while the way the bosses' qualities change from run to run (on some runs reacting to spellcasting, on others reacting to summoning creatures, etc) mean that no single boss has that strong an identity, either visually or in terms of their behaviour.

A lot of people love this game, and there's a lot of work and heart which has gone into (and is still going into) it. Still, for some reason, once I've unlocked all the cards and done a couple of daily challenges I don't find myself coming back to this.

Yeah it's a dang solid game there bud. Not the number one best in the genre of crawly card battlers, but undeniably pretty darn good in pretty much every regard. 

Not a huge fan of the art personally, looks a bit like a mobile game, but it's not bad enough to detract from the experience. Music is fair but doesn't slap. 

The core gameplay loop is very solid, the different factions and keyword mechanics are a ton of fun to mix and match, and every run gives you enough progression to feel rewarded until you're hooked.

So it's like a 7.5, maybe 8/10? A-Tier, not S-Tier, but if you like the genre it's worth the admission fee.

BUT everytime a room loads, if you tab out of the game or sometimes (although this is a very slim chance) on its own the game crashes, but not just crashes, it can fuck up things running on your pc. Youtube only showing the video and everything else being blacked out, other apps having the same issue of being blacked out partialy or entirely making it a drag to navigate through your pc but the worst was one time where my entire screen blacked out and i had to forcefully quit my pc (alt tabbing, opening task manager, escaping, going into sleep mode, all those options failed then).

Never have i experience crashes like this with games so far and i would've given it a positive review if it crashed from time to time but just instantly closes the game in response, but this and the toll it can demand on my pc is too much. I'd like better crash support from the game and a better response to getting stuck, starting with the game terminating itself easier in such occassions instead of straining my other applications.

The save system is solid though, i can just hop in from where i left off if it happens, that's fine.

I love everything about this game. The soundtrack is incredible and I listen to it in my car. I love the artwork and how the cards are animated. I love the cheeky humor, such as the googly eyes achievement. The combat is exciting and tests the limits of your strategy skills. And the lore is so intriguing. I'm one of those people who read through the whole logbook and all of the notes. What an amazing world they built! I hope the add to it, because I have so many unanswered questions. But speculation is part of the fun, I suppose.

I also love how much variance there is. You get two different champions to choose from for each different clan, different options for starting cards, mutators (which I haven't even messed with yet, btw), covenent rankings to add challenge, and so, so much RNG. It never feels like the same game twice. 10/10

I wasn't expecting to love this game but once you get into it, you really get hooked.

I just finished the last main big difficulty spike, Covenant Level 25/25 and have been the game with every class and ally combination - it was a pretty big puzzle! The game coaxes you into it with upgrades that DRASTICALLY change how good your monsters and spells are. Something that is garbage when you pick it up because an unstoppable killing machine after a few well placed upgrades from the shop and before you know it, you start steamrolling over everything in sight because you found the god combo!

That's the thing... the game is DESIGNED around you finding the god combo and that's what makes it great! If you don't find it or the enemies trip you up in a way you don't expect, your perfect set up falls apart and the run is just... over. Pfffft, just like that. Into the later stages of the game, it really starts to feel like a puzzle... every level between bosses has a more difficult mode with better rewards and going from good to great is gauging how much you think you can handle (or sacrifice) to get those extra goodies - I love that. Not to mention there's easy to read branching paths between levels that let you pick how you want to adjust your deck and spend your gold; there's a lot of customization! Is it as break crunching as Slay the Spire? No! I'm glad it's not actually, it makes it a refreshing game to sit down and keep going back to and that's why it's so much fun.

Not to mention, the music for this game? It's actually pretty frickin' good. The art seems a little all over the place, but after seeing the final credits roll and all the people that put in their ideas for neat and interesting monsters... you come to appreciate the love they put into it. I felt good when I saw that final 'Thanks for playing!' message at the end. Thank YOU guys for making it - I had a blast!

Immensely fun and nicely balanced card game in the vain of Slay the Spire - albeit more forgiving. The art style is great and replayability is guaranteed due to the vastly different clan mechanics. Each clan has two heroes to choose from with different mechanics, were the potential of combinations get bonkers is that you also have to choose a sister clan, giving you access to their cards as well during the run. My go to game when I want to relax and casually play a game. Well worth the full price.

This game is alot like Slay the Spire but I like this game alot better. In this game it feels like there are more combinations of factors that can come together for a win. It feels like the resources are more accessible but you still have to make hard strategic choices about how to spend them. The map is also more alive, engaging and every path feels rewarding. To me the emphasis here is more on strategy, tactics, and fun rather than a grind to beat RNG. I also like the gradual progression of difficulty as you complete runs and gain unlocks. The rules were easy to pick up and there is alot of content to look forward to and motivation to keep playing. I didn't stop until I realized I was light headed and starving. That's when you know it's a good one.

It has lots of fun, accessible strategy that doesn't take very long and is very interesting.
It is complex enough to be interesting, but not so much that I feel like I need to research online how to play it better.

WORTH:                   Excellent purchase when priced between 10-17 euros.

PROS:
- Well balanced roguelike.
- Solid gameplay loop.
- Game has reasonable amount of main content.
- Plenty of extra content, like dailies and increasing difficulty with "Covenant Ranks".

CONS:
- Extra content isn't terribly engaging.

[h1] My Personal Opinion [/h1]

[b] Monster Train, Is a fantastic experience and deserves love. [/b]

This game I was on the fence about and honestly I was so pleasantly surprised on how good it was I did not regret a penny I put into it, I am quite picky with games and this one did not let me down. A lot of people compare this to Slay the Spire or Hearthstone and say it is lacking, well these are obviously fan boys or girls of those games that dislike believing that another game can take the stage, Monster Train is well worth the gamble and if you were a fan of those I know you will fall in love with it.

I am not here to show pros and cons, because we all see different pros and cons in games. Stop worrying about whats good and bad about it, buy it and try it. Then make an opinion yourself and write a review based on your personal experience, I did.

It's a great game overall; The graphics are great, no bugs. The gameplay is pretty fun, but it gets stale. You traverse the levels of hell, and it's the same exact path, every time, with a left and right option that determine what you receive for your run. It's got several races to unlock, but after a few runs, you get them all. Replayablity is in the randomization; different starting cards, artifacts, and different events on your journey. The biggest issues are the enemies are limited; every run is the same set of enemies with a slightly randomized ability, and that the end boss is designed to be a hard counter to your clan choices. I'd say buy it on sale, so you can enjoy it when you've got nothing much better to do.

It's like if Slay the Spire decided to make half the bosses depend entirely upon rng instead of game knowledge and personal skill. This game was better on launch back when it was only the stealth boss that made you instantly lose for no reason half the time, but unfortunately the devs thought that was a good way to go with things and made the alternate bosses in line with that one overtuned asshole.

It's still a good game, but if you intend to play in Covenant (it's StS Ascension mode but in this game and goes up to 25) just keep in mind it's a hell of a lot more tedious than STS's Ascension mode. You'll end up needing to restart a lot of runs right at the start just because you got bad cards or two trash artifact choices. Even when you get a good start you'll still fail half your runs just because the game decided to give you bosses you were never going to beat in the first place. If you can deal with that then the runs where the game doesn't cuck the shit out of you are actually quite fun, and the mutators are a good way to spice things up and add replay value.

I went in to get my jimmies tickled by a fun deck builder and left with my jimmy jams being fondled by my demon overlord encouraging me to beat up angels with a hefty stick. 10/10 would beat up angels again. plus i can bring a friend so we can compete on who beats angels to death more stylishly.

Incredibly fun card game, plain and simple.

5 Races with 2 unique champions/starter cards per race. You pick a main and a secondary race. Some have better synergy than others, but winning setups can be made with all the possibilities. 

Starter cards, upgrades, boss fights etc. are all randomly generated with several choices. 

Game has increasing difficulties called "Covenants" which make the game extremely replayable with no two runs being the same.

If you are on the fence, or enjoyed the Slay the Spire franchise, I highly suggest giving it a shot.

This game takes the awesome Slay the Spire deckbuilding formula and in some ways makes it even better. There's less fights, but they're longer and more tactical (mainly due to it being on three lanes). Less decisions of where to go on the map, but more important to decide well. An easy recommendation for anyone who enjoyed Slay the Spire or other deck-building rouge-like games. While it may lack some of Slay the Spire's laser-like focus and expert world building, it makes up for it with its impressive scale and ambitious concept. An engaging and challenging game, there are several unique decks you can build, unlock, and level up. Monster Train's primary conceit is the ability to combine decks, with a primary and a support deck. This makes you consider the traits, cards, and goal of each deck and may completely reinvent how you play one deck when connected to another. This gives the game a greater deal of replayability and depth when compared to its contemporaries.

Monster Train is another deck building roguelike game, the player's task is to gather a number of cards, of both units and spells and defend the train against enemy onslaughts always led by bosses that clean the train floor by floor until they strike at the pyre, the player's heart.

When we talk about Monster Train it is inevitable to draw comparisons to Slay the Spire, so first and foremost, we can draw a few differences between them.

-StP is based around a single character with different moves and artefacts, meanwhile MT works around units and positions.
-StP can sometimes be unforgiving, a mistake can just ruin a run without any way for the player to avoid getting killed in the next combat, on that regard, any combat in MT can be won, even with one hit point left.
-StP has four main characters with a set of builds and possibilities, MT has six clans that always start the run with an allied clan that offers less depth, but more variability.
-StP can have long runs, averageing one hour per run, MT tend to be much shorter, many successful runs can end in 30 minutes with no issue.

Monster train is a game that may look shorter and more shallow, but in return offers much more freedom for the player to experiment, there is rarely a wrong move, even the starting stewards can become very powerful if they're buffed and supported correctly. Especially now, with the option to fuse units, it's extremely hard to get the same run or to get the same gimmick twice, even if you try to imitate a successful strategy, you will only get something similar, and it may not work again.

Music, art and sound effects are charming, all units can be told apart from others.

It has a multiplayer mode, it works like single player, but with a timer, to punish those who take too long, and a score system, to pick a winner.
It also has a challenge mode, that allows players to make runs with conditions, both advantageous and otherwise, once again competing for high scores. Both modes are a nice addition that keeps the game fresh and allows the player to try something different if they got stuck with the main mode.

One of my few complaints is about Seraph, the final boss, and the fact that while there are many versions of it, there is only one design, with a palette swap per version.

In the end this is the kind of game that you start thinking that after 10 hours you will be done with it, only to check the clock and see that you have already spent 30 and you're not even near covenant 25, where the game truly shows its teeth.

Give it a shot, it's worth whatever it costs right now, you will get your money's worth and then some.

I love this game. This game brings innovation IMO. This game is "gameplay-first". Its art style is suitable for the card game. It is not overly "expensive" for the game to potentially keep a good pace of publishing DLCs or any other content which will stress gameplay, not the art part. This game is about good gameplay. 

The difficulty curve is very good in my opinion. The covenant rank difficulty approach is at point. Every clan mechanics has a unique part in it. Mastering a clan takes time. Understanding and mastering each card is a fascinating and interesting process. And this process has different layers of depth. 

About the upgrades when progressing through the rings of hell... At first I thought capacity upgrade is always the way to go. But later I understood the value of other upgrades for different clans and different circumstances. Relics are very meaningful and add a direction to your play or give great support for you.

Balance is striking. This game has little useless cards, relics, units.

What would be great is more enemies. The variety is quite poor. But the difficulty change overrides the lack of new enemy mechanics/combinations. 

It would be great to add a player vs player runs. You build your deck against other player's decks. And race to bring the pyre to ignite hell. I think this is what this game needs in future versions. 

The mods support out of the box and the ability to design new cards and new clans and publish it for the players is amazing! Fascinating opportunity to bring so much gameplay and different mechanics to the world. This game is at the top. Very good game and IMO can cost even more.

The developer studio made a masterpiece. I hope it will keep the game growing, update and expand it. I'm recommending this game.

This game is a fantastic deckbuilder - very similar at first glance to critically acclaimed Slay the Spire. Would absolutely 100% recommend for fans of the genre - don't wait for sale its too good. Having combat over 3+1 floors and having to pick between 2 of 5 decks (major and supporting) allows for a ton of customisation - really fun runs. Of course just like StS there are random events that can massively swing your luck for the better - seems like only positive events unlike StS which had many detrimental ones especially at higher ascension. 

The only criticism I have is that with StS the elites and final bosses all had unique abilities and artwork. 
With Monster Train the mini bosses and final bosses DO come in 3 different variants but the artwork is almost identical so it feels like you are just fighting the same 3 guys every run. Would be nice to see different artworks even if the 3 current variants were the same 

Overall 9.5/10 - minor artwork and a slight card rebalance would make this game complete

Probably the best deck-building game out there. A fair comparison would be Slay the Spire (which is also a good game), and Monster Train does everything better except for maybe the atmosphere. Winning the game on higher difficulties does not require you to get one or more specific "key cards" for your strategy, which means you don't have to rely heavily on RNG to get a good deck.

The challenge is figuring out what strengths or weaknesses your deck has, and if any new cards offered to you will make your deck better or worse. This is a huge improvement from Slay the Spire where picking new cards often was a no-brainer. A big variety of cards/leaders/factions makes the game feel non-grindy even when you struggle to win and restart over and over again.

[h1]Addictive as Hell [/h1]

Monster train is a cardgame/tower defense roguelike that has you defending a pyre atop 3 levels of a moving hellbound locomotive trying to re-ignite a literal frozen-over Hell. You play monsters and spells in synergistic ways do defeat waves of enemies, with the ability to upgrade you spells and units as the run progresses, picking up relics which give various unique effects.

The closest similarity is Slay the Spire, but the game has various differences that make it stand out, I won't go into details about specifics as that requires familiarity with the game but just broad strokes:

[b] Shorter, intense runs:[/b] The runs in this game are quite short compared to most others in the genre, averaging between 20-45 mins, what this means is your deck and options scale fast, meaningful decisions happen early and often.

This encourages multiple playthroughs and definitely has that "just one more" quality. In addition the game informs you of all the main bosses, the end boss and gives a complete map ahead of time, so pausing runs for later is never a problem, just take a look at the map and you can easily figure out what you were building towards

[b] Far less RNG:[/b] The game uses various levels on the train, with enemies starting at the bottom, in addition you always draw your champion who is powerful and consistent at the start of each battle along with any banner(class) units every turn, this leads to runs where variance occurs but you never feel outright screwed because you didn't draw your block in time.

[b] A much better difficulty curve:[/b] The game actually starts out pretty easy, the card variety is far more limited, you can't play the hard factions before unlocking them and there is a lot of discovery and experimentation, which is really fun! It's so easy in the beginning you get to check out the cool bosses and experience a lot with little pressure and it makes unlocking and beating the harder difficulties more rewarding in comparison.

[b] Presentation and flair:[/b] The game has an amazing soundtrack, interesting lore and an abundance of easter eggs and little quirks like any good roguelike, it also has a speed up option and various set speeds, with a logbook that shows your progress in terms of unlocks, wins, cards etc, which is really handy and motivates you to play more. The presentation is excellent which is a welcome surprise because a lot of these mechanics first games have pretty meh aesthetics. 

[b] The faction diversity:[/b] The game has 5 different factions to mix and match with two champions each, when playing you chose a main faction which supplies your champion and a supporting one. This leads to a ton of variety thematically and gameplay wise, covering all the archetypes you would expect such as graveyard synergy, big bois, spellslinger, consuming to grow etc. It also draws out many players to various favorites, which is always a good sign. Playing demons, hellspawn, imps and eldritch horrors is just more fun and interesting than being the good guy like in the majority of games.

At the current price its a steal, tonnes of content, great music, replayability, challenge and with it's excellently paced difficulty curve you can be a complete newbie to this genre or hardened min/maxing theorycrafting veteran and have just as much fun. [spoiler] It also has a skeleton doggo that heals your pyre every turn. [/spoiler]

Edit: So I've put more time into the game, and after reaching Cov25 the game just doesn't really feel balanced at all, doing a random-random run feels like banging your head into a brick wall, there are so many synergies that flat out don't work and the path to victory often involves ignoring half your deck and just focusing on what synergies jump out while removing as many cards as possible. 

I feel like if it wasn't for the upcoming DLC I would honestly give up on the game at this point, although it did give me a good amount of hours it doesn't really live up to games like Slay the Spire etc, the attention to detail regarding balance just isn't there, some classes struggle too much to clear backline and the vast difficulty jump between most Seraphs and The Patient is sort of glaring when you look at it, you can have a perfectly valid strategy but the Patient can kinda just shut it down.

From a pure gameplay design perspective, I think Monster Train is weaker than Slay the Spire. It's loud and flashy, but the game is mostly won at the strategy layer, where it's a game of matching units and spells to the upgrades they need to be effective. Individual battles generally don't involve a lot of skill. The switch from drawing being abundant and energy being very rare to drawing being very rare and energy being abundant means it's common for the player to dump their entire hand every turn.

But despite both being deckbuilders with clear, focused, well-communicated design, Monster Train is aiming for a different experience. Slay the Spire is about assembling a toolbox, where you will never be more than a few suboptimal choices away from defeat. That's incredible game design, but it can also be stressful. Monster Train is a game about figuring out how to make yourself invincible using the components the game has given you.

I've put 200 hours into both games and while I give the edge to StS, I enjoyed every minute of Monster Train and I can see how someone else might prefer it.

This is hands down my favourite card game on steam.
If you are a fan of Slay the Spire or similar games you owe it to yourself to try this one.

1. There is stupid amount of replay ability and variety: 10 "champion" cards to pick from after you unlock them all (which if you love games like this will take you a few evenings of addictive fun), picking allied clan/champion means that you have 40 possible starting decks to choose from, which then get further customized at the start by addition of 5 random cards from your covenant lvl. This means that each run starts very uniquely. 
Add to this the fact that you get randomized bosses, and even if you get exact same set-up at the start, you need to change your strategy to fit the final encounter. 

2. From the moment your run start the game tells you what main 3 enemies you will face. No surprises here, instead you get to start preparing a unique strategy for how your deck should evolve from round one. This means that, while there is still a fair amount of randomness in the game, it's just the right amount to give you options, but you will never be surprised by and end boss that just so happens to counter your build. Instead, you get to make sure you counter his.

3.The lore/ art direction is interesting. At first this put me off from buying the game but it's actually quite refreshing. You have a 4-story tall train that you need to defend against an army of angels (who honestly seem to be the bad guys here) as it makes its way towards the frozen heart of hell itself. Pretty weird and quirky. 

If on discount get it, if full price, get it anyway. Well worth the money. 10/10

This game eclipses Slay the Spire for me, and solves two major problems I didn't realize StS had until I played this.

First, runs start off way more interesting. There's only a handful of combats in this game, so you get RIGHT to the interesting decisions. Decks are smaller. There's way less relic-hunting. Upgrades are fat and sweet.

Secondly, the combat itself is so much more satisfying. You are actually playing out units a bit like a simplified tower defense game, and placement matters. You're never just playing out your hand on auto-pilot like StS feels sometimes. 

At first I thought the theme was goofy and made no sense (It's a train! But only one tall and skinny car? And it's all along one path? And you are going through various circles of hell to fight.. angels? And it's kind of steampunky?)  I'll admit I'm still not a huge fan of the art style, but the gameplay brings childlike glee when you smash your big monsters against each other and the childlike theming has warmed on me. 

And for what it's worth, the classes are pretty cool and have been very well thought out. You pick two for each run. There's a lot of crazy mechanisms, and sometimes mixing them doesn't work the way you think, or you get burned by not understanding what's going on, but overall I am pretty satisfied with easy mechanics are to pick up. I am comparing this to Griftlands, which made my head hurt to learn all the different mechanics, often confusingly named. And mechanics are very siloed in general, so it makes it that much less fun to learn.

As a criticism, some of the numbers involved get stupid big. Thank goodness the game does calculations for you and has a fast forward button.

Also, the game is not nearly as forgiving on hardware as Slay the Spire. For a game that's not any prettier, it will chug on my laptop and consume battery 3x as quickly.
Why it's a train, I'll never know, but yes, the designers of this game seem to have never seen a train in their lives.

Monster Train, or: Single Player Heathstone as interpreted by Snow Piercer.

A lot of people are comparing this to Slay the Spire, so let's compare it to Slay the Spire as someone with shy of 400 hours on StS and 50 hours in MT. Both games follow the same format as a roguelite deckbuilder. You have a series of maps with some altering paths along the way, adding cards to your deck as you progress, and every turn in combat you have a limited amount of energy to play your cards. Sometimes, you pick up relics that modify how the game plays.

In my eyes, that's where the similarities end. Monster Train has several "layers" to it that the enemies try to scale to reach the Pyre, which acts as your health pool. You summon creatures to impede the enemies path, and combat takes place on each individual layer independently. If enemies are not defeated, they advance. Boss units at the end of each fight battle until they lose, or your monsters lose, instead of just one round.

The clans add a lot of fun variety, and being able to pick a secondary clan to diversify the card pool is a lot of fun. The card pools per clan are much smaller than card pools per character in StS, but mixing and matching clans gets you far more variety. There are two major bosses per major boss stage until you get the the end, and each major boss has small variations in their play style (such as attacking immediately or granting buffs to their allies), and the final boss has several styles of his own, which is more than StS has.

However, Monster Train is much, MUCH more forgiving, and in my eyes, far easier than StS. Whether this is a good thing or a bad thing depends on the individual player; I personally find StS' challenge very satisfying, and while Monster Train is a fun little time killer, speeding through all the Champion/clan combinations and up to Covenant rank 11 with one or two losses lacks the same sense of accomplishment. However, StS can be rough, so if you're looking for an easier or more casual time, Monster Train may be perfect for you.

I still recommend Monster Train, even as someone that prefers Slay The Spire. I love any card-based game that uses lanes (RIP SolForge) and I like that it tracks your friends' scores. Hell Train is fun (a strictly timed competition between five players for the best score). The lore for the clans are great. I look forward to what kind of content future updates will bring.

The brutal randomness of Slay the Spire might be the thing that gets its hooks deep into you.  This seems a bit less chaotic.  You have more control and in some very good ways.  

There are 5 races to play with and 3 of them unlock over time.  I just unlocked the 5th.  The achievement states that 65.5% of players have it.  I am guessing it took 40-50 hours of play to get there.  People that like a roguelike card battler really do like this game.  The other things to know about the 5 races is that you pick 2 for each run.  One is your lead and determines your champion.  A zero cost unit that always starts in your hand.  I think this gives you 10 different combinations that you can run.

You fight 7 battles to complete a play through, unless you get killed early.  The later battles can take awhile to complete.  I haven't timed a run but it seems like it takes 90 minutes but is probably 2-3 hours.

After the first 6 battles you get to choose between two sets of upgrades.  Upgrading spells or creatures.  Card removal.  Artifacts.  Random encounter goodness.  Restore health to train so that you might survive the next bad fight.  Duplicate a card.  Get 75 coins.  Some of these will be in one group and some in the other.  You get to choose which set you explore.  Sometimes there will be selection that both choices access.  The upgrades for your cards are still random.  You get three random selections that you can buy individually.  You can pay 50 coins for a random restock.  If you have banked enough coins you can buy all 3, restock, buy the 3 replacements.  

There is a lot of ability to jack up the game difficulty.  At first the game seems way too easy.  I won my first 3 in a row without really trying.  Then I lost.  Each time I played I had jacked the game difficulty up by 1.  I won't play the easiest 2 settings, but after that it depends on how much I have unlocked for the races I am running.  There are 25 difficulty settings, if I remember correctly...  That is pretty awesome.  I will try to beat the game on Covenant level 5 today, and keep working my way up.  

Lots of cool combinations to explore.  I want to talk about some of them but don't want to spoil the discovery.  Enjoy.
Been loving the shit out of this game.  An absolute must-play for fans of roguelikes, especially Slay the Spire.

A great deck-builder with RPG and Tower Defense elements. 40 clan/leader combos all with their own unique flavor and playstyle, detailed customization, hundred of relics and special events, 25+ difficulty levels, community challenges, and crazy casual play options give the game a ton of replay value. The devs are actively adding more to it, and support the modding community too! It even has some limited multiplayer interaction beyond leaderboards for the daily challenges and such. 

A pretty great pickup overall.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes deckbuilder roguelikes or tower defence.

It's basically the best parts of Slay the Spire crossed with the best parts of a tower defense game. During each run, you draft a handful of monsters and spells (how many depends on your build and preference but 20-30 is likely) and customize them with a variety of mix-and-match upgrades to help them defeat waves of invaders followed by a boss. There's a wide variety of monsters with varying purposes, both as combatants and for utility, and an equal variety of spells.

There are 5 monster clans to play as, each of whom have a couple specific focuses and very different gameplay. But in each run you play as an alliance of two clans, with a powerful "champion" from one of them who you can upgrade down three paths. And each faction has two champions (and two sets of starter spells). Taken together, there's a ton of different teamups you can apply even before you draft your first card, and one of the early difficulty modifiers adds a few random cards to your starting deck each run for more variety.

Speaking of, it has a difficulty scaling system similar to Slay the Spire. Each time you win on your highest Covenant level you unlock another level with a tweak to make it slightly harder (the new challenges being cumulative). Unlike STS, you advance on this scale for all factions at the same time, which is for the best since there's more of them. In a nice touch, as long as you're playing at least Covenant level 1 you unlock an alternate card border for any card you beat the game with, encouraging you to try out new cards and new builds. Within a run, each level except the three major bosses also has an optional challenge you can activate for an extra reward (such as extra gold if you give all the enemies a buff).

Enemies have a variety of unique abilities designed to punish over reliance on a certain strategy and force you to be flexible. There's also several variations of each major boss with similarly varied abilities. Another nice feature is that you get a preview of the major bosses (particularly the final boss) at the start of a run to help you plan your build, and before each level you get a preview of the level boss and of the enemy with the most notable special ability (with a description of said ability).

There's also daily challenges (with leaderboards) which apply a variety of modifiers to the game to make it easier or harder, and you can mix and match those modifiers yourself for a custom game. And heck, there's a few more extra modes I haven't even tried yet. This game has tons of replayability.

Production values are very high, with great visuals, music and sound design. The story premise is simple if you want to be but if you like lore there's in-character descriptions for every card and artifact in the between-runs logbook, along with in-battle dialog, which you can put together for a broader story.

There's so much to keep coming back for, catered to all play styles. You can be the simple physical smash deck with Hellbound or you can do something a little bit different by having weak starter cards and buff them gradually with something like Umbra. The champions are well balanced, although being honest - anything with multistrike absolutely destroys. Usually....

One of my favorite roguelike deck builders. The gameplay TD-ish in the sense that you have three floors/lanes, enemies spawn from the bottom and advance up each turn. Combat happens automatically with Attack stats striking defense stats, and enemies attacking first unless you have abilities that do otherwise.

It borrows a bit from deck-builders like Smash Up! in the sense that there are many different factions with their own cardpools and champions. You select one faction to be your primary (and you get to use their Champion -- a creature that always starts in your hand that you often will build around), and another to be your secondary. These will be the two cardpools and artifact pools you work with and draft from thru the game.

Champions have upgrade paths and each faction has two champions. Between each floor are upgrade/shop floors to upgrade cards, get events, artifacts, and so on.

There are just so many viable ways to build and fun interactions to make.

The game is really good and making you feel "OP" and letting you have seemingly broken and really fun synergies and interactions. At higher difficulty "Ascension" levels, you'll find that you'll need this kind of OP damage for the last boss.

One of the most well put together and just plain fun deck builders I've ever played since Spire. With the giant wave of deckbuilders that came following Spire, I was hesitant to try this one but it's in my all-time favorites now.

This game is perfect for killing time doing something solo.  The graphics and game concept are well done and professional, with an interesting take on your typical deck building game.  Unlike other deck building games though, you need no opponent to play and enjoy it, and that isn't because they replace a typical opponent with an AI opponent, but rather its more of a "build your deck to survive to the finish".

It involves no AI, and yet remains challenging, with lots of options for customizing each game, and enough randomness to provide a unique experience every time you play.

Coming from Slay the Spire, overall I've found this game to be underwhelming. I've expected it to be more like roguelite deckbuilder game with a MtG/Hearthstone-style creature battle system. Instead it plays like a TD, a genre I am not a fan of. You basically set up a defence using limited space and then see how it fares against the boss. Rince and repeat. It's very puzzle-ish.

My main issue with the game is that it just feels so random, and that's coming from someone who enjoys roguelikes and card games. While in Slay the Spire you more or less understand why you've lost (aha, I should not have picked all those low impact powers in Act 3 against the Awakened One), in this game, you are left wondering what exactly went wrong. Some of the games you just stomp with absolutely no challenge, and some games feel hopeless. Overall balance just feels wild. In Slay the Spire, upgrading a card can make it 2 times better, in this game, it can make it... 10 times better?

While there are 5 factions you can combine (leading into total of 10/20 combinations depending on how you count), game does not appear to be that varied. Every faction has very few strategies. Green? Well, 90% of your synergies will be with heal and thorns. Blue? Well, you will have to go spell-heavy. Mixing them up does not change your gameplan, you have your main and supporting factions. No dual color cards.

It is not a terrible game, but it feels lacking, considering the price asked. If you enjoy TDs as much as deckbuilers, maybe you'll have a better experience.

My only minor gripe is that the first time you beat it comes a bit too easy, otherwise it's fantastic. It's addictive and there are so many choices and options to keep it fresh. The differences between decks keeps it fresh and provides a lot of extra enjoyment. The train is too tall though, it's not so much a train as it is a tower. Monster Tower on tracks is a fantastic game though.

Pitch perfect evolution of Slay The Spire's JRPG-style turn-based deckbuilder format, pumped up with elements of monster collecting and tower defense. That said, imaginative design and some high-quality worldbuilding helps to make Monster Train a fresh and groundbreaking experience on all fronts.

Monster Train sets itself apart from other deckbuilding roguelites with its unique battle system. 

Decks are built using monster and spell cards rather than attack and skill cards making deckbuilding more akin to traditional versus card games like Magic and Hearthstone. The combat itself happens over the course of 3 levels of your train + the top Pyre floor with surviving enemies going up a floor after each combat. The 5 factions all have unique gameplay elements and the champions gameplay varies even among the same champion as you can choose their upgrade path. 

There are several game modes, difficulties, and as mentioned above factions that you can play giving it a lot of replay value. The only downside I've found is that playing the same faction over and over can get stale since there are only so many cards and you tend to get forced into an archetype based on your champion's abilities. Having a secondary faction helps mitigate this though and overall it's a fun game that'll hook you in quickly if you're a fan of the genre

[h1] Summary [/h1]
[b]The game is fun and I enjoyed finishing all the classes.[/b] However, the Overwhelmingly Positive is not quite deserved, the game is overrated. At first, the game is way too easy (and that might not a bad thing for some casual players) but at the current price of 20‚Ç¨ I cannot recommend this game.

After finishing the game with a class, you can play on a new difficulty mode called "Covenant Rank" which goes from 1 to 25; so that you have an idea covenant 1 starts to be challenging (compared to the base difficulty which is non-existing) and RNG plays a big role. The more you play the more repetitive the run feels, the added difficulty is very artificial.

In short, [b]Slay the Spire is still superior in most aspects[/b].
[hr][/hr]
[h1] How this game compares to Slay the Spire [/h1]
If you don¬¥t have Slay The Spire and you are trying to decide which one to buy: go for Slay the Spire without a doubt; If you already have it and you want a similar game it¬¥s probably the best next alternative out there.

Monster Train is much easier than Slay The Spire generally speaking. Graphically, both have their charm. Both feel slick while playing. 

The core mechanics in both games vary just a bit and in my opinion Slay The Spire does a much better job overall, however, they share several things like the stops between fights, artifacts, etc. I would only recommend Monster Train if you own and finished Slay The Spire - at least with the basic characters - on the default difficulty.

[h1]Slay the Spire or Monster Train if I have none of them?[/h1]
Slay the Spire, without a doubt. Unless you are looking to play in "zen" mode, totally casual, in which case you might find Monster Train more appealing.

Ultimately, both Spire The Slay and Monster train can get a bit repetitive, is just that the mechanics of Monster Train makes it a bit more annoying.

[h1]How is the game, though?[/h1]
Graphics are good, music is decent, the game runs smooth. At first, the game is very interesting and definitively fun, but it gets repetitive very fast once you win with all the classes.

The "covenant" difficulty is not very well calibrated, covenant 1 is orders of magnitude more difficult than the default and you depend on the RNG a lot more.

In my case I already played Slay the Spire which I got from some bundle and I enjoyed Monster Train, which is essentially a copy of it. And so, I found Monster Train refreshing, but I cannot advise anyone to play this game first and then Slay The Spire to be honest.

You can beat the game with all classes in a few hours, your first run win can be in less than an hour, so it¬¥s that easy. IMHO, there should be more tracks per run, at least one more should be added.

The game at the full price is arguably expensive, I got it on 20% discount which is not that much after you see its content.

[b]What about replayability?[/b]
It has pvp, daily run and challenges. Since it has many classes and combinations together with covenant modes I can say there is a ton of replayability in Monster Train. Unfortunately, it gets boring rather fast and the difficulty added by the 25 Covenant Ranks is just tedious rather than fun.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
The game is fun (even if not for too long). You should play Slay the Spire first except if you want to play on "easy mode" only.

You can easily get up to ~30h of gameplay having fun before you enter Covenant Ranks, then it gets a bit tedious and more repetitive but if you are looking for a challenge you should play Slay the Spire.
Great game, great mechanics, can't wait for the upcoming DLC, I've clocked in over 100 hours and intend on playing even more

This is easily one of the most addictive games that I have played in a long time.  The deck-building aspect of the game feels fair and rewarding by giving you choices between floors.  This game receives frequent comparisons to Slay the Spire and rightfully so.  They are both deck-building games.  BUT, Monster Train feels more balanced.  There are no random monster encounters between rooms -- only ways to improve your deck.  The choice between starters empowers you from the start and, more often than not, you'll run across cards that will compliment your leader.  If you are looking for a game to buy and/or on the fence about this game, I assure you -- you will NOT regret your purchase.

Monster Train is great fun--the game is polished and looks beautiful, the battles are tough, the deckbuilding works pretty well, and the progressive unlocks are fun. Runs are a bit shorter than Slay the Spire, which I like, but I find that I have more of a sense of skill and control while playing StS than with Monster Train, which I sometimes find a bit chaotic.

Great game

Great game. Any fan of Slay the Spire will most likely enjoy this. It is a sort of mixture of a card battler and a turn based tower defense where the towers are demons and minions you put down to fight against the hordes of angelic freaks out to destroy the life source of your train. It is pretty unique and great fun with various factions to choose from. Each play through you pick two factions and will only draw cards from those two factions and some neutral cards. You also get a much stronger and unique champion unit from your main faction. After enough play time you eventually unlock a second champion for each faction that can mix up the starting cards and playstyle quite a bit.

Each faction also plays quite differently from the rest. For example the starting faction has a lot of units and cards built around rage. Another faction is more plant based and seems built around tanks, spikes, and healing. It can be really interesting to mix and match the various factions to see how they complement each other. My favorite faction is really unique compared to the rest here and essentially involves making the front unit stronger through cannibalizing other units. 

Just like slay the spire, it is essential to find a way to scale, and there are various paths to do so. Just because a faction may be good at a particular strategy doesn't mean you will always roll that strategy and trying something new can surprise you. 

One thing I like is that after the initial run, each following run will display the three main bosses (like act bosses) at the beginning of the run. That way you can read ahead of time what each will do to be sure you don't build a deck that will be hard countered by them. It is important to read these, can be frustrating to scale via buffs then find out the final boss will just purge your buffs anyways making the DPS race much harder.

I do think Monster Train is one of the best card battlers out there and will be a mainstay along with Slay the Spire. My only real gripe with it is the same as other card battlers and that is they entice players to keep playing by challenging themselves on higher ascension difficulties. I had fun climbing them for a while but at some point some of the curses that come with the higher difficulty just got annoying -  such as stunning the top floor when you place a monster there. I understand the challenges are ways to force you to strategize more and vary your usual playstyles but at some point difficulty becomes less of a fun factor and more of a frustration. That is me though, there are certainly many out there that love the challenge.

Besides, nothing forces you to keep ascending. There are many records and a card compendium to fill out - can always just continue running normal playthroughs and attempt win streaks or just play for fun. It's a great game and can keep you going for a long while.

This is a good game, I would recommend it, but I would wait for a sale. If you came here for a change of pace from Slay the Spire or other deck builders, it is a little different but it is useful for comparisons. Overall I would say that a good run on monster train is way shorter than Slay the Spire, and that may be a positive for some as you get more runs, I dislike that fact, because it limits the amount of deck building choices you make. Each run in monster train feels like an act and a half in Slay the Spire, and this has consequences.

There is no early, medium, or late cards, its what cards fit into your already existing archetype--so when in Slay the Spire you may pick up a card to survive the early game or avoid a good card because its too late to be good, this game lacks those decisions, once you start a deck a card is either good in your deck or it wont ever be. The shorter game also limits the amount of satisfaction i feel from making a good deck, by the time its working its over.

Instead all the choices are based within the combat, where you set up your units and let them auto battle. On your turn you generally either buff your units, put more units into play, or attack or debuff the enemy. Since you can't easily rearrange your units, each battle seems more like a puzzle than combat. I love that, finding a balance between wiping mobs and making sure the resources are properly distributed to handle the boss.

The covenant system is supposed to be like Slay the Spires ascension, but I think it needs reworking. Some of them don't really impact the game all that much, and the ones that do are really boring effects, like a small buff to enemy damage. I still struggle to beat Slay the Spire's higher difficulties, but monster train, once I got a hang of it, I flew through the early covenants not sure if they were supposed to make the game harder or not.

Overall the game is good, I just wish there was at least an option to have longer runs with more deck building opportunities. If I were to put a price I would recommend this game as a must have it would be around fifteen bucks. If there was an option to extend a run, like an epilogue or anything I would recommend full price

Not sure what I was buying/getting with this game, a blind purchase; but I enjoyed it enough to put in over 100 hours. 
The gameplay involves you choosing an alliance between two factions and getting a hero unit in which you will use to defend the bases core in a 3 tier tower defense style play.

The fun comes from all the support units and spells you get that are represented as cards in a deck. You draft from a selection in the overworld and then play them out in turn based combat.

The challenge comes from punishing Rogue-like mechanics which reset you back to start should you lose.

The variety is that everytime you restart a new shuffled game awaits.

What stinks, but sometimes doesn't smell is that the difficulty mostly scales by forcing you to begin with a worse deck.
