If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, you will definitely enjoy Monster Train. An excellent deck builder strategy game with excellent visuals and a fantastic soundtrack. 10/10, would most certainly recommend.

The game has 5 clans and a run consists of a primary clan backed up by another one which results in 20 clan combinations (the two starting clans have to be different) and that`s only the beginning. Each clan has a champion with 3 possible evolution paths and it evolves 3 times during a run which again adds to the variety of the run. When you add on top of that a large number of clan cards and shops that can upgrade those cards along the way and artefacts that actually influence the run, you get huge replay value.

The game also has daily challenges and a "multiplayer" where multiple people start the same run and everyone has to play against the clock and the winner is the one with the most points. 

Also, the game is very polished and the UX is for the most part very good. I`m struggling to find negatives for this game, but one of them would be the unintuitive interaction between spell shield and damage shield with some spells, artefacts and effects. Another example would be how silence and ‚Äúremove enemy buff‚Äù effects are again not what I was expecting them to be. These negatives are really minor and can be figured out with trial and error, but I couldn`t come up with other negatives.

Update: 350 hours later I still love this game and there have been so many new great additions and so many things planned for the future. I really can`t recommend this game enough.

I bought the game for 20% off at ¬£15.59 2 weeks after its release, the last day of the release sale. 

The game both plays and looks very similarly to Slay the Spire. It's a deck building rougelite with "floors".
As for the story, hell has frozen over and you, playing as factions from hell, try to reignite the fires. Heaven has sent beings to stop you.

I "beat" the game 2 hours in meaning I defeated the final boss for the first time but doing so I unlocked Covenant, effectively the same as Slay the Spire's Ascension.


- (Content) Because it is so similar to Slay the Spire, it also has its pitfalls: dead runs from the start and limited variation. However, there is slightly more variation due to having 5 clans and choosing a primary and ally clan each time means there's many unique ways to theme your deck.

~ (Story) There's a small story about the wars between Heaven and Hell.
~ It is VERY similar Slay the Spire. It has copied: artefacts, upgrades, Ascension and risk vs. reward fights just to name a few. Perhaps they are a staple to this relatively new genre? There are a few unique mechanics though: the levels on the train and the 2-class system. 

+ (Audio) Music sounds like a battle between heaven and hell. Strong clangs battling heavenly strings. The sound effects are also satisfying clangs or metal or blood squelches.
+ (Content, Replayability) Covenant ranks extend the life of the game making you want to repeat it with added difficulties.
+ (Replayability) The game is quick to pick (back) up and I definitely will be coming back to it in the future to further my Covenant rank and get victories with primary/ally clan combinations that I haven't gotten.
+ Discovering new combinations of cards and then beating the game gives a good sense of accomplishment.

Best: Building up a massive multistrike backline and spikes frontline combo and destroying a boss.
Worst: It feels too much like Slay the Spire and so doesn't feel fresh. If I'd played this first, it probably would be the other way round.

This is by far the most addicting game to come out in 2020.

Much like Slay the Spire, you build a deck by drafting cards while navigating a map and engaging in battles, in this case, you are riding a train through the now-frozen 9 circles of Hell with the last vestige of the Pyre which can re-ignite Hell to it's former blazing glory.

What differentiates this is that you choose a combination of 2 factions, one which is your main and one your secondary.  The main faction will determine who your Champion, a special card, is while the combination of both will determine the contents of your starting deck.  The game consist of 8 multi-wave battles on your 4-level train as the forces of "good" try to climb its floors and extinguish your pyre which sits on the topmost floor.  You play cards either Units or Spells to defeat each wave until the boss Spawns.

Once you complete the game the first time, you unlock Covenant levels which are similar to Ascendancy levels.  Each subsequent level will give you penalties to make the run harder.

Another very nice feature is the ability to creature custom challenges that can be shared and played simultaneously among friends each challenge having their own leader boards.

I have over 900 hours player in Slay the Spire and I believe this game will have more longevity because of the multiplayer aspects and the multiple faction system.

End of 2020 has arrived and this is still one of the better card builder games out there.

Whilst Monster Train takes a lot of inspiration from Slay the Spire, it changes up the formula in a way that feels refreshing.  Instead of playing as a character, you play as a train in an almost tower defence-esque style. The various combinations of monster clans available for players to choose from and additional optional challenges means that almost no two runs will be the same. Replayability is one of this game's greatest strengths, allowing for players to try out different clan combinations and strategies. With its reasonable price point and in my opinion excellent bang-for-your-buck value, this is an absolute recommend.
Yes, really good game
pog game

If you like slay the spire, then getting this game is a no brainer. The developers have no qualms about the fact that this game was inspired by slay the spire (going as far as offering a 20% discount for Slay The Spire owners at launch), but has a huge number of variations to make it a different game on its own. There is an extra element of strategy involved in unit placement (borrowed from tower defence games) which can make or break your run. In one of my runs, I got destroyed by a boss because I forgot that he can directly climb from floor 3 to floor 1 and floor 2 had my most powerful units. Apart from this, there are 5 clans at launch, with a number of cards to unlock and get this, you get to play not as 1, but as 2 clans at the same time, which means that there are 20 combinations possible. 
The game seems fairly balanced and you can customise cards depending on your run, during the course of the run. How many times have you thought, in STS, man do I wish this card cost 1 energy less, well, you can do that in this game. With some card combinations it's possible to breeze through the run, only to have the game kick you in your balls and tell you bitch, you ain't shit. 
To summarise, this game is STS but with tower defence and crack.

This game is so good it makes Darkest Dungeon, Slay the Spire and Teamfight Tactics (each the titan of their genre) entirely obsolete in comparison. It's not every day a game is so innovative and so perfectly executed that it dethrones entire, brand-new genres of gaming all by itself - and every fan of the aforementioned games or card games in general owe it to themselves to give Monster Train a try!

The game looks, sounds, controls and has a soundtrack that is exactly what you'd expect from it and it runs like a charm even on integrated graphics cards (tested on an Intel HD 4000-equivalent). I wish there were more keyboard controls but I can't complain about the current control scheme either.

EDIT: no longer working on Linux through Steam Play (Proton).

Other than needing to skip the non-playing introduction video (black screen) with a mouse click, it works flawlessly on Linux through Steam Play. Being an Unity game, it's confounding why there isn't a native download of the game at all!

The possibilities for combinations between the multiple factions caters to every type of playstyle you could think of, and the RNG is just punishing enough to make it challenging, while being just lenient enough to make you think "I messed that up" when you lose; not "the game screwed me over." I purchased this game on the day of release without having heard of it before the day it showed up in my Steam queue.

Monster Train is a deck building rogue-like. Expect to play through the game many times (this isn't a bad thing). Here's how it works: You'll choose a primary and secondary faction to join you in your quest to protect your demon train as it travels through the tracks on its way to relight the pyres of hell. At each stop you'll face a boss and its minions. You'll play cards to bring out minions of your own. The object of each level is to keep the angelic minions from reaching the top of the train and destroying the last pyre of hell.

Okay, it may sound a touch confusing, but it's super easy to learn.

If you like deck building games, as I do, you'll probably like Monster Train. Each game can take up to an HOUR to play through, so it's similar to a digital board game in many respects. Maybe you make it to the pyres and relight them, probably you'll get killed by Fel ... or that ass with the bombs. But you WILL have fun along the way.  I've played it ever day since I picked it up and I've been having a blast.  I hope you do too.  #Recommend

TL;DR: The game is fun, but lacks variance in its challenges.

I really enjoy the thought and originality that went into creating this game, but it's hard to give this a solid 100% yes. The gameplay is a lot of fun. Clearly inspired by Slay the Spire, the objective is to defend your train by building a deck; from this deck you play creatures to a train with three different floors, or cast spells. After you pass your turn, the game almost works more like a tower defense; the enemy creatures attack, then your creatures attack, and then all the remaining enemies advance one floor upward, or fight it out with your pyre (sort of like your "base" in tower defense games).

You create a starting deck from two factions: a primary, and a secondary. The primary clan gives you a champion (one of two), a powerful and free creature which you always begin each combat with. Otherwise, what clan you pick only determines which cards you start with and which cards/relics will be available for the run. After this, you alternate between combat, and choosing one of two sets of rewards. Every third combat is a boss battle.

While the spells and creatures have some interesting interactions, and it can feel incredibly rewarding to pull off some of the combos, my main problem with this game is that it feels fairly limited in its challenges. Each level has only one or two sets of enemies to fight against, with an optional random "modifier" you can apply to make the fight harder in exchange for an additional reward. While these can create some interesting new challenges, ultimately, I found that quickly, it felt pretty, well, same-y. You either have a strong engine, or you don't. Once I get a strong engine/start, usually, I find the game becomes too easy (even at high ascension levels). If I don't, it's either a rough climb, or a quick loss. The bosses, while they have some variations on the same six possibilities (I believe there's two or three variants of two possible boss encounters, except the final boss, which is the same with three variants). 

It's hard to put my finger on exactly what it is about this game that doesn't quick click, in my opinion, like Slay the Spire did; because even in StS, there were only so many possible encounters. But I think if I had to pick a few reasons, they would be 1) that in each run, you're locked into the same reward-fight-reward-fight pattern, which feels a bit old after a while; 2) that your relics you encounter don't feel as rewarding as in Slay the Spire, as they often feel either too powerful, or not powerful at all (and thus, you can't use them to milk extra effectiveness out of how you play quite as much); and 3) that, while there are six factions to play with, each of which with their own unique champions and mechanics, ultimately, they all serve the same purpose: to spam huge buffs on one or two crucial units, which then carry the whole game for you.

That being said, the game has some great things going for it. The soundtrack is great, the devs seem responsive to player feedback, there are some multiplayer/community options (such as a "race" mode), and the gameplay is genuinely fun and unique. I would say this is definitely worth checking out if it sounds interesting to you, and you'll get your money's worth. But it's worth noting a few of its flaws before purchasing.

This has become a fast favorite of mine. I love deck building games and this has some of that element. It is an easy game to learn but offers a fair challenge once you feel you have a clear understanding of the card combos you can achieve through the various faction pairs. 

A 'Run Through' (Game) consists of 6 or 7 sections with your chosen faction pair. Each section allows you to boost/buff your deck with a new artifact, new card, or new card enhancements. Then you 'fight' to proceed to the next section until you reach a final Boss section. New cards are unlocked along the way (win or lose). 

A game like this is perfect and relaxing for me while I am listening to a book or when I may be called away at a moment for work or other. Easily my favorite game of 2020 thus far.

This is not only a well made, fun game, but it seems to have solved (or at least vastly improved) the "lane" mechanic attempted by other games such as Artifact, Elder Scrolls: Legends, and Gwent.  The aforementioned games approached lanes in their various ways, but the approach in Monster Train feels not only the most intuitive, but genuinely adds to the game's strategy and fun, while feeling streamlined instead of cumbersome.  Even without the lane mechanic, Monster Train would be an interesting and enjoyable card fighter, brandishing a personality that sets it apart from the saturated genre.  It's smooth, fast, interesting, fun, has professional quality and depth, and just downright feels good to play.  Definitely compels the "just one more run!" user experience that signals the hallmarks of a good game.  Highly recommended!

Edit: Updated for 2020 Steam Awards; nominated for "Sit Back and Relax Award".

Update 11/27/2020 - After sinking about 80 hours into the game, I have to say this is my choice for game of the year.  The mechanics are a combination of Slay the Spire and Darkest Dungeon with the visuals of Hearthstone.  

When starting out, it is best to experiment with each clan with the following recommendations:

*  When selecting units or spells  it is best to take the paths towards your primary clan.
*  When you only have spells or units from your support clan look for ones that offer the best utility.
*  You want to have a Tank, DPS, and some type of buff unity.
*  You will typically want to place your hero on the top or middle floor so you have time to setup floors.
*  Look to add units or spells that offer incant or buffs.
*  You typically want to take additional draws or add draw cards to your hand so that you can buff your primary damage units.
* For unit bufffs. you should prioritize add health to your tanks, and multistrike & damage to your damage heroes.
* For spells you should look to reduce the cost for your bigger spells, add endless to your best buffs or sweeping spells.
* Make sure to also remove the Train Stewards and starting spells.  I typically will add a damage / consume to spells and prioritize removing stewards first.

The skill ceiling gets progressively harder as you complete covenants with each level adding changes to the the play environment.  You will had to adjust your approach in order to put out the needed DPS and debuffs.  That is why having additional card draw is important.

[h1] TLDR: If you like Slay the Spire, buy Monster Train.[/h1] 

Monster Train is the best deckbuilding roguelike I've played, after Slay the Spire. The gameplay is a fusion of "summoning followers" style card games (MtG, Hearthstone), deckbuilding roguelikes (StS), and tower defense Games. 


[h1] PROS:[/h1] 
[*] [b]A lot of combinations.[/b] There are 5 classes, and in each run you have one as the main and one as the sub. So there's 20 different combination of ways to play with each classes' unique and interesting mechanics. After almost 10 hours, I haven't even tried the last class yet, as there is so many combinations to explore. 

[*] [b]Much less "grindy" combat.[/b] In StS, some of the beginning rounds can be absolutely boring to play. Monster Train solves this by having every fight have a boss at the end, and reducing the amount of fights needed to win.

[*] [b]The UI.[/b] Everything is clear, everything can be learned from the UI. You don't even need to do maths, the UI does it for you. One of the best game UIs I have ever seen.

[/list]

[h1] CONS:[/h1] 
 [*] [b]Balancing issues.[/b] Due to the insane amount of combinations, this was to be expected. The game is still new as of the time I'm writing this, so maybe the devs would work on the balancing. Holdover, Multistrike are two of the upgrades I find absolutely broken. One of the most broken card imo  is "Unleash the Wildwood", a 0 cost green card that heals everyone to full. At the first glance, I assumed it consumed the card. 

[*] [b]Weird Difficulty Curve.[/b] Imo, the early game is more difficult than the late game. Most of the time when you reach the Seraph (final boss), your deck is strong enough to beat him easily. However, in the earlier battles, you sometimes take so much damage in the first few battles, and it usually is completely out of one's control. Due to summoned creatures not recycled into the discard, some games, especially in the early game, can be over when your champion dies. 

[*] [b] Randomness affects runs too much.[/b] Compared to StS, there are much fewer chances to add cards into the deck, so the likelihood of the run getting ruined by bad rng is higher. Starting from Covenant 1 (this game's version of Ascension), you get random cards added to the deck at the start of runs. That can ruin the run, or make it really easy. Also some events are busted, like the make 5 duplicates of a card event. 

[*] [b]The sound[/b] It can be really annoying for the boss fights. Maybe add an instant end effect.

[/list]

Despite its flaws, Monster Train is still an amazing game, and I believe it would keep improving. At of time of this review, I have been playing at the difficulty of Covenant 1/2, so my opinions are based on that.

One part rogue-like, one part deck-builder, one part turn-based combat game; it's an eclectic combination that's unlike anything I've played before. It's obviously a distant cousin of Slay the Spire, but it's different enough to feel like a completely new experience. It feels well-balanced, has an excellent art style, and the music is even great. If there's a problem with it, it's that it starts to feel a little repetitive after sixty or so hours. Seems like value to me.

A weird hybrid between Slay the Spire rogue-lite deck-bulding card game and a tower defense game. Lots of cool characters, OP synergies. Nothing is better than seeing a big'ol hellish monster destroy every single angel. And the dev is so enthusiastic and active that new contents keep pouring out!!!

A pleasant addition to the up and coming roguelite card-battler genre, with subtle twists that makes it unique enough to not being considered generic. 

The game's dual-clan system adds a lot of replayability in a genre that already lives of it. With a flat 10 different clan combinations and several playable build for each, many hours can be spent to just explore what suits your playstyle. The clans themselves are varied, althought I'd say the power difference between some are a bit steep (sorry Hellborne, you suck). The most interesting difference in my opinion is the use of a three-floor stage, further adding to the strategic complexity. You can split units evenly amongst them, leave some open for AoE spells, overstack the top floor etc. Higher difficulties can directly impact the floor system, which in my opinion are some of the most penalties.

The downside, in my humble opinion, is the aestethics. The music is fair enough, some soundtracks are actually awesome, but the graphics is unappealing to me. It's polished enough, but somehow it reminds me of a mobile game. Not enough to keep me away from playing it, thought.

So if you're looking for a strategy game that can be played in relatively short bursts for months to come, or if you really liked Slay the Spire, don't hesitate. Totally worth it even at full price as a lot added content has been free!

This game can be very easily compared to slay the spire as it shares many basic features, however this game notably allows you to combine different factions for various synergies and strategies. Also unlike STS this game involves the placement of minions rather than attacking directly. The battles in this game take place on several vertically stacked fields, where enemies that arent killed or hindered ascend each round. Due to these features there is a lot more strategizing to be done in this game than in STS. 

The only thing I remotely dislike is the visual style of the game, it can be a little inconsistent and some of the animations don't make sense or don't have the correct weight to them. Rector Flicker's lanterns specifically don't make much sense, they seem to float around a little,  and the Hornbreaker prince's weapons slide around in his hands in an odd way. This is however a small nitpick, and the mechanics are the real star of the show here.

Monster Train is an extremely addictive deck building roguelike. Pick one of 10 unique heroes, choose one of 5 allied clans, and off you go. You play as the bad guys and your objective is to defend the last train to hell from waves of invading heroes. Each wave becomes more difficult, but rewards you with extra cards, credits and possibly some magic artifact. In between waves you get ample opportunities to add or remove cards, repair your train, boost cards or buy artifacts. Each run feels different, there is a daily challenge with run modifiers, you can setup your own custom challenge, and there are end-game objectives aplenty. I like everything about this game, both art and gameplay are very much my cup of tea. If you love(d) Slay the Spire, I think this game can scratch that same itch while at the same time being very different. 10/10 for me, easy recommendation. I even voted for this game to be Game of the Year in the 2020 Steam awards!

I've been a fan of roguelike deckbuilders since slay the spire, and have tried most of the newest iterations released so far. This one tops them all:
Replayability - with 5 clans, and 2 variable starting champions each (as well as 3 different upgrade paths you can mix), there are so many options to build a deck around. Plus, cards in this game don't have set upgrade path(s) but you can purchase from a relatively large pool of upgrades, furthermore increasing variability in the decks you can make. Like StS, there is mod support, so the game will only become even bigger. Also, I quite enjoy the daily challenges and comparing scores with friends and looking at the different strategies others have used successfully to beat the same run.
Mechanics - There is greater depth in the game mechanics compared to its peers. You have to consider not only mana and card advantage, but also the different floors and space/room on each floor (playing umbra for the first time made this painfully clear). There is more to think about regarding the path you take, like do you want to upgrade your spells or your creatures? Do you take the challenge in the upcoming battle for a chance at a greater reward (maybe trading pyre health for additional gold/score)? Is that challenge feasible for your current deck? How do I best combine the strengths of the two current clans? Coming from a guy who has put hundreds of hours into StS, compared to this game, StS is quite "barebones".
Music - The soundtrack is just awesome. Seriously, go listen to it on youtube.

PROS: More complex than Slay the Spire. You pick a MAIN/ASSIST each time, so you have more combos to replay. There's also a difficulty scale that increases the encounters with more rewards. AND each mini boss has a challenge if you toggle it you get more rewards. 

Trinkets/artifacts/etc are often RNG 

The FINAL BOSS is pretty meh. It just feels like another mini boss but this is on lower levels, I haven't worked my way up yet.

So far this is actually MORE fun than Slay the Spire, but that may be the 'newness' of it. It clearly took a lot of inspiration from that game in all the best ways.

So yeah, if you liked Slay the Spire buy this now, don't even wait for a sale. You'll love it.

Edit: Yes this game is amazing

Not to mention, if you DO enjoy losing horribly, there's 25 difficulty settings to ramp up the game. There's even mod support, so give it some time and I'm sure the community will cook up some ludicrous extra content for all of us to enjoy!

A deckbuilding game with unique and enthralling gameplay. Finding synergy and balancing short-term and long-term decisions is necessary at every turn, and it's exciting to plan out strategies and watch them come to life. If you are a fan of Slay the Spire, you will also love this game.
